content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
Half-genie, all quality.CONTENTWhile this game is a bit shorter than the series' previous outings (though the addition of in-development add-on content at a later date will likely change that), the gameplay, animation, sound and visual design are all utterly fantastic.The game sports pop-in voice overs at select points in the otherwise (and more often than not hilarious) message box based dialogue, that the developers at WayForward used to great effect to enhance the charm of the game. There is also a bevy of usually well-hidden items to collect throughout the levels that will require copious backtracking to acquire all of- several of which, as with past entries in the series, will result in encounters with some of the game's highly amusing NPC characters.The soundtrack to the game is also completely fantastic. Composed by WayForward go-to composer, the masterful Jake 'Virt' Kaufman, the entirety of the game's score is nothing short of pure ear candy. Every stage, cinematic, screen and else all exude top-quality music that earns the games' track list the highest of marks.CONTROLSThe game controls extremely well with tight responsiveness to input, and features native controller support for those that want a more classic gaming experience.The series' signature transformations are triggered by pressing a key/button to enter dance mode, at which point any currently available transformations can be selected via a wheel that will appear on screen, which switches pages in time with the beat.In addition, usable items such as those used to restore health are accessed via the game's item menu, which features a simple and efficient design with scrollable lists and fields rather than relying on spreading items and features across multiple pages.GAMEPLAYThe game is entirely a side-scrolling single-depth platformer, as with (for the most part) all previous Shantae installments.There are a few spontaneous and sudden upswings in difficulty at select points throughout the game, though most players will find that in some cases these troubles are merely caused by a lack of clarity as to the intended objective at hand, rather than that of a spontaneous rise in the actual challenge of the gameplay. In most cases, these unfortunate but minor hurdles can be overcome quickly once the solution is discovered, resulting in a speedy resolution and a return to the game's usual play.In addition to the previously mentioned (as of this writing) pending additional gameplay content, the game also boasts a new game+ feature which allows you to replay the story after beating the game once with all of your main transformations unlocked from the start of the game, perfect for speed running purposes.GRAPHICSFeaturing a clean blend of high-quality hand-drawn character sprites, specific world elements, enemies, items, etc., and typical 3D environments, the game's '2.5D' graphics presentation are refreshing and striking. The combination of vivid color palettes and layered animations make the game stand out noticeably and beautifully. Even in spite of combinations of multiple entities, particle effects, and more on screen at many points throughout the game, it maintains a consistent run speed that should function fairly well even on less than impressive machines (I played the game on a relatively underpowered laptop, and suffered no lag or frame loss the entire game).Overall, Shantae: Â½ Genie Hero is a stellar addition to an already extremely consistently quality franchise that will likely go down, and unsurprisingly so, as the greatest installment in the series yet. While a tad underwhelming in length, the entirety of the rest of what's on offer is fantastic. If you like classic platforming games, striking visual presentation, and constant comedic banter, then you're sure to come away from this one thoroughly satisfied.

content:
Posted: January 6
												A few years ago, I was browsing the virtual console games on 3DS and found a game called Shantae, which was originally for Gameboy Color. I played it and found it clunky, but the characters and world were very charming, so I picked up the next game. Risky's Revenge was solid and improved a lot of the gameplay, and I became a bit excited when I heard that Shantae and the Pirate's Curse was coming out. Shantae and the Pirate's Curse was absolutely one of the best games I've ever played, so when I found the option to kickstart a new entry to this series which I've become really fond of, I absolutely did.And it delivered.Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is an incredibly solid entry into the Shantae series. While the pixel art of the previous games was amazing, I really do like this new art style, and I'm a sucker for 3D backgrounds with 2D characters. The game is really pretty, keeps up with the silly quirky story and characters I've come to love, has great platforming, and is absolutely a worthwhile sequel.The game improves upon a few things from previous entries. One of the biggest problems in the first two Shantae games was how long transformations took for the amount of times you needed to use them. Transformation dances took a LONG time, and really took you out of the moment. To be completely honest, the best part of Pirate's Curse was how there were no transformation dances. The Metroid-style pirate items they used as a replacement made the action smoother and more enjoyable. Half-Genie Hero did take a page from this to an extent, and made transforming MUCH easier and quicker, especially with the optional Metronome item that increases the speed further, but the best thing they did was triple the amount of dances Shantae could perform. This gives the player many options on how to tackle a puzzle, and while I think some could have been utilized further than they were, I really appreciate having so many creatures to transform into! I really feel like they hit the sweet spot of Shantae having her signature transformations while keeping the gameplay smooth.In terms of music, Half-Genie Hero has definitely gone more electronic than its predecessors, but in a good way. It's very lively and really gets your heart pumping. It makes you feel good to play while listening to it. I think good music is a very important component to making a game enjoyable, and the Shantae series has always delivered on this. I love the track for Mermaid Falls especially!There are a few negatives, of course. I feel that some of the unlockable items are utterly useless except for achievements (a lot are just attacks for your animal forms, which generally are very weak and serve little purpose). There are also times where I would get stuck in an area after a puzzle and need to exit the entire level just to get out of that room, or going into a new room would totally screw up my camera requiring exiting the level as well. I also really miss dungeons, which were a Shantae staple up to this point, but the new level-based design really wouldn't have allowed for them the same way, so I can give them a pass on that.In terms of gray areas, things that some people might like and some people won't: There is a LOT of backtracking through levels, and its really hard to avoid some enemy attacks. You're going to get hit and need items to restore your health. Both of these are really common in all Shantae games though, so they're just kind of expected at this point. I didn't mind backtracking in this game as much as games like Pirate's Curse or Risky's Revenge, though, where you have to go back through entire dungeons to find stuff you might have missed. I also really don't like the TOTALLY CAPS YELLOW TEXT that appears in a lot of dialogue. I just feel it shows up way too often, but it's really not a dealbreaker to a lot of people.Overall, I think I would still consider Pirate's Curse to be the better game. I think its puzzles, bosses, and levels were more fun, and it had a really good story as well as some interesting bombshells, whereas Half-Genie Hero's story falls a little flat as far as these games go. That said, Half-Genie Hero is no slouch, and has been an overall great game that I had a really good time playing.Whether you're a fan of the series or just want to try it out, I recommend Shantae: Half-Genie Hero as a very solid platformer with wonderful visuals and music, and I recommend checking out the other games in the series if you can!

Recommended to all my friends.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												I'm not normally one to write reviews, but I really want to write my thoughts on the game somewhere. It's like 4AM though, so I'm not sure how coherent this is going to be, but uh, here we go.First of all, I love the direction that they've taken the art style. The visuals are absolutely gorgeous. The hand-drawn characters over the 3D backgrounds look very nice. Speaking of the characters, I feel that the more chibi-style is really cute. All in all, it's just a great game to look at.The soundtrack is fantastic as usual. A couple of tracks really reminded me of Mighty Switch Force!, which y'know, makes sense considering Jake Kaufman composed the soundtrack to that too. I don't think he's ever produced a track I haven't liked.Now in comparison to the previous titles in the series, I do feel like Half-Genie Hero takes a couple of steps back in places, particularly the level design. I wouldn't really call the game a Metroidvania. The more exploration-based dungeons are gone and have been replaced with much more linear levels divided up into a few sections each followed by a boss. If I had to draw a comparison to something similar, it'd probably be Mega Man. (This certainly doesn't mean I think Mega Man has bad level design or that I think the level design in this game is bad. Really, it's just different.) The scale of the worlds also feels a lot smaller, especially in comparison to Pirate's Curse. I was a little surprised at how short they all felt, even on my first playthrough. I also feel like the game doesn't utilize all of the transformations enough. There are a couple that are really only used once and then never again. There are also a few that don't even really need to be used at all. Most of those are optional though, so it's not a huge deal.I've got a few small issues with the story, too. I'm sure others have said this before, but the game is sort of a soft reboot. There were some character development moments in Pirate's Curse that I was interested to see possibly get expanded upon, but the game kinda just ignores them. It's not really that big of a deal, though. It was just something I was kinda hoping to see. Something that does bother me though, is how disjointed the story feels at times. The events of the game never really feel all that connected and are more like random tasks that are just there to move the plot along. It doesn't really feel all that much like an adventure. The dialogue is great, though. I did enjoy the references to previous games and I laughed at most of the jokes.I know it probably sounds like I'm being too critical, but I really enjoyed the game. It just feels a little weaker compared to the rest of the series, in my opinion. On its own, it's a really great game and a hell of a lot of fun. If you've never played a Shantae game before and you're interested, this is a great place to start. I feel the game does a good enough job of introducing the characters and the world to newcomers. If you do pick it up and enjoy it, then I strongly recommend you check out the others as well. It's a great series and it's really a shame that it's still so relatively unknown.To sum everything up, I feel the game takes some steps forward in certain areas and some steps back in others, but it's still a great experience. Give it a try if you're interested!There's probably more I would like to say, but it's really late and I'm tired so I think I'm about done here.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
TLDR; if you like collecting stuff and revisiting levels to collect more stuff, you'll like this. Sort of like a Metroidvania with the level-to-level gameplay of Mega Man.Gameplay is fun. There's lots of items to collect if you want to get the 100% clear rating! Revisiting the stages with power-ups you've collected since is rewarding, occasionally expanding into areas you didn't expect. The upgrade shop is a nice idea, but could do with a bit more stuff in it. The difficulty curve starts a bit higher than average - it might be a bit difficult for a beginner player - but it peters out towards the end as it doesn't scale well to match all of the upgrades you've amassed. The bosses are okay, but some of them are quite boring, especially the two phases of the final boss. Controls are nice and responsive (as they should be!), but I'd recommend using a gamepad.The visuals are great! Shantae definitely benefits from not being on a tiny handheld screen! They've built upon the techniques they learnt while making Ducktales: Remastered - bright 3D environments with 2D animated characters. The characters are really well animated, and share a nice, consistent style.Music is on point as well! It's been done by the wonderful Jake Kaufman (who also appeared on previous WayForward titles). Definitely some very catchy songs in there, my favourite being the haunted castle stage.Luckily the story isn't the focus of the game, because it's an afterthought at best. I'm not familiar with the series, but it seems clear that they tried to squeeze every single earlier-established character into the game. They also introduce a new character... only to have that character be killed off five minutes later. Overall, it doesn't really make much sense.The writing is terrible - it definitely tries way too hard to be funny. It seems like it was written by a four-year-old; I remember one of the worst offenders being "hey, guess what? Monkey butts". Unfortunately, you need to read some of the text to know what to do next; if you don't want to read it, try skipping through the main text, then talk to the NPC characters afterwards to get them to repeat the important details.Overall, it's a good platforming experience! It suffers from being a bit short - it took me 7 hours to 100% it at a rather leisurely pace - but I'm aware that there's more content coming in the future.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
A worthy successor to the Shantae franchise Once again imbued with her magic powers, Shantae has access to a record-breaking twelve transformations. Each form bears a unique function that allows you to further unravel a level on subsequent playthroughs. There's plenty of fresh, risque content to pique your interest. Several new, cute enemies are bound to catch your eye. It's refreshing to see fantasy mainstays like ghosts and slimes portrayed as cute, sultry ladies. Newcomers and familiar faces both are given a fresh look as the entire game is now beautifully rendered and animated in cel-shaded art, an upgrade from those classic pixels. The storyline remains as lighthearted and humorous as ever. Progressing the story once again hinges upon catering to fetch quests and revisiting old levels with new powers. Levels are now incredibly linear, complete with a level select screen ala Megaman.  A tremendous amount of effort has been put into developing the bosses, these are by far the most developed in the series. Unfortunately I must temper my praise for this game by pointing out a few fundamental, glaring flaws. Several transformations and their upgrades go nearly or entirely unused. Most forms can't attack by default, and those that can be upgraded to strike are not viable compared to Shantae's regular form. This game should have focused on four main transformations, consolidating their abilities (Mermaid and crab have too much overlap) and giving them decent attacks. Majora's Mask did it better. In Pirate's Curse you had access to every upgrade at the press of a single button. The final gauntlet was complex, requiring all of your abilities in conjunction with one another. In here you have sections of gameplay sharply divided between each transformation with no interplay. I love going back to a level with new powers to find new items. Here I ended up repeating the same levels four or more times, well beyond being able to enjoy my revisits. You can 100% the game in under 3 hours, but your first time without a guide may take you up to six. Since the levels are entirely linear, the game world feels less interconnected and more sterile. Unlocking new transformations no longer fills me with any sense of wonder partially since there are so many and also since they're not punctuated by deeply buried, ancient shrines. There are no dungeons, and the penultimate level is painfully brief. Amazing art direction coupled with Jake Kaufman's musical prowess make for a winning combination. Half Genie Hero is another wonderful installment, but doesn't hit the same high notes as Pirate's Curse.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2016
												After 3 years in development, the fourth installment of the Shantae franchise has finally been released. Is Half-Genie Hero worth the weight? Well, let's find out.Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is the fourth game in the sassy and charming Shantae series and now in high-definition. The visuals in this game are fantastic to say the least. The game mixes colorful and nicely textured 3D assets with high-quality 2D sprites. The animations on characters are also excellent and gives the game some life. Game also ran very well at least for me it did. No crashes either.Unlike Pirate's Curse, Half-Genie Hero brings back the transformations from the first two games; however, they made some more changes to the system in this one. The way transformations work now is that you go into dance mode and the game goes through a menu of transformations automatically and you use the d-pad (if you played it on a controller which I did) to select your transformation. Additionally, there is now a grand-total of 14 transformations (2 of them can be swapped) with some being more useful than others. The transformations are fun to use but they are not as good as the Pirate Gear from the previous game due to having to pause and wait to select the transformation you want to use which can ruin the flow of the gameplay. There is an upgrade that increases Shantae's dancing animation speed which helps somewhat.Now for the most important part, the gameplay. Is it any good? Absolutely. It controls nearly as well as Pirate's Curse and using the transformations is still fun despite not flowing as well as the Pirate Gear. The game is more linear than its predecessors but the metroidvania elements are still there as you will be doing a lot of backtracking in earlier levels to go into areas you wouldn't have access to before. The levels are fun to explore but the lack of dungeons is really disappointing. The Shantae games always had really fun dungeons to explore and the lack of them in this game is a crime. I don't know why they removed them but hopefully they will bring them back in the next game. Also, there is no map in this game which is odd considering that Risky's Revenge and Pirate's Curse had maps. The game seems to be quite shorter than the other entries but there will be new character modes that will be coming up later on which should increase the length of the game.The music is composed by Jake Kaufman once again and I must say, some of the tracks in this game are the best in the whole series. The soundtrack of this game consists of high-quality remixes of songs from previous games and new tracks. There is one track from the previous games that gets reused but is only used for one section. Overall, the soundtrack does not disappoint and Jake Kaufman has done an amazing job once again.Now for the story, I know the story isn't really the main focus in these games but Pirate's Curse did a pretty good job on that aspect and this game seems to ignore some of the character development from that game. Risky just goes back to her "LOL IM EVIL" self without any explaination and a few characters from the last two games don't make an appearence in this game. Speaking of Risky, there is a lack of Risky in this game as she only appears in the beginning and the end of the game. The story feels pretty unfocused throughout the majority of the game as each level in the game feels more like an episode of "Shantae beats the bad guy from doing bad things". The rival Half-Genie that appears early on in the game would have made for an interesting story but they just conclude her story shortly afterwards. Despite the story being unfocused, the dialogue is still very funny and charming.Overall, Half-Genie Hero is a very polished and well made game that will not disappoint any fan in the series. It may not be as good as Pirate's Curse but it's still a great entry to the franchise. Due to its pretty short length, I would recommend to pick this one up on a sale and/or when the new character modes come out.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2016
												Disclaimer: I backed the kickstarter (sort of). To be more accurate, I gave a paypal donation that counted towards backing the game well after the campaign had been successfully funded. I'd just finished Pirate's Curse and was excited to see how they'd treat the franchise going forward. Well, you see that red thumb in the corner so I've got some explaining to do.Let's start things off by saying that my actual feelings towards this game lie somewhere in the middle, however, steam only has a binary "good or bad" system for rating games. Given what I have to say though, I'm sad to say I'm going to have to give this a thumbs down. The game leaves a great first impression but the deeper you get in the more you can see the cracks in its structure.Let's start off with the positives. The music is fantastic, Jake Kaufman continues to be one of my favorite game music composers and I'm delighted to enjoy the soundtrack to most games he's worked on. The upgrade from pixel art to drawn sprites is absolutely wonderful. The future looks great assuming they stick with this art style, the game looks fantastic. The controls are nice and responsive and the basic gameplay has a good feel to it. While my issues with the genie transformations, that have followed me as I've played through all four games in the series, aren't entirely solved in this game they're much quicker to access, especially with the metronome, which I consider a must have item. There's a couple fun ideas for settings and it's neat to see how the tech of this world is advancing in each installment.Unfortunately, good music and visuals do not alone for a good game make, now we're in the negatives. The game only has a small handful of levels that feel shorter and shorter the more you have to scour over every inch of them to find more collectables to progress the story. That's the biggest problem with the game, it's spread incredibly thin over a very small and tightly packed space. I loved my first run through each level, the first time through mermaid falls is my personal highlight of this game. The second run through, it was neat to see how little elements had changed. However, by the time I'd finally gotten everything there was to pick up I was pretty much sick of every area. Well, aside from the first and the fifth one which are both, comparatively, tiny levels with little to do.The linear "level" structure really went against what I've become familiar with in this series. While the map design is nowhere near as bad as Risky's Revenge, (Which, as it stands, is my least favorite entry in this franchise by a wide margin.) it's definitely a huge step back from Pirate's Curse. They went from open maps to screen to screen "levels" packed with things you are required to get but can't until you get more transformations. Aside from that, the biggest problem with them is how they're checkpointed, which is really only an issue because of any of the instant death traps that are in the later environments. The game isn't really all that hard but instant death spikes/lasers isn't how you remedy that. (Side Note: Games don't have to be "hard" to be good.) At best, it's a nuisance, but at worst it's a complete waste of time. Some genie transformations are usefully only for one or two manditory uses to collect an item but outside of that are completely pointless when put up against the other transformations you get (spider). Any points I can get into beyond this get more into the territory of nitpicking so I'll spare you that.If I were to give you a recommendation it'd be for what is, in my opinion, the best of this series and perhaps the only 5/5 worthy one on the list. I'd highly encourage you to check out Shantae and the Pirate's Curse. It goes above and beyond all 3 of the games it sits alongside. Funnily enough, it's the only game where Shantae doesn't have her genie powers (animal transformations) and I think it plays like a dream because using your abilities flows better with the controls. There's no stopping to turn into a less powerful, less interesting form. Instead you flow smoothly through actions. Be careful though since there might, unfortunately, be some odd issues with the PC port of Pirate's curse based on my browse of the community page.  If Wayforward could "remaster" Pirates Curse with these visuals it'd be a dream come true. Edit: 12/30/2016 This review was made with the base version of the game in mind. In the event that any of the added characters/campaigns be paid DLC I feel my review will not need to be adjusted to reflect content sold separately of the original product. There's no guarantee that I'll think to return to the game by the time additional content is added. Any willing to "take up the mantle" are free to do so in my absence.Author's note: If you enjoy the game, great, more power to you. I'm honestly happy that you have a thing to be happy with. You don't have to agree with me, in fact, I don't expect you to. I just felt compelled to put this together by the time I'd finished with the game. I don't often share my opinions in writing like this but I felt like I had a case to make even though it was going against the tide. Hope your day treats you well.

Product received for free
												Okay... I have no idea where to start. Shantae and The Pirate's Curse amazed me. Half Genie Hero astonished me. I have literally tried for hours to find the right things to say and give this game a proper review, but I'm at a loss. There are just too many good things and not enough bad things to say about it. Nonetheless, here are my personal pros and cons...Pros: AMAZING GAMEAdorable charactersWonderful visuals and animationJAKE KAUFMAN'S MUSICExtremely fun gameplayShantae's voiceDecent game lengthGiga Mermaid was such an awesome boss fight!ShantaeCons:I sometimes felt that having to transform so frequently stalled gameplay.Not enough spoken dialogue for our favorite lil genie girl.Some of the fan art was... weird :PI was initially disappointed at how Shantae goes off-center of the screen when running through Scuttle Town. I wasmuch relieved to see this wouldn't be the case throughout the remainder of the game.Last but not least... I really don't like how the background of the stages adopt a blue fog after you've completed it. It especially hurts the Mermaid Falls' appearance... there goes my prerry sky and clouds.. :(I feel really awful that I wasn't aware of the kickstarter campaign. I had no internet at the time, but I would have gladly pitched $100 to this game. I also feel awful that it was gifted to me... and my friend got it on sale. I would have wanted WayForward to get the extra $2. Every little bit counts, and it certainly shows in this game. I love Shantae and I love WayForward for making this amazing title happen. An amazing series with an amazing character, Shantae Half Genie Hero is a continuation of some of the best games I have played since the rest of the gaming industry went nuts on us.9/10

content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
												Full disclosure: I am a Kickstarter backer of this game.The Shantae series has been a consistent provider of well-crafted platform adventures since the original was released on the Game Boy Color, with each game adding new refinements to a proven formula. This latest release continues the trend with updated abilities and a combination of hand-drawn and 3D graphics.As mentioned, this game doesn't deviate much from previous Shantae games - though this isn't a bad thing. Bad guys are up to bad things in Sequin Land, and it's Shantae's job to collect what she needs to stop them. Fans of the series will be on familiar territory, and metroidvania fans will find a lot to like. The characters are endearing and memorable, and the plot would fit nicely in a well-written Saturday morning cartoon.Of course, an important element in any game of this type is the quality of the puzzles and secrets. This game has well-crafted ones just difficult enough to make you want to finish them, without being overly frustrating. I was able to clear 96% of the game without a guide, and the items I had to really work for can be passed over if you just want to play through without finding every little secret. The boss fights are mostly of the "action puzzle" variety as well. At times, the method for beating them wasn't immediately clear, but it didn't require much work to figure it out, and the fights themselves were still challenging.As for the shift in art style, I am in favor of it. As much as I appreciate well-done sprite graphics (and I do), the hand-drawn characters really suit this series, and it goes well with the cartoony atmosphere. Speaking of, I enjoyed the dialogue as well, with well-written humor that managed to be sharp without resorting to being too crude.All in all, I think adventure fans will enjoy this game if they've never tried the series before, and returning Shantae fans will be well satisfied. Shantae is securing her position among gaming greats.

number of helpful: 17 of 17 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 1
												It's a Shantae game, in both the good ways and the bad ways.The good ways are that Shantae looks and sounds better than ever, and that the characteristic good writing is present, along with all the characters you know and love(or love to hate).The bad ways are in the sense that every Shantae game is, to some extent, experimental. Some aspects and mechanics recur, but every single game is made up of those "classic" elements mixed evenly with the developers tossing new ideas up into the air and seeing what sticks. But it feels like they rarely test these things(except to avoid bugs), as long as nothing's outright breaking the game, it stays in, and the final test of whether it's actually fun or functional, is left for the game's buyers to figure out.For instance, we've got the shapeshifting from Risky's Revenge back again, this time with even more forms. But there are a couple of forms that you'll never actually use(outside of their mandated one or two applications for gaining bonus items or quest items), because their uses are either extremely niche(elephant, spider and mouse, looking at you) or heavily overlapped with another form. Some also feel like they weren't tested much, since the Bat allows you to trivialize large parts of some areas(sky bridge in the desert, hello to just flying past all those platforms).Boss fights also still feel spastic rather than tactical. I'm sure I'm going to get the usual "git gud" comments for this, but in some platformers, I can go into a boss fight, and after screwing up one or two waves, I can go: "Oh, okay, this is what they want me to do." And then sure, I may lack the brains or dexterity to actually do it, but I can always see the IDEA. In HGH, there are some attacks where I just can't see HOW to dodge them, some bosses where I just can't figure out their mechanics(what actually triggers the Tinkerbrain popping up its canisters?) and the game also suffers a bit from some things that look good being a bit counterproductive.In the case of boss fights, circular boss arenas are VERY neat, since they basically give you "infinite" horizontal space without any screen scroll, but it makes it hell to judge the distances of something rolling towards you, and when there's a LOT of stuff in the middle of the circle, like in the final battle, it can be hard to see projectiles spawned on the other side of the circle before they're all the way past the clutter and way in  your face.In general, the improved graphics also feel like they make things a bit more vague. It's less "sharp" where spikes end and where they begin, or what parts of a heavily animated flame projectile actually burns you. I mean, it looks GREAT, not denying that, but it feels like if you're gonna do that in a platformer, you should be a bit more forgiving about hit areas. It also feels like there's no "good" difficulty in the game. Like, again, I enjoyed it, but I never really felt challenged except by instakill spikes in a couple of areas, and that's not the sort of challenge that appeals to me(seriously, WayForward, the final dungeon of Pirate's Curse was a mistake. PLEASE don't try to recapture any of that. Ever.). But unless you intentionally avoided upgrades and heart holders, it just feels like you can brute force your way through most areas, chugging a few consumables when necessary, and the same for the boss fights. On the one hand, a bit more challenge would make it feel a bit more satisfying when beating an area, but on the other hand, I appreciate that if I really get stuck on doing something "right" I can just power through it with potions.I'm also not sure how I feel about the new approach to travelling, with the world map and warp dances. It makes everything feel easier, backtracking is considerably less of a pain, but it also makes Sequin Land feel less like a world, and more like a series of levels. But that's probably a personal thing.Finally, there are a few technical issues, mostly related to some animations "chopping" a bit, sometimes characters flicker partway through animations, etc. but it's pretty rare. It's almost completely isolated to the world map screen where Sky, Wrench and Shantae sometimes behave a bit oddly.So ultimately, the verdict is: It needs polish, and in some cases issues that have been showing up in Shantae games since Risky's Revenge need to be recognized as issues and addressed, but it's got so much heart that I can't pretend I don't love it. This was money well-spent for me, and it will be for anyone else who likes the Shantae games. Because like me, I bet you've spent half an hour listing all the things that could be fixed about Risky's Revenge and Pirate's Curse, but then you finish by going: "I loved the game anyway. How did they manage to make a zombie so cute?"You know, unless you have no taste and don't agree that Rottytops is best girl.

												I AM A BACKER OF HALF GENIE HERO'S KICKSTARTER AND I HAVE PLAYED MORE HOURS THAN LISTED ON STEAM.The 4th game in the Shantae Series, and it continues to be an incredibly funny, and fun Platformer.For Shantae Fans, Half-Genie Hero is more Shantae Goodness to enjoy, and it's the easiest entry in the franchise.For New Comers to Shantae: Gameplay-wise: Half-Genie Hero is a fun platformer with great controls and dance abilities to traverse and explore each level in it's entirety. With new dances/abilities you can explore and discover secrets as well as new methods to blast through each level. It is not as complicated and vast as previous entries. There's no chance of getting lost as there are plenty of hints in the game to tell you where to go. The challenge only comes in from getting 100% Collectibles.Story-wise, It's best to play previous entries before Half Genie Hero, as the story HEAVILY references events from (2nd) Risky's Revenge and (3rd) Pirate's Curse, with previous villains return to fight Shantae. Anything beyond treads Spoiler TerritoryThe only Technical issue I experienced was the frustration from restarting the game in order to change the resolution or switching from Windowed or Fullscreen.Other than that, the tranistion to HD was well done.One of the most Successfully funded Crowdfunded Games ever made. And There is promised additions and characters to the game incoming in 2017.Half Genie Hero is a Highly Recommended Platformer. Shantae is Cute, funny and too pure for this world.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												Everybody's favorite Half-Genie Hero is back and Ret-2-Go! She's dancing her way through the danger with a variety of forms, spells, and items--but does it hold up compared to the former entries?Mostly, yes. Let's start off with some pros.PROS: *The new art design is absolutely gorgeous, with painstaking attention paid to both the animation fidelity and character design. Sequin Land and its people have never looked so good. *Core gameplay is still superb: jump, whip your hair back and forth, and dodge what you can as you make your way through levels and discover hidden secrets with the help of any shapeshifting forms you happen to pick up along the way (and after). If you've played a Shantae game before? You'll feel right at home.*As always, the soundtrack is a joy to listen to. Nothing more to say on that--the music is great!*If you're a fan of the usual dialogue found in a Shantae game--wacky, weird, and sometimes a little 4th Wall-Breaking with a veritable drenching of saccharine Feel Good Vibes--then you're in for a treat. It's not gonna make you think on the existential crisis that plagues us all, but hey, it'll warm your heart and probably get you to crack a smile. Just as good, right?But, no game is perfect. So let's look at some cons.CONS:*While the backtracking you'd come to expect from Shantae, or any Metroidvania for that matter, is still present? It feels cut down, streamlined, and less rewarding than before. While you'll amass over a dozen new forms that get your hips shaking, most of them are rarely used for more than bit puzzles--and then they're never really needed again. Mermaid, Monkey, and Harpy eventually become your main forms, and the rest are kind of left hanging.*While the dialogue remains as endearing as ever, the main storyline itself feels somewhat disconnected from the actual theme it's trying to convey. There are also elements that're introduced, but addressed in a manner that feels lacking--looking at you, Holly.*While the UI itself is very comfortable, the menu screen suffers from some clutter issues that were a minor irritation. Items you wouldn't think to use again--like the previous ranks of your damage upgrades--are kept in the inventory as toggles, so you can weaken yourself by choice. Still, that's a case of "Your Mileage May Vary." I could see somebody using those toggles as self-inflicted "hard mode" conditions.*It's not long. I clocked in at around seven hours to complete the main campaign, though there's the additional Hero mode to tackle for fun--you get to start a new game with all of your main forms.Shante: Half-Genie Hero isn't -better- than the previous games, but despite some minor gripes and irritations, I find it still holds up rather well to former iterations of the series. There's also the point that DLC will be introduced at a later date which may shake up some of my points. If it does? I'll revise my review to accommodate.Still, if you're looking for a simple "buy it or not" deal? Go ahead and buy it. It's good, simple fun that's worth the price of admission.

												This game took me 6 hours to complete at 100%. I'm a tad disappointed but I had a lot of fun. It's not as thorough as the other games were when it came to level design. One entrance, one exit. Small puzzle rooms inbetween and one main gimmick. I miss the Zelda like dungeons from the other games, but this Mega Man like approach isn't so bad. It's just a shame that it starts out with huge amounts of puzzles in the first 2 levels then the rest just peeter out. The last 2 levels have like no collectables in it whilst around 45% of the games collectables are found in the SECOND one. It's insane the weighting on content. Not too pleased at the concept of DLC being made during development that's free to backers. I'd have backed if I knew backing was even an option. Oh well hopefully it's not stupidly priced considering the game makes stabs at that concept. tl;dr: It's fun, but it won't last you long. The other games have more content but it's pretty and Jake Kaufman is still legendary.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
A solid step forward for Shantae Games ||  Spoiler FreeI LOVE the Shantae games, and after waiting a while for Half Genie Hero to come out (not a backer, wish I was, just love the series) I was very very excited going into it, and after finishing the game, I can say that it is my personal favorite Shantae game in the series, and would recommend this to anyone who enjoys a good platformer with solid graphics and excellent music.Half Genie Hero is a lovely HD entry in the Shantae series, and the music and graphics is a nice step forward for the series, as it breaths new life into the franchise and makes everything look, feel and sound better. One thing it does differently compared to Risky's Revenge and Pirate's Curse is change up the level.Where Pirate's Curse changed Risky's Revenge's world layout from a single world to a hub system, Half Genie Hero took the hub world and made it level based. There is backtracking in this game, but once you have completed the level through once, you can use a special dance to warp from one part of the level to another. There are typically three parts to a level, but [side note] if you warp from the first part of a level to the second part, you cannot go back. This can be a little annoying, but it isn't too bad so long as you remember why you came to a level. The level design also makes it a bit easier to track item collecting throughout the game, as you can see which items you have / haven't collected in the level select area, and compared to last game, this made it enjoyable to collect everything in the game.One thing that I VERY much enjoyed was the unlockable concept art. This is something that I found to be very rewarding, as I am one who likes those unlockables, especially when the game makes it doable and entertaining to unlock (and is a pretty enjoyable game). There are seven concept art galleries and three fan art galleries, but that's as far as I'll talk on that.The bosses throughout the game are pretty fun and interesting, and they all added a little bit of personallity into the game. The enemies were okay (or as okay as enemies get); they look beautiful thanks to the HD graphics and, like the bosses, add personality to the levels they inhabit. "Will this take long to complete?" No. It took me around nine-ish hours, give or take. I was able to get about 93% of the achievements in the process, but I definitely see myself going back for the Hero Mode and perhaps another general playthrough.Overall, I really enjoyed this game. Is it different than Pirate's Curse? Yeah. Do I like the changes made? Yes. So take my opinion and review as you will, but I do recommend this to anyone who enjoys a good platformer with solid graphics and excellent music, as I enjoyed every minute playing it and am excited to see where this franchise will go next.

content:
Posted: January 11
My first jump into Shantae: Half-Genie HeroThis felt magical again! Like "Risky Boots Revenge" - the first Shantae game I played. Transformations are back, the graphics feel more HD (the previous games were made for the Nintendo DS and thus had a way smaller resolution), and familiar faces in every direction.Stages are set up "Select Screen" style again. I preferred the way they did it in Risky Boots Revenge - the world map I mean - and thought it was a downgrade to the game world as a whole when it went from that to a simple stage select in The Pirate's Curse - which they kept for this. It's not the worst thing in the world though.The puzzles weren't hard until the final level. Most of the stages weren't set up with puzzles.  There were some here and there (avoiding laser beams, climbing a maze before time is up, the entire final level) but most levels were based around exploration or simple advancement from point A to B through a horde of enemies.A lot of the transformations completely outclassed other transformations. I enjoyed using them anyway - and I felt a bit more lenient about there being forms that were less useful when I found out some of them were just tossed in as extra rewards for the players to enjoy.While the graphics themselves were enhanced the animations for the characters seemed a little less amped than the previous games in the series. I mean I still enjoyed them and they still came to a point I feel keeps WayForward of the "We care about the animation quality" mentality, but they were clearly a little less ambitious than previous games on that specific detail. There's only one dance animation for example when everybody was amazed at her dancing in Risky Boots' Revenge. I can totally understand why though: they added several times more transformations so waiting for a cycle of 20 dances to roll through would have been unintuitive and probably aggravating after a bit.Pet PeevesThere weren't many levels. At the end I felt like the game could have gone on another few hours. The game length on my first play through - which included a lot of fooling around, some gem grinding, and a decent amount of backtracking for 100% completion - was roughly about 10-11 hours. So the game holds up in length, but the stages don't feel numerous - especially after finding out two of the levels were added as Kickstarter rewards.The final stage was another spikes-and-pitfall level that made the game hard for the wrong reason. To be fair sometimes the only reason the challenging parts are challenging is because they can be cheap, but in Shantae's series it's always shooting itself in its own foot since it throws away the point of spending extra hours finding more health. I'd have preferred more numerous enemies and stronger enemies over spikes and pitfalls again; something to give the health bar some stress in combat.Holly, a character that seemed centered on an  interesting rival-genie arc, is resolved very quickly. She has a decent buildup to what ultimately just concludes and disappears into thin air all of a sudden. I think she would have offered something new to the universe as an rival character even if only for one game before the rivalry were concluded, but it ended so fast it could easily have been skipped entirely. ConclusionI played with the transformations like toys. I love the transformations. I did what I could to try and beat every stage I reasonably could as each transformation (which I'm still in the middle of doing). Ultimately I feel the transformations are what make a Shantae game a Shantae game. I feel like the game lost something about it that was there in the earlier games but I can't put my finger on it. It also added more "something else". It still feels like a Shantae game. Just somehow with a little more and a little less "something". I really could have seen it being longer but despite  feeling as though I blazed through it they did pack content into this game. I think it feels slightly unfinished because a lot of this content can't be used effectively.

number of helpful: 12 of 15 people (80%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
												Shantae: 1/2 Genie Hero is exactly what it was initially intended to be: a shined and polished Shantae title that offers a fourth helping of exactly what made the previous titles so well-loved. While it still has a lot of growing to do to live up to everything WayForward has promised (in the form of DLC and other bonuses), the core game is ret-2-go, and for the most part, it's pretty wonderful.As with previous installments, Shantae: 1/2 Genie Hero follows a policy of "if it ain't broke, don't fix it," retaining the same core gameplay mechanics it's always had while further refining the way extras like items and transformations work.As always, Shantae runs, jumps, and attacks enemies with her hair, exploring (and occasionally backtracking through) five main worlds, each chock full of secrets and surprises, and as with the first two titles, earns (or discovers) new transformations that enable her to navigate her world in different ways.While the immediate predecessor (The Pirate's Curse) temporarily did away with transformations in favor of new abilities that blended seamlessly with Shantae's standard controls, reverting to the transformation mechanic is handled tastefully. Shantae can now choose from a palette of up to 12 "dances," which are accessed via a single button press and subsequent single directional command, enabling Shantae to transform in and out of forms hastily to suit the occasion. Many of these dances are optional, hidden, or available for purchase, and a few are actually mutually exclusive- players must decide if they'd rather hold onto, say, a convenient teleportation dance, or a form that spits out free money. Players are free to change their mind on these choices, but only via trade with the merchant who sells said optional dances.While a few of these forms are combat-capable (or can be made so via hidden upgrades), few if any are ever more viable for combat than Shantae's base form. Though Shantae can no longer pick up hand-to-hand secret techniques or upgrade her arsenal with pirate weaponry, her trusty battle-ponytail can be upgraded as in previous titles do deal quite a bit of damage. If this seems duller than integrating projectiles and blades into your fighting style, fear not. Series mainstay items like the Pike Ball and Storm Puff have been given a very welcome upgrade- rather than consumables to be purchased and used at the player's discretion, these magic items now manifest as permanent upgradeable skills in Shantae's arsenal, swapped out as sub-weapons and usable for as long as Shantae has the magic power to deploy them (think Mega Man). Thus, players can now hurl flames and thunderbolts at will, or protect themselves with barriers and damaging satellites. While not quite as seamless as the previous title's pirate powers, this is a fun system that puts the series' classic quirky weapons on full glorious display. This is largely a welcome change, but I couldn't help but notice that sometimes the extra powers made things *too* easy. The fully upgraded bubble shield, for example, makes Shantae completely invincible for as long as she has magic remaining. This synergizes very well with items that expand Shantae's mana pool, to the point that by the game's final challenge, I found I was able to remain invincible indefinitely. I'm not sure if this was an oversight or simply poor judgment, but I hope to see it fixed in the near future- I'm not opposed to letting players enjoy some casual godmoding, but I feel like offering it to players just before the last boss is in poor taste.Indeed, the difficulty of the game is perhaps its weakest attribute. While the game has a few sections that new players are very likely to need to repeat again and again (an aspect soothed tremendously by the introduction of frequent autosaves), I often found myself sufficiently geared and upgraded to pass most challenges on my first try, not from skill, but from simply having so many health items and defensive upgrades at my disposal. The game does offer players the choice to turn off any specific upgrade at will (which is, honestly, a fantastic option to provide), but offers no real incentive to do so- after facing the odd gauntlet of instant death two or three times, I falsely presumed the rest of the game would match that challenge and prepared accordingly, only to watch the rest of the game crumble before my seemingly-bottomles well of force fields and monster steaks, and before I knew it, it was over.After three years in development, I'm a little surprised. True, the worlds are enormous and the powers vast, but five main worlds? Just five? I confess I'm a bit disappointed by the shortness. I completed this game with 100% progress in exactly the same amount of time as I took to complete the previous title. DLC promises new levels and modes, such as the ability to play as the other main characters in their own separate stories, and as much as I did truly and consistently enjoy my first playthrough as Shantae, I do welcome the chance to do it all again differently. Still, until those new modes arrive, I must say, the game feels a little scant for all the work that's clearly gone into it.And to speak of that work- my goodness is this game ever gorgeous. The characters are presented as hand-drawn faithful recreations of their old sprites, and if one recalls just how fluidly-animated those sprites were, one can correctly assume the degree to which this title absolutely gushes charm. The visual style of lively 2D characters against lovingly-rendered 3D backdrops works marvelously here, and unlike other 2.5D titles there's no question of where obstacles begin and end.  Shantae: Half Genie Hero is without a doubt the tightest 2.5D game I've yet experienced.As for the story, it's a bit less compelling than its immediate predecessor, but every bit as hilarious. Shantae has really found its essence in humor and awkard charm- I caught myself laughing out loud once or twice, and my heart lept to see certain characters reappear. Still, while I was never bored by the dialogue or story, I don't feel that this game has yet managed to outdo itself in terms of weaving a truly epic narrative. Pirate's Curse opened the characters up to a measure of depth not previously seen- we saw a powerless Shantae, a vulnerable Risky, a lost Rottytops, a successful Bolo and a terminally misfortunate Sky. None of this is present in Shantae's latest adventure, and while it does tell a pleasantly lighthearted story, we've seen WayForward do better.After so much time in development, Shantae: 1/2 Genie Hero feels solid, if surprisingly sparse, and is over long before it has a chance to wear out its welcome. With the promise of expansive DLC on the horizon, I feel hopeful that WayForward will gradually flesh this game out into the epic adventure we imagined it becoming. Perhaps future stories will introduce us to new sides of beloved characters, offer us the chance to approach the world from a new perspective, or simply expand upon an already successful formula. For now, though, it's another short yet fantastic romp through Sequin Land, and well worth the price of admission.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
												Elephant Dance? Check. GAME. OF. THE. YEAR.Half-Genie Hero feels and plays like an HD 2.5D Shantae should. The animation and music are, as usual, incredible. The dialogue is hilarious and it's great to see all the old favorite characters return. This entry has more in common with Risky's Revenge than Pirate's Curse, as you'll be dancing to take animal form, INCLUDING THE TRIUMPHANT RETURN OF THE ELEPHANT! It feels rock-solid right from the start and you'll be hair-whipping mermaids in no time.Two very minor, very patchable gripes though: my natural instinct is to use Escape to get out of/go back in menus, and that doesn't work here. Two, monkey controls for climbing might take you a bit of getting used to, as they're not what you'd think they'd be (pressing toward the wall does nothing, pressing away from the wall holds you still, can't remember if it felt this sticky in Risky's Revenge).Overall though, I am loving the game and am very happy with how it turned out! Worth picking up if you enjoyed the previous games or are in the market for a fun, colorful, and actually fairly challenging Metroidvania platformer!

content:
Posted: January 7
												A great addition to the Shantae line of games that have become big favorites of mine. To start off, 2D animation amongst 3D shaded backgrounds looks sharp! I was a little surprised at first, because I had played Shantae so much in it's pixel art form, but this new style WayForward has adopted for the series is fantastic and I got used to it fairly quickly. That also including the control scheme which is very snappy and responsive! Shantae has become a living realtime cartoon and it is a major factor that I'm so glad the series now has.Major and minor characters are back including Bolo, Uncle Mimic and Rottytops and they all have great dialogue and look great in the new style. The character interactions and text are all very funny, even including some fun unexpected moments where the characters will speak automatically, used a bit more here than in Pirate's Curse. I also really like how townsfolk give you hints and small clues, which comes in handy for dummies like me in those moments where I'm stupid and can't put 2 and 2 together.Music is great as always, Jake Kaufman bringin' it down with more sick remixes of Scuttle town and Burning Town. The new song sung by Shantae (Cristina Vee) is awesome when you first hear it on Main Street. Absolutely a major factor that makes the game stand out and goes along great with it. Though I will say I take more of a liking to Pirate Curse's tracks, these orchestral songs are great and are very dance worthy.The transformations are back from Shantae's earlier games, being staple powerups. They are used awesomely in this game! Very quick to transform and each stage uses different transformations for key areas to find secrets and other essestial items for achievement hunters and casuals alike. For Pirate's Curse of course, I did like how snappy and fast it was to use the pirate items for the corresponding buttons, but each key feature of the chosen transformation helps out greatly in areas, not just to get around the level, but also to find secrets. And hey, it's all worth it just to see Shantae dance again!Oh man, the bosses are pretty good too this time around. They all have some cool attack patterns and look great all while the kickin' battle them is blasting from your headphones. They're all varied and some do bring out great fun. Whoever thought up that rad giant mermaid needs a big ol' smooch.If I had to bring up any cons at all or stuff that just irked me personally, there's nothing that kept me from enjoying the game majorly. But the story is a biiiiit more straight forward this time around, and each world is sort of broken down into tiny subplots that don't really show up again, such as with Holly Lingerbean, the new kid on the block who's sort of just kicked out in a few minutes. But the small stories are essential for getting items back into the main plot.Some characters also felt kinda weird in this game, there's not a lot of ongoing character development carried on from past games. Risky in Pirate's Curse was Shantae's arch nemesis doin evil stuff as always,  but when the pair had to work together, she became a sort of hothead with a short temper while she worked with the good guys compared to Shantae's upbeat goofiness. She also came with a backstory where she used to have a powerful master. Here's she's just kind of the generic main baddie. Don't get me wrong, I know they kinda want the games to be accessible in any order, but for me it was just kind of a shame to see characters who have been sorta fleshed out in other games back to their plain old selves. Though it was kinda just a thing for me with Risky upfront.Something I noticed was that some aspects can make the game feel too easy, flight abilities can have you skip entire sections of levels, you can rack up gems like nobody's business though who's ever complained about free coinage?? And with enough gems, armor and hearts, getting hit every once in a while is really no problem.But hey, I love Shantae, and overall, this is a dang fun Shantae game with lots of great powerups, funny writing, a sweet new artstyle once again and a great soundtrack. It's just that compared to Pirate's Curse, it felt a bit more compact. While I would rate that game my favorite in the series, trust me, Shantae Half-Genie Hero is definetely my second. A great effort to everyone at WayForward and another definite step in the right direction. Can't wait to see that future character DLC!

content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
Product received for free
												(Note: Shantae Half-Genie Hero was a Kickstarter-funded game, and this reviewer backed it at the $12 level.)Shantae Half-Genie Hero is an exploratory platformer made by developer Wayforward Technologies, and it's absolutely fantastic. As the titular half-genie, Shantae, you run all around the world of Sequin Land, alternating between finding machine parts for your uncle and solving various crises that might pop up. Instead of an interconnected sidescrolling world map with towns and dungeons like previous games in the series, Half-Genie Hero opts to give you a handful of large stages, each divided into sub-areas and each filled with hidden permanent upgrades and/or new mobility options. On your first visits to these stages, you'll only be able to grab a few items. As you unlock new powers, however, you gain the ability to explore new parts of the levels and gain even more abilities and powerups to help you through the game.Shantae's main attack is whipping her hair, but you also have the ability to transform into different animals. These vary in usage, and they'll be often used to get to the aforementioned new areas. From a wall-climbing monkey to a sea-swimming mermaid to a high-flying harpy, the powers are welcome and interesting to use... although some are situational. You can also purchase magic spells for more offensive/defensive capability, and these are helpful items to grab as well. The game looks and sounds amazing, with HD art assets for all the characters and 3D rendered platforms to jump and climb over. Its soundtrack by Jake Kaufman is especially catchy, and you'll have the hooks of more than a few stage tracks in your head. Helpful, since you'll be revisiting them a lot.There are only one or two flaws with the game, and one is far less a transgression than the other. Some of the upgrades hardly change anything, and feel like filler. Attacks for forms you'll hardly use unless you're messing around, or powers used exactly once in a single area to gain another hidden item. In addition, things peak before the climax; the final two stages offer almost no hidden treasures to be found whatsoever. It's as if the game runs out of momentum before the end, and speaking of that we must discuss the penultimate boss. The fights before and after it are relatively engaging and straightforward, but in this middle fight you can only deal damage when the boss uses one of three attacks. The problem is that it spams the other two over and over again, turning what should be a three-minute fight into an agonizingly slow-paced slog where you're just waiting around, dodging the same two easily-dodged attacks over and over again and waiting for the game to decide to give you a chance to deal damage. It's unfortunate and really deflates the climax of an otherwise great game.At $16 USD you're looking at a five to six-hour experience, if you go for 100% item completion. That would be a bit short for the price, but there's an unlocked "Hero Mode" that lets you play the game over with most of your endgame transformations, and fly through it for kicks in half the time. Other playable modes are forthcoming, so I feel confident in saying the asking price is a worthy investment and giving this the thumbs-up. If you're a fan of the "retro" style of platformers, or love exploratory games like Demon's Crest or Odallus The Dark Call, this will absolutely be your jam.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
												Worth it. Sure it took 3 years for this kickstarter game to come out, but I can say I got my money's worth for backing this game...and the game only just has the FIRST of FIVE playable characters so far with the rest coming up soon!Wayforward's best traits are simple yet enteraining gameplay & amazing animation, and both are on full display in Shantae: Half-Genie Hero. They really took what they learned from Ducktales Remastered and refined it into some of the best use of 2D Sprite and Vector animation in a videogame to date. All the characters are drawn by hand this way, no cop-out use 3D-Model characters like in Rayman Legends and many other similar 2.5D games. 3D is only used for the colorful levels and backgrounds, but even you can hardly tell half the time by how well painted and textured they are that the characters feel right at home in the game.The game itself is probably the easiest to get into of the Shantae series; keeping the mainstay of the series' gameplay, but reducing the amount of backtracking of its metroidvania roots for a wider audience, though a little bit does remain, especially  when trying to get the optional upgrades and 100% completion. I would say that Pirate's Curse is a bigger and more epic adventure entry in the series then this game. However throughout the development of this game I felt like Wayforward were trying to make a more accessable game for the Shantae series, as the first three games are all tied together in their overarching story, making playing only one of the games a bit confusing if you didn't know the plot of the previous ones. Half Genie Hero is its own self contained story so there is no need to play the other games, which can be troublesome for many people as the first game for the Gameboy Advance is a bit arcadic; Risky's Revenge though still enjoyable is a tad flawed with bits of its gameplay, and Pirate's Curse relies on the player knowing the story up until that point in the series.Currently as of the day before release, none of the DLC has been implemented yet, but once everything is set in it should be avaliable. The only DLC that may take a while is the other playable characters as Wayforward plans to release them one at a time as the three stretchgoal characters Bolo, Sky, and Rottytops aren't quite ready if I remember one of their previous development logs. But the backer level DLC and Risky Boots character story should be coming in soon hopefully.That said, there are a couple minor shortcomings I am a bit disappointed about. Nothing that impacts my enjoyment of the game, but just a couple nitpicks I have:1) Once you beat the boss of some levels, if you return to a place you have beaten before, the background is fill with a glooming fog, obscuring the wonderful and charming backgrounds of the levels. It's a shame that such nice looking levels become muddied up by the choice to put up a fog in some of these levels once they are beaten.2) This one bugs be more then the other: Shantae only has one dancing animation for all her transformations and magic dances. Reguardless of which transformation you choose, she currently only has the hip-shaking dance and the finishing pose for all 14 of her dances. In previous games she had various dancing moves for each one; most notable was the first game where each dance was unique to the transformation or magic; then in Risky's Revenge she only had three dances, but each one was different for the animal she transformed into though the final pose was the same one for all three. FInally is Pirate's Curse, which granted do to plot didn't have transformation dances, but using the lamp item did give two different animations, one of which was a all new belly dancing animation. It wasn't necessary for the gameplay or plot, but it was a nice little touch to her character. However here in this game there are 14 dances, but they all use the same one.It could easily be fixed by tweaking the animations a bit. Here's how the dancing works to get an idea. You press the "Dance" button to bring up the dancing menu. Soft music and a steady beat starts playing and Shantae dances to it in rhythm. The menu shows the first 4 dance slots for 2 beats then for the next 2 beats it switches to the second set of 4 dances, then 2 beats for the third set, then it cycles back to the first four, making 12 slots for dances total. Risky's Revenge had a similar concept with the dances where holding down the dance button would cycle through the three dances in that game and releasing it activated the transformation she was performing. The issue of Shantae having only one dance and one finishing pose could be fixed of each of the 2 beats she did a different dance move for each set of dances, then finally once the dance is selected she does a finishing pose that represents the transformation she turns into.However, regardless of the minor shortcomings that may get fixed, Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is a success in my book. Sure this kickstarter isn't the groundbreaker or epic adventure Shovel Knight is; but it is FAR from the disaster Mighty No. 9 was. This game isn't meant to be grand, but rather a fun, charming adventure with likeable and often funnily-bizzard characters you know from Wayforward. So if you enjoyed Wayforward's previous games or want to start getting into their games; Half-Genie Hero is a full time winner, and will get even better as the stretchgoal content is released.

												I backed this game during the Kickstarter campaign both due to the fact that the Shantae series has had some excellent games, and WayForward have yet to disappoint with any game they've made. I received the code for it approximately a week ago and basically marathoned my through it.If you've played many platformers, or even more relevant, many metroidvania style platformers, you will find an enjoyable but somewhat short experience in Shantae: Half-Genie Hero. In about 10 hours in-game time I had completed everything the base game had to offer. This includes achieving 100% in the main story and in the New Game+ style mode known as Hero Mode. That being said, the experience was a thoroughly enjoyable one. There is DLC content on that way the will no doubt add several dozen more hours of play time to the game for me. I'm actually half-considering learning to speed run it, that's how much fun I've had with it.The sprite work in the game is phenomenal, animation that is both smooth as butter and full of personality. You can tell just from first the level alone that a lot of hard work and dedication went into producing this game. With all that said, I highly recommend the game to anyone who is a fan of the genre.

content:
Posted: January 9
												Shantae:  Half-Genie Hero is a competent platformer, but it gets too many things wrong for me to recommend it.  There are 6 stages in all, including the final stage which holds no secrets and another stage that holds only a couple that you'll visit maybe three times.  As you play, you accumulate more abilities and forms for Shantae which enable you to visit previously inaccessible areas and acquire more items and powerups.  But because the final stage has no secrets and another one has only a couple, you'll spend most of the game visiting the same 4 stages repeatedly.  To pad the length of the game and make up for a lack of content, you are occasionally given strange, lengthy fetch quests to complete to advance the story.I'll be blunt:  Half Genie Hero doesn't feel like a complete game.  It isn't just the lack of stages.  A few of the transformations--like bat and spider--have no real part to play in the game.  You use them a couple of times to collect optional items and nothing else.  Half Genie Hero was funded on Kickstarter and I suspect the developer may have hoped to be funded for more stages that would make use of things like the bat and spider transformations.  And unlike a traditional metroidvania game, there is really no variety or sequence breaking to be had.  You either have the right upgrade or you don't.  And since the game is so small, there really isn't any sense of progression.The game starts out at an average difficulty, but once you start buying some of the items in the shop and upgrading your life the difficulty soon vanishes.  You'll have so much health and take so little damage from attacks that you can literally just walk through normal enemies.  You can even buy an invincibility spell which further reduces the challenge.  There are a couple of places where the difficult absolutely skyrockets.  One is an area where you must climb quickly to avoid instant death, and another consists of a long path of one-hit kill spikes that you must fly through with extremely awkward controls.  It's like the developers struggled to balance the difficulty and then decided they needed some areas with serious challenge.I really like the style of the game and its characters, but the game just doesn't live up to its potential and I can't recommend it.  If you want a platformer, grab Shovel Knight or Freedom Planet instead.  If you'd like to play a game specifically like Castlevania, I'd recommend Valdis Story.  If you like games like the classic Metroid (or just good games in general) check out Axiom Verge.  If you're set on playing Shantae because it looks interesting, I'd recommend checking out the previous game in the series instead.

Through the Power of Kickstarter Shantae ReturnsIâm very glad i stumbled upon Shantae game series last year it was relatively unknown to me, but it looked very appealing and i decided to try out Pirateâs Curse and fell in love with the series and recently played Riskyâs Revenge before jumping into latest game the Half Genie Hero.The game feels like improved version on RR with more Transformations and bit more expanded item system that works the same way but offers more choices and upgrades. Half-Genie hero looks very beautiful the art style, effects and characters look very colorful and its really pinnacle of 2.5D art if you ask me. Posted: January 3
												It's no secret I love the Shantae series, and I've been waiting for this game to come out since I seen the kickstarter page. Now its out and it time to see if it was worth the wait. Story: Shantae Half-Genie Hero take place after the events of Shantae Pirate's Curse but if you haven't played it don't worry. The game stand on it own. Shantae is the guardian genie of the town and spend her days solving problems and stopping pirates. After a strange dream followed by a pirate attack, Shantae set off again to save her town.The story is straight forward. Not as much character development as previous games, but it felt like a good game for new players to jump onto the franchise.Gameplay: Shantae can jump and hair whip her opponents into submission. As a Genie she can dance and transform into various creatures to gain access to new areas. You can buy upgrades for Shantae hair whip at the item shop and also buy magic spells. The magic spells have always seem to break the game. If you're a completionist  than you're going to upgrade all your magic and with magic that can make you invulnerable, well let just say some bosses become a cake walk. But they give you option in the menu to disable any upgrade if you feel the game is too easy.Final Comment: Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is a good game for new players to start at, and veterans will be glad to see the return of loved characters. If you like platformers than Shantae: Half-Genie will grant one of your wishes.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
												I was a backer of this "Daniel David" in the credits (should have been Daniel David Kelly but it seems they acknowledge that some names got messed up), but theres no bias here, the game is good. I'll go into some details on the game however because its not flawless, no game is.Shantae managed to make a game many times better than Mighty No. 9 on a fraction of the budget, beautiful artstyle with solid gameplay with a feel of a Saturday morning cartoon. This really was a kickstarter done right.Shantae is not without its problems however, the main thing to point out in these flaws however is they've been persistant throughout all Shantae, so if these are a problem for you its more a problem with Shantae in general instead of this specific game:1) Game is linear compared to the past..... I guess? The past Shantaes were no Symphonies of the Night as far as exploration goes either, I don't know why it suddenly becomes a huge thing for this game. And in all honesty while they don't have alot of screens, theres still alot of stuff hidden in them for you to find using your powers which kind of ties right into the next major complaint.2) Alot of backtracking and fetch quests as "content":  I got no counter for this, its absolutely true. Even if the fetching is comical and corny on what they make you find, a spade is a spade. They do make you backtrack alot as playing in Hero mode proves. Most every shantae I've played however used this formula so its more a knock against Shantae than this game specifically.3) The game is short: my first play through was 6 hours, and has only gotten shorter in replays and hero mode.... once again however this is something Shantae has almost always been known for (I mean hell Risky's revenge you can 100% clear in 2 hours X minutes) Platformers are rarely epic 60 hour games unless they are a castlevania where most of that time is grind.What should be made important here is the game is put together very well and solid, while its a short experience its one that is great from beginning to end and is colorful and fun. I also sort of liked the format of this one that really felt like playing an old Saturday morning cartoon, as in each "level" feels self contained like an episode out of a show that all contribute a small thing that the last level feels like the conclusion of a season arc, it added to the over experience and made it fun.If the game is a bit too pricey for you, just wait for a sale, but if you love platformers this ranks up as one of the best ones.
