content:
Posted: January 1
												Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is the fourth Shantae game in the series, and is a pretty good game overall.The minute I started playing this, I was instantly blown away by the amazing graphics and catchy soundtrack the game had to offer. Unlike previous Shantae games, almost all the songs in the sountrack are not remixed and are completely new (one of them being Burning Town). The characters are humorous and lovable, just as usual.In terms of gameplay, Half Genie Hero is a very fun and enjoyable experience. The platforming and quests aren't very difficult. The game itself isn't very difficult either; at most, something in a boss battle catches you off guard but when you try again it's simple. The game is very linear, and there are no dungeons or labyrinths unlike previous Shantae games. Despite these differences, the game is still extremely fun to play and I see it as WayForward trying a new, fresh approach to making a Shantae game. Half-Genie Hero still has its fair share of backtracking to collect secret items, though.The only complaint I have about this game is the amount of content. It feels a bit short. The game also has a weaker plot structure compared to the other games. My first playthrough of the game, collecting everything, took me approximately eight hours. There are always the achievements, though, and you'll probably have to play the game some more if you want them all. The game is good, though, so no trouble. Also, additional downloadable content for Half-Genie Hero is scheduled to come out soon. It looks really interesting and will add more things to do in the game.Overall, I would definitely recommend Half-Genie Hero to anyone who likes Shantae, platformers, or anyone who just wants to play a well-made game. The game has a bit of an arcade feel to it, kind of like Mega Man, and is very entertaining and simple to just pick up and play. While the game may seem short, extensions will be released in the near future. The game is definitely worth playing (especially multiple times) and I suggest picking it up and experiencing it yourself, too.edit: a few soundtracks were remixed

content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
												Before I begin, I will let you know that I have played both Risky's Revenge and the Pirates Curse (both prequels). And Although I don't recommend this game, YOU SHOULD GO PLAY SHANTAE AND THE PIRATES CURSE! (which is a great game).First impressions about this game.The graphics are amazing (much more so than predecessors) and music is fantastic. And as usual, the gameplay is exceedingly smooth and controls respond very well. The dances are pretty cool and the story also leans more on the comical side compared to most games leaving a lighthearted feeling.Despite my glowing remarks above, I have 3 large issues with the game.Content: The length of time required to beat the game and get full completion is ridiculously short, ~5-7 hours for the average gamer.Story/Character Development: This is also related to the content. The story is pretty weak and honestly if you remove playing the actual levels, I could tell the entire story of the game to completion with like 2 sentences. Connected to this is character development. This game in no way makes anyone really care about any of the characters! Not even Shantae! If I hadn't played both the prequels, I would have no idea why Shantae was a half-genie and why she cared about the genie realm, or what her relation to Risky was! And then the supporting characters, rotty-tops/brothers + sky + bolo/grandpa: the game really does a disservice to how these people relate to shantae as from this game alone you could barely even tell that they were friends and not just some random townfolk A, B, C.Difficulty: This is yet another problem. Going through the levels are like a walk in the park (even so for non gamers) and the bosses while looking cool, are extremely dissapointing. All of the bosses patterns are extremely easy and they are honestly so weak that as long as you decide to use a potion (which you shouldn't really ever need), you can completely face-tank never dodge any of the bosses attacks and still smash them! Also the 4 skills which have always been a shantae staple are pretty much never needed. The fireball->flamethrower and lightning cloud are excessively weak and useless it pretty much every scenario. The pikeball/scimitar aren't really necessary but are usefull for clearing out monsters/bosses faster. And then the bubble is really good enough to make you invicible to some bosses (not counting the 3rd upgrade which is literally invincibility). And the magic power these things use is almost negligible for the time you need to activate it.Aside from ease in monsters and bosses, getting 100% completion and finding all the "secrets" is so simple that I don't even need to put any thought to find every single item! While it wasn't extremely hard in the Pirates curse at least I had to go revisit some areas just to search every nook and cranny for the special tinkerbells. In Half-genie hero, all the secrets are pretty much just lying in front of you waiting for you to get the right power to unlock it.Overall, the game is lovely but is waaaay too easy with a laughably simple and short plot that does not make you care for it in any way. I was really looking forward to this game but it really dissapointed me on many levels, even as a Shantae fan. Although I don't regret buying the game because I was a fan of the Shantae series (and this is probably the last game I'm guessing), I can't really recommend this unless this game is under $10. However, if you haven't picked up any Shantae games before I recommend you try out Shantae and the Pirates Curse. That game is way more polished than this one and doesn't really have any of these big issues that I listed for this entry here.

content:
Posted: January 31
 Target Audience:   Non-Difficult Platforming Fans, or Those who want an enjoyable, relaxing romp  Summary:  The 4th game in the Shantae series (the GBC game counts damn it), Wayforward put a bunch of emphasis in revamping the presentation this time around: and the change definitely works. While I still enjoyed the more classical pixel style of the older series, this new art style brings colors that jump off the screen, while still keeping the animation quality at the series high standards. And while the sound design does leave a bit to be desired, the music is fantastic as you would expect when Jake Kaufman is involved (Shovel Knight, Shantae series fame). This game is just a pleasure to look at, and the character design is probably the best it has ever been in the series.The gameplay on the other hand has taken a step back. While the platforming is still enjoyable, its difficulty in combat has taken a step back from Pirate's Curse, as some of the returning transformations such as the monkey form make dodging enemies a breeze. The emphasis on movement over combat still shows off the smart level design Wayforward is known for. And the boss fights do bring it a bit more this time around, as they are better designed then in Pirate's Curse. But a lack of length in gameplay and just a overall lack of difficulty plagues the game a bit. Overall, the game still is an enjoyable romp that keeps with the Shantae style. If you've liked the previous games in the series, you'll love Half-Genie Hero. Just don't expect an evolution in the gameplay.Video Review:  


YouTubeâ¢ Video: Shantae Half-Genie Hero (Review):Â 

			Views: 499		

			Shake, Shake, Shake that booty. Also, Mermaids and Monkeys. The Shantae Series has always been known for solid platforming action, but can the latest kickstarted game in the series keep it up?		

 Lists: Positives: The art work and presentation change is fantastic, as the new color and line work really bring Shantae and her dancing booty to life on the screen.  Good color choices as always: putting the foreground and the action elements with the stronger hues.  Music selection by Jake Kaufman is fantastic, appropriate for the levels in question.  Boss fights have definitely gone up a notch, as they felt like more of a test of my overall skills then previous games. Giga Mermaid fight was a prime example of a good difficulty: not too hard, but needing to take some skill in order to execute. Good humor as always from the writers of Wayforward. Some groan worthy puns as always, but it's the good kind of humor. Level Design great as always. Always good to go through the first time, but still fun to go through on the next few playthroughs.  Enemy variety is good. Good mix ups of melee versus range. Good difficulty for the casual player. Performance is flawless. 60 FPS with no drops. Character design elements are fantastic as always. Being able to recognize Shantae in her transformations is fantastic through the specific characteristics like her headband and her eyebrows.Negatives: The gameplay's combat has taken a step backwards. A bit easier to deal with enemies, and the enemies just don't pose the challenge they did in Pirate's Curse. Was Hoping for more after beating the game. I know that more content with new characters is coming later, but I found myself disappointed. Sound Design does leave a little bit to be desired, as some sounds seems to be missing, while others don't make a lot of sense in the big picture. Squeaky sounds on grabbing metal rings for example.  Shorter then the last games, and to me it showed a bit. Just didn't have the same impact over the full game's length. The Genie sub-plot here doesn't work as well as other games plot lines. The thread connecting the various substories is missing, unlike in Pirate's Curse. Keyboard default configuration must have been done with someone with giant hands. Missing sound sliders.

												While it falls short of previous Shantae-games, it's still quite the fun game and there's currently more to come (I believe there's a Risky Boots addition coming along). The art style alone makes the game worth the money. Game play is responsive and fluid, no major hiccups and as is usual you're able to chose your upgrades freely (magic or pure damage). The game is quite short though, beware.It's way easier to navigate than earlier games and there's more places to save your game - so if you haven't played any Shantae-games earlier this could be a good place to start. Though you will probably miss out on some of the jokes that's been carried since the very beginning.The only real negatives about this game is the lack of dungeons. Those were fun in previous titles. But since this whole game is built on instanced content and each level is a form of a dungeon which you'll need to do several times in order to unlock more and more of it - it's my favourite metroidvania-style-type of game series.Casual playthrough: 7h~ est.100% playthrough: 8h~est.100% steam achievements: 11h~ est.

												This is a solid game, with plenty of charm and great gameplay.  I love hearing the intro song for the first stage, and there's so many little tidbits to make this game extra nice.  I'd say it has that "Nintendo Polish"... like you know when something's added into a game that's not nessessary but adds positive spice to the presentation and emmersion of the world?  That's the "Nintendo Polish."  The dance transformations are back and they're great, with little time used to transform to different animals and objects for all your platforming/spell needs.  And I think the best part is the fact when you get an item like the Max Attract (third tier item) you can switch them off and go into every stage with as little equipment as you'd want, giving you a little challenge should you wish it.  It's wonderful to have that as an option, especially if folks want to challenge one another to beat the game with certain aspects. (hint hint Mr. Dragonrider Completionist ;D )As for completing the game, achievements and all, it's very doable.  So long as you've got a good memory for all item locations and a good place to farm the cash, and with the bonus Hero Mode when you beat the game once, you'll have a fun time.  And I'm looking forward to when the DLC for a new story mode is available.  n_nShantae: Half-Genie Hero is Highly Recommended for all players.

												Here it is, mentlegen! The third Shantae game has finally arrived (MY third Shantae game anyway)!Boy, this one was worth the wait. Both the animations and the gameplay are silky smooth, the music and the jokes are as good as ever and while I feel that the overall gameplay difficulty may have been dumbed down a little, there are also some new ways built into the game which enables all players to customize the stuff (power-ups/abilities) that they want and don't want to use, so they can manually make their game experiences harder for themselves if they find it too easy.It's so easy that I actually managed to get a 100% right during my first playthrough with some microscopical help.Easy as it may be, it's just as much fun to play. Backtracking no longer feels like the chore now that the dungeons are removed altogether and thanks to the buttload of new transformations and the majorly increased visual quality added to the once again catchy tunes and wacky gameplay it's ensured that you won't get annoyed about the fact that you have to visit the very same place for the 6th time.If the difficulty or the P.O.O.P.load of dungeons were the only things holding you back from getting a sip of the Shantae universe, then now is the perfect time to join our forces of relentless belly dancers.Together we shall dance through the danger! (and we'll never fail!)A must have for Shantae fans and highly recommended for fans of Raymanish games.P.S.: WayForward, you have my moniez for any future DLC content.

Great game altough a little way too easyShantae: Half-Genie Hero is that OTHER kickstarted game that was during the days of Migthy no.9 and oh boy, this one delivered unlike that other one. Altough quite short and simplistic on some aspects, Shantae delivers in what it promised. Shantae has:Lovely visuals and character-designInteresting level design that encourages exploration and revisitsLikeable characters and a easy-going plotPower-upsAwesome musicHowever, the game falls kind of short on some areas. For starters, it is incredibly easy... so much in all my playtime I didnt even died once nor had a hard time figuring where to go or do next.  Thats not inherently a bad thing but way sooner than later your character gets so strong it becomes laughable how you breeze through the stages. Magic spells are incredibly strong and in general, power-up items are really easy to get, you can pretty much start breezing through the game after the first hour of playing. Bosses are incredibly easy (with the exception of one or two, but not by much tho) and stages are pretty to see, but easy to traverse once you start getting one or two items and power-ups.Outside of the game being way-too-easy for its own good in general what it offers is great. The levels are pretty and intersting, the music is insanely good and, even if it easy, it will provide you with a handful of hours of great fun.Again, its only sin(?) is just that its way too easy for its own good but that might be a plus to some, not so much for the more hardcore of players tho. Totally recomended

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2016
												Full disclosure: I backed the game way back in 2013 and may be a little biased.I was really worried that Shantae: HGH is going to be another Mighty No. 9. I reminded myself that WayForward is a company with a good service list, but to err is human, right? Well, It has been out for 3 days now and I'm glad to say that it's not Mighty No. 9. In fact, HGH kinda blows the Kickstarter failure out of the water. HGH is a neat experience of a great colorful and vivid artstyle, amazing music and comfortable gameplay. The gameplay is your typical metroidvania: scattered over the levels are areas that are reachable only by performing a certain dance that transforms Shantae into a spider, a crab, a mermaid and et cetera. You could seperate the transformations into two groups: group 1 is made for platforming and group 2 is made strictly for puzzles (at least I have never personally found a platforming use for the mouse transformation). You're going to spend most of the game travelling back-and-forth, collecting hidden items with newfound transformations.This is when you get to the cons of the game. The transformations are, long term, pointless gimmicks. The mouse transformation is used around 5 times all over the game, while some of the other ones (mermaid, for example) come in too late to be a viable alternative to the one you got earlier (crab transformation). There's also no point to use them to combat enemies. In the end, you're going to use transformations to discover the occasional blocked off area, transform back to original Shantae because she's stronger, faster and more versatile, and then go on. By the way, as I've said, that's all you're gonna do for the majority of the game. I didn't really find that too bad because I'd be doing it anyway, but the fact that you're basically forced to repeatedly go through the levels to find hidden stuff makes it easier to 100% the game. And if you 100% the game too early, you get an eight hours long playtime. Now, I think that's quite normal for an indie platformer (for example, Shovel Knight takes about 8 hours to beat it too), but some people may disagree - that's quite alright, though WayForward has new characters for the game in the works. Maybe that will make the game longer?Basically, as a summary: Shantae: HGH was a very good experience, however it's only two real flaws are the most important ones: the transformation gimmick that dies off as the game progresses and the length.

content:
Posted: January 12
10/102017 is off to a great start (even though it released in very late 2016 shhh) with the release of Shantae: Half-Genie Hero, and let me tell you, it was worth the wait.  I was so excited for this game, I had to buy the steam version even though I already backed the game, because I just couldn't wait for my copy to arrive. Being in development for for nearly four years after a sucessful Kickstarter isn't always good, and I think we were all worried about a repeat of a certain blue helmeted robot boy's mistakes. Happily though, Wayforward has delivered in spades. Even though it's only January, I can already tell this is going to be one of my favorites, if not definitive favorite.Let's go over a few of Shantae's merits, if I may:The controls are as tight as you could ever want. Never once did I feel as if I messed up ro died because things were out of my control. The music is astounding. Wayforward always does good soundtracks, but they've gone above and beyond for this. It even has it's own single "Dance Through the Danger". The first time a Shantae game has had a voiced song, and it's absolutely wonderful. I've been listening to it all week.The art design is beautiful.  The colors and lighting will make sweet, tender love to your eyeballs.Demerits? I can't really think of any. There are some things I'd have liked that aren't there, but nothing that takes away from the experience. The first two games, the original and Risky's Revenge, had sprawling overworlds between dungeons, and while I really liked those and kind of miss them, I can see why they were removed from this game. The dungeons here are the focus, and I think they're stronger for getting the full spotlight.The game is very short. Spent about 8 hours on my first playthrough, but I enjoyed those 8 hours so much, I immediately tried to speedrun the game on 'Hero Mode' right after finishing, so replay value is high.I thought the dificulty was absolutely perfect. Challenging at the right times, and with simple portions as breathers. Some people may find it a little easy, though.

												PROS:- Amazing artwork, and the animations as always are fluid.- The dialogue and character interactions are pretty funny.- Jake Kaufman provides another great soundtrack.- Good platforming challenges- Controls are snappy and responsive, the best in the series so far.CONS:- The overall length is a bit short. The levels in 1/2 Genie Hero are more similar to Megaman stages.- Some of the transformations are just a pain to deal with. Looking at you, mouse.- The checkpoints are few and far between, which is made more frustrating with the inclusion of bottomless pits and instant-kill traps.It's a good game, you should consider getting it. There will also be more characters added that will drastically change (or so we're told) how you play the game. Fans of platformers will surely not be disappointed.

tl;drA fun, if simplistic, platformer with lots of metroidvania-esque backtracking.  8/10Ps & Cs+ Beautiful artwork+ Not everything is voiced (you'd hate it if it were)+ Lots of secrets to find+ A hard mode (which I recommend over the regular game)- VERY easy (on normal)- Levels don't connectNitty GrittyThis was a competent platformer.  If you choose to play, I'd recommend playing on Hard Mode, as normal is a joke (I think I died via damage like 3 times).  The plot isn't anything to write home about, but it's told tongue-and-cheek and it's cute enough.  You'll do lots of backtracking as there are tons of secrets that require advanced abilities to get through.  I got a solid 8 hours out of it, and I managed to collect about 90% or so of all of the games secrets.  Worth $20, for sure.  8/10

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2016
												Your typical platforming experience, with gorgeous graphics and full of charm. You jump around to get through levels while whipping some fools using your hair as a weapon. The usual.The most notable aspect of the game is that Shantae, the protagonist, transforms into different animals, each with their own abilities that'll be necessary at specific moments to reach all sorts of secrets or progress-related key items. There are also a lot of upgrades to these transformations that increase their capabilities to deal with both enemies and the terrain.Every level has a very distinct theme and gameplay focus. Each of them feels original and engaging.The only possible problem with this title is how much backtracking it puts the player through. I personally didn't have a problem with it, but I'd wager some people did. It's probably done to extend the durability of the game, since it's quite short. The silliness involved in the many NPC interactions that occur during these backtrack experiences made them totally worth it to me.Overall, it gets a hearty recommendation. It's fun, it's charming, it's funny, excessive backtracking being the one thing to be aware before you get this title.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
												Disclosure:I backed this game during it's crowdfunding campaign. Upon launching the game offers a 64bit DX11 version, this is the one I played.Shantae returns to once again do battle with her arch nemisis Risky boots and save Scuttle Town from certain doom. Graphics:This time out the pixel styled graphics from the previous games make way for new hand drawn sprites and 3D rendered environments (think Duck Takes Remastered). The game looks beautiful with high quality assests used throughout also teamed with the high quality animations the series has had in the past. The game also runs at a locked 60fps. However the graphics options are lacking, offering only resolution changes and AA options of off, on or dynamic.Controls:Controls are nice and responsive, press a button and the action is immidiate I was unable to detect any input lag or delay during my playthrough. The game supports both keyboard and mouse and controller configurations. However the game is best played on a controller and also gives out Xbox One button prompts. The default keyboard controls are a little odd with movement on the arrow keys, but are fully rebindable in the optins menu. The options menu is fully mouse driver as is the inventory screen, but the level select and save promps are not which is a little odd.Gameplay:The game plays out in the same way as the other Shantae games. Scuttle Town acts as the main hub world for the game offering a shop, access to the games art gallery (with unlockable concept and fan art), a save point and a selection of npc's to talk to who offer game hints or side quests to undertake. Heading into Sky's Hatchery allows Shantae to access the world map where the games levels are represented as desitnations that are unlocked using maps Shantae uncovers along her journey.The levels themselves consist of two platforming areas followed by a boss battle, however subsiquent visits to a level once completed does not have the boss battle and there is no way I have found yet to replaying bosses without starting a new game. The game does offer three save slots so new games can be played without fear of data loss.As with previous games in the series, Shantae unlocks transformations and abilities which allow her to further explore each of the levels and uncover more secrets each time through. It is the upgrades that are bring up the first negative of the game which is difficulty. The game is more on the easier side than previous installments if you go for all of the upgrades, especially health. Max health gives Shantae 14 hits before she is defeated and the game is quite generous regarding healing items as well. But these health items are optional and the game can be played through to the end with the starting 2 hit points if desired.Sound/Music:The sound in this game is great. Nice high quality sound effects are used throughout and some dialogue is even voice acted at times, although this is limited to Shantae and Risky Boots. Shantae even has voice lines for her magic spells.The music is also fantastic in this game, with personal notable tracks for me being the music for Mermaid Falls, the boss theme and of course the rocking main theme of the game Dance Through the Danger.Overall:I would thoroughly recommend this game as a purchase for those who are into platforming games or those who want a fun (all be it quite short, but replayable) experience. My first playthrough took me 7 1/2 hours to complete, with a 98% completion rating. There are unlockables such as gallery art and a Hero mode which opens up after completing the story once. Not sure what Hero mode is at the time of writing.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
												This Shantaeâs first HD adventure along with her returning genie powers, and it is excellent.Story/Graphics/Music:Like the previous entries, this is a very light-hearted story, not as great as Pirateâs Curse, but still fun. The cute style and great humor is all there, but in HD. You can probably tell from the screenshots, but this game looks beautiful and set a very high standard for future Shantae games to come. I also donât know how Jake Kaufman did it, but the soundtrack is even catchier than the last. Iâd also like to note that I really like how many older animations were carried over such as the butt wiggle as well as both Shantae and Rottytops idle animation, because it wouldnât feel right without them.Gameplay:Weâre back to regular movement with genie transformations. I thought Iâd miss the Pirate items, but transforming is quick and each one serves a good purpose. Levels are pretty big and while there is a decent amount of backtracking, it really feels like youâre exploring the map a lot more than previous titles. So while it is technically backtracking, it doesnât feel like youâre going back to levels just for the sake of padding. Most of the time youâre looking for more items, if not youâre at least compelled to because finding secrets in this game is fun. Some of the secrets donât blatantly stick out either so youâll have to use a bit of brain power to find everything, which I perfectly welcome. Much of the annoyances some people had are also gone, such as being able to leave a level at any time and skipping any parts that youâve already clear for free (once you receive the ability to). This means more playing and less traveling.The combat is quick and satisfying like an old school Castlevania game. You get access to spells and upgrades that generally help you do more damage and take less damage. One of the great things about every one of these upgrades is that they can be toggled off. This is great because after fully completing the game I started a playthrough with minimal upgrades on for a good challenge. Bosses are generally fun, with a few that are the âwait for your turnâ variety.Some grips:I really only have two issues with the game, the first one being the missing dungeons. If youâve played the previous Shantae games, you would consider these dungeons a staple in the series. You could say theyâve made up for it with bigger, more explorable levels, but they will be missed.My second gripe is the difficulty, way too easy this time around. I actually died being careless once or twice on the second level, but once you clear this and you get access to some money, you can reduce your damage by half. On top of that, you start to gain access to a lot more health upgrades so youâll have tons health. Another issue is that most enemies will not knock you back when getting hit like you would a lot of the time in Pirateâs Curse. Because of this, I normally just ran through levels taking damage for the sake of speed. Most bosses can also be brute forced before you need to use items, however I will admit I had to use healing items for the last boss. If you really wanted to, you could also fully nullify damage by end game which is a very questionable decision. I mentioned earlier I'm on a limited upgrade playthrough thanks to being able to toggle off upgrades. Again, I'm glad this is something you can do.Final thoughts:This marks the beginning of some great Shantae games. They have the engine and everything they need to make a great game now. I see this game as a little reboot to the series so Iâm hoping for many more to come. Some people might call this game too short. My first 100% playthrough was about 5 Â½ hours, about 1 hour shorter than my first Pirateâs Curse run. I would say the amount of content is just a little under the last game because you save so much time with the new features Iâve mentioned before, such as skipping beaten sections. Another thing that saves time is that the town NPCs actually give you hints on where to go so you more or less always know what you have to do. Regardless of the short time, I loved every minute of it and Iâm still re-playing the game even with all the achievements. I canât wait for Riskyâs campaign and any more content to come. If youâre into these types of games, thereâs absolutely no reason you shouldnât own Pirateâs Curse and Half Genie Hero.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2016
												I'm somewhat disappointed in this installment, but it was still a solid experience overall.If you're a newcomer: Shantae is a 2D platforming metroidvania series, and this is the 4th installment. It's got very well executed gameplay and controls. Shantae can transform into various animals to get around the area. There's a bunch of world to explore with their own themes and hidden secrets. It's very linear and easy compared to the previous installments, so I would recommend getting this one first to get a feel of the series, but overall I feel Shantae and the Pirate's Curse was a much better game.If you're a veteran: This game left a bittersweet feeling in my mouth. Half Genie Hero is still a well done game, but it feels so terribly bare bones compared to Pirate's Curse and Risky's Revenge. It's much shorter at about 5 hours long, way too easy especially with upgrades, no dungeons, very linear compared to the other games, plot that is very boring and goes nowhere, generic and few interesting setpieces, much smaller and linear stages that don't have any emphasis on exploring since most "hidden" objects just require a dance or upgrade you don't have yet. However, with all that said, it's no Shantae on GBC. What the game does, it does well. I just feel it lacks in a lot of areas, but it's by no means bad. Worth picking up on a sale if you loved Pirate's Curse.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 1
												Note: I backed this game on Kickstarter.Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is very interesting platformer. Before playing Half-Genie Hero I have played Shantae: Risky's Revenge and Shantae and Pirate's Curse. Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is much easier than previous games. I think I died only once while playing the game. The problem is that you can easily get Shantae overpowered for each stage. You get plenty of extra health, you get different methods of healing and you can power-up Shantae really fast. Also for last stage and bosses in it, I was able to be literally invincible. In other games I was never so overpowered. Good thing is that it's possible to turn off upgrades, so even if you try getting 100% everything, you don't have to be overpowered.  I believe that by turning of some of the upgrades, game gets much more challenging.I'm also little sad, how little some transformations and their skills are used in the game. Some transformations I only needed once or twice and some of their skills I never needed. On the other hand other transformations and their skills you need little too much. Also I used some transformations to skip platforming sections.I really love the new visuals. Every character and stage were visually very beautiful.  I think this game has best soundtrack of the franchise so far. Jake Kaufman truly nailed it with the soundtrack.Game has pretty nice and very funny story. There are lots of jokes with the characters. There's even some fourth wall breaks. It's not very long game, but that is good for me. I finished the story in 100% in 11 hours. After that you unlock a new mode, which I haven't at the time of writing this review.Even though I citicised some aspects of the game, I still loved it. It might be little too easy, if you make it too easy, but it's still very fun. Bosses are clever, though little easy. It is fun game. I'm not sure, if I liked this game more than Pirate's Curse, but I would recommend playing this one first of the franchise.

content:
Posted: February 25
												So I wrote a review on this game before but I'm doing another as there was an update along with hardcore mode. Pros of Orginal:Good musicGood graphics and animationsWhen there is voice acting it sounds goodLevels have many secretsGameplay wasn't too hard or easy (for the most part)Smooth controlsCons of Orginal:Story is very lacking and feels rushed at pointsRisky is pure evil despite what happened in the last game (Pirate's curse)Levels were short and linearDifficulty spikes because of different mechanics (such as the slide or using transformations for difficult sections)Overal fixes:Underwater mines now show explosion effect (No longer causing confusion)Hypno Baron's castle can no longer be flown over at the outside area (at least in hardcore mode, not sure about orginal)and some other small fixes I can't think of at the momentHardcore Pros:Enemies are actually a threat and take more damage while doing more damage (although some enemies do way too much in my opinion)Enemy attacks are faster and aim more for ShantaeDeserves the name "Hardcore mode" Hardcore Cons:Enemy placement can feel just jerkish and annoyingThe amount of enemies is way too highSome enemies doing way too much damage for normal enemiesBosses take too long at times or don't give you enough time to attack their weak points (Giga Mermaid is the worst in this case)The first phase of the last boss has an instant kill attack (which is cheap not hard)Risky takes even longer to defeat (doesn't help that if you die on the last boss you have to face her again)The difficulty spikes from the orginal feel even worse and I hated themIt made this game a bad experiance for me (I loved the orginal story a lot and made me a Shantae fan but this made me feel like crap and I didn't enjoy playing it)Overall I feel like people should play the orginal and should only play the hardcore if they're looking a for a big challenge, It's a shame that the hardcore mode changed my opnion of this game so much but it feels like it was made just to be hard, not to be fun or fair. I still like the game and I'm still looking forward to the other modes (like Risky mode or the other playable characters) but if they end up with that same difficulty I might take a pass. My scores of this game are Orginal : 78/100Hardcore: 60/100

content:
Posted: December 22, 2016
												This is a great addition to the series.Gameplay, music, visuals, all top-notch. The game consists of bright colors and the cute, cheery half-genie hero Shantae as you play through several different environments, be it a mermaid factory surrounded by water or a hot desert with strong winds. The transformations are really interesting. Some are chibi looking animals while others are cute monster-girls with every one having their own unique abilities that can be built upon if you find the hidden upgrades throughout each level. Shantae herself can be upgraded from the item shop by buying new spells and hair products and accessories.The game is a reasonable length of about 6-7 hours for your frist run (hard for me to judge because I left the game on in the background so my own time is not arcuate), although there's speedrunning challanges that time you for under 2 hours. I'll like to add I completed my run with 100% item collection and I think you should look for all the art gallery keys, the mayor's reward is worth it. There seems to be more content in the works, probable DLC for us none kick-starter folk, but I think as it stands the game is worth the asking price.I do recommend a controller for this game though, the default keyboard settings, at the time of this review, don't make much sense and it just feels way more responsive with a controller in hand. Overall, a great game and I highly recommend you pick it up!

content:
Posted: January 20
												I've been greatly enjoying some of the most recent WayForward games lately and this one is definately on the peak of enjoyment. Ever since they made A Boy and His Blob for the Wii, they have had this asthetic of hand drawn animations and amazing backdrops. I feel that Ducktales Remastered helped them solidify their style. And they brought it to Shantae, their own IP. And this game shines for so many reasons. Their art style brings every little detail to life. The music is really catchy, especially the one with lyrics you encounter early on. The gameplay gives this sense of exploration that fits the Metroidvania style of coming back to places once you have new powers. It is fun to play.Now, there are a couple gripes I've got. The game length is pretty short. Getting near 100% took me just about 6 hours to do. If the game had maybe a level or two more, I'd feel more satisified. There is also a huge issue in Mermaid Falls in the factory setting. At one point, you are jumping from hook to hook, but they are not in sync to always line up. I've spent a great deal of time just trying to get up the first time I played. It was frustrating.But beyond the slight flaws, I have to say I love this game. This is one I'd suggest you pick up and normal price if you love exploring based side-scrolling games. If you're on the fence, maybe wait for a sale, but I don't regret getting this game.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
												Cute characters and light-hearted humor elevate this tiny indie gem of a game.True to the series roots, Shantae combines a liberal amount of classic Megaman-esque run and jump platforming with a bit of exploration and backtracking ala Castlevania/Metroid. As you beat bosses and explore the mostly linear levels, you will earn upgrades to open up new pathways through levels and discover secrets in previously completed areas. While relatively small in scale, it matches the length of the previous installments in the franchise (about 6 hours for my first time to 100%) and certainly lives up to the legacy of its lavishly illustrated predecessors, trading in it's former pixel art for hand animated characters and brightly painted textures. Level design is clean and concise, making up for a lack of quantity with a density of quality content for the price. This game maintains the series focus on light-hearted humor and cute characters, with a strong soundtrack to tie the experience together.Some upgrades curiously seem superficial and under utilized in the level design (i.e. the Bat Sonar ability is only use-able in one side room and the room can still be navigated using visual cues from other light sources), but most content in the game is well utilized throughout the game.The storyline feels much more segmented than previous titles, probably due to the fact that each level was a different "stretch goal" when the game was being kickstarted. This makes the plotline and characters feel much more episodic and less developed than previous entries (especially comparing it to Pirate's Curse), but overall tone maintains a sort of "Saturday morning cartoon" feel that remains consistent across the entire game.While the current release only includes Shantae as a playable character, future updates have promised an expanded roster of playable characters, but they are not in the game as of this review. Wayforward generally doesn't do many post-release updates (they have a good track record of releasing games that very feature complete), but this is also their first crowdfunded game so time will tell just how well these promised expansions end up being.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2016
												While this game is visually superior to previous games in the series, in other areas it appears to have taken one or two steps backwards.Gameplay is as good as it's ever been, though perhaps a bit stale given how little has changed. Same spells, same upgrades. Even the transformations are largely recycled from previous games. In fact there are probably too many transformations. It sometimes felt contrived how the level layout required certain transformations to progress.This game can't seem to decide whether it's aiming to bring in new fans, or pander to old fans. The game is more simple and linear compared to previous games, but spends next to no time on character introductions, expecting you to already know who everyone is. And while the old transformations do look great in HD, they lack personality. In particular, I really miss the monkey's idle animation from Risky's Revenge.The pacing is also kind of messy. As with previous games, to progress you need to find the relevant collectibles in levels you've already cleared. This creates a sort of slow, leisurely "scavenger hunt" type of game, during which you jump around and fight enemies set to an exciting soundtrack. This structure was also in previous games, and is not a problem.What I'm talking about is the "in-between" segments, when you talk to NPCs to get hints and hand in quest items. There's very little dialogue before you're onto your next task. So you might spend half an hour finding the item you need, and then you get less than a minute of plot before you're onto the next level. The game felt really short, too.While we're at it, boss battles. This game's bosses are pitiful. I'm not talking about difficulty, I'm talking about buildup. Risky's Revenge had actual dungeons in which the bosses resided, and you would know their name before meeting them.Pirate's Curse was longer, so didn't do this for each boss. Those it did build up, though, were well done.Then we get to Half Genie Hero, and there's practically no build up for any of them, least of all the final boss, which is only introduced when the battle begins.The final bosses are the most irritating example of this. RR had the boss take something the player themselves had come to cherish, and turn it against them. PC had a deliberate repeat of this, but getting the right collectibles adds a twist to the ending which turns everything upside down. HGH has the boss show up and fight you. And... that's pretty much it. If more effort had gone into developing the plot or characters, the stakes might have felt higher, but as it was, it was just a moderately more difficult boss battle.If you've read this far, you might be wondering when I get to the reason this is in the positive reviews section. And that reason is that despite all its flaws, this is a good game that I enjoyed playing, and I think it is well worth the $20 USD pricetag.The other games are better though.

content:
Posted: January 12
												I've got a lot to say about this game, but not all of it positive. TLDR; Good game, Wait for sale.---Pros: Character Design, Visuals, and Animations: Gone are the days of the retro low-res character sprites and pixelart tiled level design. Each character has high resolution character sprites that are fluidly animated, and the traversable environments are all rendered in cell-shaded 2.5D. Music: Anybody that has played a Shantae game will tell you that it has some of the best music of the platforming genre. A lot of the more memorable leitmotifs from the series, such as the Burning Town and the main theme, return in a number of ways. This include such tracks as Neo-Burning Town, which retains its middle-eastern flair while also taking on a club-music feel, and Dance Through the Danger, which I'm admittedly biased about because Cristina Valenzuela (the voice actress for Shantae's spoken lines) provided A++ vocals for the song. Never get tired of hearing that woman sing. Like all Shantae Games, you'll be hard pressed not to find a track from its soundtrack that hooks you. Puzzles: The game loves to make you look for the solution to finding that one collectable you can see but not get to. At the same time though, they are never too difficult; it's usually just a matter of backtracking, and if you keep up with chatting with the NPCs, you'll never be short on hints. Just keep on exploring. Just be aware that some transformations completely kill puzzles, and some puzzles you can technically complete before you get the ability or power-up required to do them. Boss Battles: One thing I've always liked about the boss battles in the Shantae games is that they are almost always unique, and in Half-Genie Hero, it was no exception. One battle has you relying on bits of the environment introduced in a mission, while another has you running yourself in literal circles as you try to figure out how to actually damage the boss. Transformations: Lots of them. I won't spoil all of them, but a number of the classics from both the gameboy color Shantae title, as well as the returning forms and abilities from Risky Revenge make their return in Half-Genie Hero, in addition to a number of new ones to play with.---Cons: Performance: For a modern game with such modest specs, Half-Genie Hero has its share. For one, the game has Vertical Sync permanently enabled and expects your monitor to have the exact refresh rate of 60Hz, meaning that if you're running on a 120Hz monitor, or you're playing on a TV at a non-60Hz refresh rate, such as one running at 1080i, you're going to have a bad time. It spazzes out on higher refresh rates, and on lower rates, sprites flicker, FPS caps at 30, and within the first minute of the game the camera goes epileptic before shooting off into the void. Even if you're running it at a 60Hz refresh rate on a progressive resolutionâsay 720pâand your system meets and exceeds the reccomended system specsthere's no guarantee you're going to get that smooth 60FPS the game expects to run at without a bit of fiddling. Case in point, I had to tell Radeon Settings to use the Frame Rate Target Control at 60 just to get that smooth 60 at 720p. Level Design: To put it bluntly, the levels are incredibly short. Most of the dungeons consist of medium or large 'rooms' that require you to navigate back and forth through on the x and y axes, taking into account the elements and obstacles of that particular level. You might be required to hop across a series of platforms that fall if you stand on them for too long, or scale a tall room hopping from moving ring to moving ring. For the most part, it's a far cry from the Shantae standard of dungeons being a series of small interconnected rooms. Heck, it's so simplified that you don't even get a map this time around. This brings me to... World: In the previous Instalment, Shantae and the Pirate's Curse, you access to Scuttle Town as your 'hub', from which you had access to a boat which would take you to the world you would then need to navigate and explore, just to get to the dungeon. In Half-Genie Hero, the devs took the 'boat' and decided, "How about we just drop you right in the 'dungeon' and cut out the middle man." You just go to Skye's place, hop on her mode of transportation, and off you go to the dungeon select screen. Don't even get me started on Pirate's Curse vs. its predecessor. Of course, to account for the smaller world and bigger, they had to put in a lot of... Padding: With only a series of short dungeons, the devs definitely seemed hard pressed to make sure the game lasted. To account for this, they utilized a number of things to pad out the game. Backtracking was always a big thing in previous Shantae Games, but a lot of it could usually be mitigated by knowing where something was ahead of time. There wasn't TOO much that hinged on you having a specific transformation, or a particular ability for said transformations. I'm not talking about little mini-puzzles that force you to use specific transformations and problem solving, I'm talking about the things that draw things out such as the mouse form mazes, or one-off abilities such as sonar for the bat transformation, which is used for all of one puzzle that can technically be solved without it. You see that collectable on display right out in the open where you can't get it because you don't have a specific ability? You're going to be tormented by those a lot for three quarters of the game until you get that power you don't have. Then of course you have things like rings that disappear from the foreground or the infamous disappearing platforms. If you've played the classic Megaman games, you know exactly what I'm talking about. They're just a right pain to get the timing down on, which just creates... Artificial Difficulty: I just want to say that Half-Genie Hero is not a hard game. That said, it does have segments that will make you want to tear your hair out. For example, in the very final dungeon, you are required to use your Harpy transformation to navigate a series of spiked walls, some of which were moving. This might not have been so bad if the game actually gave you reason to use said transformation [which was only just acquired AFTER the second to last dungeon] and some practice, but you're basically thrown into the deep end of the pool with cement sneakers on, and you've been missing leg day lately. It is basically Flappy Bird in that section. You have an early segment where you're in a restricted movement auto-scroller, and you need to rely on reflexes and skill to not miss a jump or hit something that will inevitably damage you. This kind of segment returns after the final boss and is cranked up to 11, with shorter platforms, the rings where if you're not placed just right, you will miss and go back to the start, and wall of death that continues to take up more and more of the screen, making the segment a game of memory and reflex as you end up with less and less space to work with. It was, apparently, difficult enough that the devs removed your life bar for this segment. I can only imagine how bad it would have been otherwise. Stretch Goals: In case it wasn't readily apparent, Half Genie Hero is a kickstarter game, and budget can be blamed for some of the shortness. Two of the levels in this really short game were in fact stretch goals. Yep, the game would be shorter if those goals hadn't been met. Iterestingly enough, the very first stretch goal, a mode where you play as Risky Boots, is not present as of this review, and is slated as Coming Soon. So in a way, the launch exclusion of Risky Mode, coupled with the performance issues kinda gives the game an Early Access feel rather than a full launch.

content:
Posted: January 15
												*Note: I was a backer for this game*This latest installment is a bit of a departure from the rest of the series, but is fun nonetheless.  For those of you that are new to the series, this game is made up of 18 well-designed levels (3 levels per world, 6 worlds total).  There are 8 creatures you can transform into to aid in traversal, but some of them are redundant (do we really need 2 forms for flying, and 2 for swimming?  Surely these could have been merged).  Where the level design differs from past games is that they are more linear like you would find in a standard 2-D platformer.  This is a good or bad thing, depending on your preference.Cons - The game is pretty easy, with up to 10 heart containers to find in the world, buyable armor that you can get very early to cut damage recieved in half, and a bat form that can also be found pretty early that breaks most of the platforming sections after that point (if you really want to cheat).  Bosses can be fun when trying to work out how to damage them, but with lots of health, armor, and recovery items you rarely need to even bother with dodging their attacks.The story seems to be decently written, and funny at times, but is also unfocused.  Each level is treated like it's own episode, which sounds nice, but also means that things are introduced and quickly discarded.  For example a rival Half-Genie Holly appears after the first level, but disappears after some taunting.  After the next level, she appears in 2 more scenes before she's gone for good.The game is really short.  My first blind playthrough of this game took about 7 hours to get to 100% completion.  When hunting for trophies on the PS Vita version I finished the main campain in 1 hour 40 minutes (any %) and 3 hours 30 minutes (100%).  More content is on the way as DLC, and it'll be free for me, since I'm a backer, but others will have to pay for it.Pros - The game is beatiful, with great music.  It is made up of 2-D characters on 3-D background, but at times it hard to tell what's drawn or not.  The style blends very well.  Animations are smooth (though maybe the idle animations can be a bit over-blown sometimes).  I've enjoyed Jake "virt" Kauffman's music since the VGMix days, and this soundtrack is no exception.The levels are fun when you don't break them with Bat or Harpy form.  Playing with minimal power-ups feels like a closer approximation of the intended experience.  Level and monster designs are good when the skillset is brought more in line with normal 2-D platformers.Searching for secrets in this game was a lot of fun as well.  The developers put in some interesting puzzles, making re-visiting levels something you actually want to do.Rotty Tops.As for a straight "Recommend" or not I'm a bit torn.  I honestly had a lot of fun playing through the game, but at $19.99 USD for what is a 4 - 8 hour game it might not be worth it.  I will click "Recommend" for now, but I would advise that maybe you wait for either a sale or at least for some of the DLC to come out.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
												Great level design, very tight controls, and wonderful music are the best ways to describe this game.  Every level feels fresh and unique, and the game very heavily (almost to a fault) promotes revisiting old areas with new abilities to discover secrets and items.  There are a few bugs here and there, but nothing that harmed the experience.  My only gripes with the game is that there aren't enough areas to explore (5 in total), and the lack of overall challenge in the game.  I said that the areas are fun to explore, but they are considerably less fun the umpteenth time an npc sends you out looking for an item.  Many items can be achieved prior to an npc asking for them however, and those looking for the shortest completion time will be challenged to find the quickest way to collect everything.  Enemies do very little damage and falling down pits does even less.  Additionally, the game hands you upgrades in the form of "Relics", which grant secondary abilities to your transformations, magic attacks that draw power from a mana bar, or passive abilities.  One such relic, obtained by gathering 10 keys hidden throughout the game that unlock concept art in the town hall, gives you an endless mana pool to draw on.  This is very easily abusable with the magic powers you acquire over the course of the game, including a shield that makes you invisible.  By collecting this one relic, you essentially activate god mode and can't be damaged at all.  You are able to turn the upgrades on and off at any time, which I found very welcome trying to give myself a bit more of a challenge, but even without them you'll very rarely see the game over screen.  The game also relies on manual saves where an autosave system would serve so much better.  For instance, going to the map screen mid-level calls a save screen, and upon selecting any other area on the map calls ANOTHER save screen.  The game is also rather short (I achieved 100% completion in about 7 hours according to the in-game timer), so I would mostly recommend this game to completionists or those looking to speed run.  Overall, this is a fantastic game marred by just a few disappointments.  As of the writing of this review, I have only finished the standard game mode with 100% completion with an early copy provided by backing the kickstarter campaign, so the bugs I mentioned earlier will probably be ironed out by the time the game fully launches.PROS:-Great sound design/OST-Fun and diverse levels-Incredibly tight controls-Great for speedrunningCONS:-A little too much backtracking-Lacking in overall number of areas-Some minor oversights (such as the save system)I give Shantae: Half Genie Hero a 9/10.

content:
Posted: January 26
												I came into this game with low expectations. I really didn't like Risky's Revenge, and never played Pirate's Curse. I was prepared to walk into another boring backtracking marathon.And then The title screen came up and I changed my mind. You can tell a game is going to be great when the freaking title screen makes you excited. I made a new file and holyâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥everything just blew me away. The animations are so fluent, the graphics are amazing, it controls really well, and that was just from the intro section.I soon got into the game, surprised to see it's really more of a metroidvania hybrid of sorts. There are metroidvania elements, but for the most part it plays like a regular platformer. It's like your first time through the stage is normal, and once you clear it you can revisit it to get the stuff you couldn't before. Unlike in RR, the areas are all REALLY interesting. (Mermaid Falls is easily my favorite level in any platformer, actually!) And the backtracking doesn't get old. It'd be nice if there was a minimap of some sort, so you could easily check unexplored areas on the fly. But it's not that hard to figure out without it. I managed to 100% this game in 7 hours, and I enjoyed every minute of it.A bit of a fair warning, though. This game suffers from "Help the enemy is too cute and I don't want to kill it" syndrome. Especially prevalent with Nagas, Mermaids, and Slimes. You may take lots of damage from ogling the things out for your head instead of fighting.I don't usually mention music in my reviews, because there's not much to say about it usually, but this has a really great soundtrack. It's a real earworm that pumps you up. And what else could you ask for with a platformer?The game isn't too challenging, as long as you keep yourself upgraded. If you get 99% before the last level, you are basically immortal, as you can infinitely use Invincibility or Total Restoration. And you'll NEED IT. Because WOW that last level is so freaking rough. It's incredibly challenging, much more than the rest of the game. But all that aside, the game is amazing in every other regard. I would easily say it's My favorite platformer, ever.9.5/10. Go buy this game.

Posted: January 6
												PROS:- Wonderful character designs- Beautiful backgrounds- Great soundtrack- Smooth gameplay and controls- Well-designed levels and bossesCONS:- A few minor storyline plotholes- Game is quite short (10-12 hours for first 100% run)- Not all promised Kickstarter features have been implemented (yet)The art and music immediately stand out in terms of quality, making for a very enjoyable gaming experience. The controls, level design and gameplay are all highly polished, ensuring that it isn't too punishing for platformer newbies while there are enough secrets and challenges for more serious players to complete. However, like its previous installments, the game suffers from its short length and limited replay value.Overall, I rate "Shantae: Half-Genie Hero" as one of the best platformers released in 2016. The game is definitely worth full price on its own, but do note that several DLC are already in development to add additional costumes for Shantae and new campaigns where you can play as Risky, Rottytops, Sky and Bolo. I'd recommend keeping an eye out for new game updates this 2017.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2016
												WayForward once again delivers on the Mega Man X formula that made Shantae and the Pirate's Curse a success with Half-Genie Hero. A not-quite reboot of sorts, this entry ties together the classic tropes of Shantae's transformations and collectable abilities from the original Gameboy Color entry with the streamlined world design of its immediate predecessor. The game rewards exploring previously visited areas with newly gained abilities, and all but the most impatient of players should find it quite clearable without a strategy guide. Though not a difficult game, there are some puzzle platforming sequences and potentially Klonoa-inspired boss battles to keep things fresh. Although not every bit is a slam dunk (a certain escape sequence comes to mind), Half-Genie Hero makes for a breezy, fun weekend's worth of adventure platforming, and I look forward to tackling it again with the unlockable characters.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												I should probably say that Iâm newcomer to the series and Half-Genie Hero is my first game in the franchise.  I liked the game, which seems strange considering my final vote on it â my final feelings lie somewhere in the middle, but Steam doesnât have neutral score, so I cannot use this.The game certainly looks polished when you play it â characters look beautiful, music is fantastic and animation fluid. Game plays smoothly and responsively (usually, we will talk later about some forms...). The level design is good and most of the levels are blast to play. Transformation are fun and open a lot of new ways to move though levels, other power-ups and spells make fight interesting and give players a lot of options to dispatch enemies.So far it seems like very nice platformer, doesnât it? However, the longer you play, the more cracks start to show. There are only few (hub, five main and final) levels, which wouldnât be a problem â game doesnât really have to be very long to be good and leave nice impression, but you can see that creators saw short length of the game as big problem and were afraid that it seemed to short. Most of my problems stems from methods they applied to combat this problem.- First, that five main levers? They are very interesting first time you play though them and nice second time, with some small changes in monster or trap placement. However, you better hope you will really like them, because you will be playing them over and over trying to find that missing upgrades necessary to progress your story. At this point I just cannot look at beautifully designed and interesting creepy factory level considering how many times I have to beat it. When you have to give players spell to skip parts of the world to get instantly to next level (you get that and this is immensely helpful, but still doesnât  eliminate main problem) you really should think if amount of backtracking isnât too big. At some point it just stop being fun (and Iâm a completionist type of player) and start to seem like artificially padding the gameâs length.- Instant death traps spanning entire sublevels. Well, they are not exactly instant death (you only lose some energy after failing and are moved to the beginning of challenge), but they are rather long with no checkpoints in the middle. It wouldnât be that bad, but they are designed for you to fail at least few times before you can play them from memory. Two of them remove most of your special skills and make you fall down slippery slope while jumping over chasm and avoiding barrels (donât know, maybe it is series tradition? Doesnât really seem fun), with some jumps timed in the way that you cannot really succeed on them without inhuman reflexes or precise knowledge coming from failing them before â and if you will, you will have to replay entire segment from the beginning.  Another one is âlava risingâ type of the level â you need to climb tower while instant kill condition rise from the bottom. This is classic platformer design, however even in Ninja Gaiden series it was clear where you should jump â Shantae sublevel is long and have tons of blind ends, making you constantly fail until you progress to almost the end and can play sublevel from memory where you should move to avoid moving into blind end.- These instant death trap type of sublevels? One of them comes just after final boss. Itâs extremely fun to have do trial and error long gameplay segment when you have just won final fight and want to sit back and relax while story unfolds ;-)- There is instant death sublevel build entirely on how unwieldy and full of inertia is one of the transformed Shantaeâs forms. I know that controls of that form are bad, you donât have to show me that so much ;-) - Lots of upgrades seem like afterthought â for example, special power of bat transformation is used exactly once and only to get relic that allows another (not really useful for combat) almost optional form to attack.- There is an upgrade late game (I think you get it for unlocking entire art gallery? Not sure) that gives you unlimited mana allowing for endless casts of spells. Doesnât seem too bad, strong bonus for completionists, until you realize it means unlimited instant full life heals, unlimited healing items spawn and unlimited invulnerability bubble spell.  Because of that final level consist mainly of instant kill spikes, while final bosses are a joke.- For the end â characters. They seem fun and interesting. They seem to know Shantae, but I have no idea how and why. If you donât know them from previous installments, there is pretty much zero explanation who they are, how they know Shantae and why are they friends/enemies.To sum up -  I enjoyed most of this game, at least until more annoying parts came up, killing my enjoyment each time. It is a very nice game and I hope there will be next game in the series that will polish problems this one is full of â but at this point, my opinion is a little more negative than positive (I would really like to be able to choose neutral opinion in Steam review options).

content:
Posted: January 8
												I am confused as to what went wrong. Looking back at the previous installations of this series, all that needed some refinement was the minimap and maybe enemy combat. However, Way Forward tries to solve the navigation issues by making all levels linear, completely debilitating a lot of the established core design patterns, and we can see the consequences of this: the game has a mere six levels, yet there are eight transformation abilities, each of which can be further upgraded. The game's world is too small to bring all these abilities to life in a meaningful manner. What follows is the tedious kind of backtracking: Revisiting previous levels to find that one block you could not previously break, that one spot you could not previously climb, that one platform you could not previously reach, all while traversing exhausted content that has lost its meaning by the time you come back with your bag full of upgrades that allow you to fly past everything, just so you can get some thing using some other thing you just got, which, afterwards, you won't be using again, except maybe once in some later puzzle, deliberately designed to make you use the thing, all in order to feign the presence of meaningful choice; but there is none. This design decision spawns further problems, but I'll refrain from emphasizing. By reducing the world to linear levels selected from one central screen, Way Forward has placed an obstacle before themselves that they could not deal with.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2016
												This game is very cute and has a lot of love poured into it, but suffers immensely from a very bumpy difficulty curve. The developers seem to be either unable or unwilling to create levels that are anywhere between easy and hard.Most of the easy levels feature platforming and enemies, but with little or no consequence for failing the platforming - and enemies can be easily dispatched, ignored, or avoided most of the time. I never once died to any of the enemies, including the bosses, and I imagine most other players will be able to say the same thing.However, some of the levels are completely different, and feature very few enemies, and often difficult or finicky platforming, with the consequence of missing a jump being an instakill, which sends you back to the last checkpoint. Unfortunately, there are very few of these, so falling into a pit can send you back quite a distance.The final zone is where this all culminates into one huge mess. The levels leading up to the final boss consist mostly of screens that are almost literally Flappy Bird, with instant kills lining every wall. Getting through those screens took me significantly longer than beating the final boss itself, and after that I was dropped in an auto-run level that was even more difficult, and took me even longer to complete. I didn't feel a sense of accomplishment by the time I was done; just frustration.Bottom line: Watch a playthrough instead. The difficulty of the levels spikes too much for me to call this a good game, which sucks, because there's a lot of great work put into just about everything else.

Posted: December 20, 2016
												I am proud to have backed Shantae: 1/2 Genie Hero, and along with games like Shovel Knight stands as evidence to the usefulness of Kickstarter in delivering the game developers wanted to make to the players who wanted to play it. From the onset to the credits, its a delightfully colorful and vibrant platformer, that happens to be well written and funny on top of its mechanical excellence. I consider it a treat for returning fans and I'm sure, for newcomers as well.As the first title in the series built for home consoles and PC, the graphical improvements are immediately apparent. We have come a long way from Game Boy Color, with vastly more fluid sprite animations over pleasing 3D backgrounds. It has notably lost none of the magic of its predecessors, as well as its reputation for charmingly attractive character designs that have just enough appeal to not be tacky. The controls are spot on, and should be familiar to anyone to has played SNES or Genesis era titles with a keyboard. I must give special consideration to the soundtrack, which I coughed up extra for during the Kickstarter. If you're at all familiar with Jake "Virt" Kaufman and his work on the previous Shantae games, Shovel Knight, Contra 4, Scurge: Hive and many other projects, you'll know what to expect. He's really outdone himself this time.The transformation dances that are a hallmark of the series return, including at least once dance that hasn't been seen since the very first game. This one has by far the most dances and other upgrades, enough that collecting all of them makes you virtually indestructible, in particular making the final boss fight rather trivial. This would require you to actually FIND everything, but it's not the hardest Metroidvania to explore. In fact, it's structured more like the Megaman X games. It also has some harder platforming segments then Pirate's Curse.The few negative reviews of the game all talk about the difficulty, or rather, the lack of it, and the afforementioned backtracking. At no point in the game did I find either of these things aggrivating. Having recently completed a solo playthrough of Bloodborne, I can tell you that there are hard games out there. And there are cheap ones, overhyped ones, and ones that value leaderboard scores over anything resembling fun. Shantae: 1/2 Genie Hero is none of those things, and that is fine. What it is, is a diamond in the rough, a game that made me feel good just to be alive to play it. I think it will do the same for you, and in the end, that's what gaming is really about.

												Shantae:  Half-Genie Hero is a very fun platformer, I highly recommend this game to those that are looking to get into the genre or for those that enjoy these type of games.The world map is very straight forward, you going from stage to stage with each one containing a boss.  You may choose to do this, but the game encourages you to replay the levels again to find secrets and upgrades.Combat is fairly straight forward.  What makes this game special are the various unique transformations you can turn into to complete stages and also find secret areas withen them.  Throughout the game you can find secret npc's that upgrade your transformations that lets you do special moves/attacks.There are also a variety of spells that you can choose from and each one is upgradeable to a certain point.  The only issue I have is the small amount of content, I would love to see more stages because they are very well done.  The progression system is just right which keeps you constantly engaged, which makes this game very enjoyable and you'll definitely get your money's worth.

												Beautiful graphics, amazingly upbeat music and tons of humour from all the characters you meet makes this game a nice addition in the Shantae series, but also a strong and well done game on it's own.The platforming in the game is very well done and it doesn't feel floaty and despite it doesn't have as many levels as other new platformers, it manages to build the stages in such a way that it's practical from the start, but also shows you how to get to the secrets later on when you get the needed power-ups.This game about a ponytail whipping, belly dancing and spellcasting half-genie is something I can recommend to anyone who loves a good platforming game.

Posted: December 23, 2016
												Shantae:  Half-Genie Hero is a very fun platformer, I highly recommend this game to those that are looking to get into the genre or for those that enjoy these type of games.The world map is very straight forward, you going from stage to stage with each one containing a boss.  You may choose to do this, but the game encourages you to replay the levels again to find secrets and upgrades.Combat is fairly straight forward.  What makes this game special are the various unique transformations you can turn into to complete stages and also find secret areas withen them.  Throughout the game you can find secret npc's that upgrade your transformations that lets you do special moves/attacks.There are also a variety of spells that you can choose from and each one is upgradeable to a certain point.  The only issue I have is the small amount of content, I would love to see more stages because they are very well done.  The progression system is just right which keeps you constantly engaged, which makes this game very enjoyable and you'll definitely get your money's worth.

Posted: December 20, 2016
												Love the game but the story feels like each character has their own vertical silo and it doesn't interact together well compared to previous titles.Solid controls, beautiful graphics, fantastic music, slick animations.Had fun solving the puzzles although stage design varied, sometimes yawn-inducing to exciting.The game has been put together well and it's enjoyable to play as an overall package. This is a masterpiece compared to the other kickstarter I backed (Mighty No 9) in terms of project management, community communication and overall product.Main irk for me was the save points.
