Posted: January 3
												Having played every single one of the Shantae games (starting with the very first on the GBC), I must say that this kick-started game is the best one that Wayforward has ever made. Although short (and lacking in the story department), there is a lot to love about Half-Genie Hero. The art style and animations are incredibly cute and vibrant, the music is ridiculously catchy, the dialogue is drenched with the Wayforward wit we've come to know and love from all their other games and the gameplay is exactly how any good Metroid-vania game should be: responsive, precise and genuinely fun. If you haven't played a Shantae game before, do yourself a favor and pick this one up. Show Wayforward some love for all their hard work!

Posted: January 3
												Manages to be a great game despite being entirely different from its predecessors. Transformations, while interesting and numerous, are just not as interesting as the gear used in Pirate's Curse, with most ending up very situational (I can count the number of times I used spider shantae on one hand, and I 100%ed the game). Despite this, the game seems to use the premise of dance-transformations the best of all previous titles, and is honestly a lot of fun to play through.Risky Boots DLC could easily fix these problems, but it's not out yet.If you're looking to get into the Shantae series, I would still recommend Pirate's Curse, but if you crave more, then this game won't disappoint. The story is well-written and entertaining in each game, but the overarching plot isn't too serious, so playing out of order won't hurt anyone.PS: This game does not feature the best girl, squidsmith, and thusly is complete garbage. Bring her back right now, wayforward!

Posted: January 7
												So far, really enjoying the game. It's bright, colorful and is super smooth with it's tweened animations. Really impressive art and animation. I'm less into the 3D backgrounds, they contrast too harshly with the character art, they work for the most part. Gameplay is nice, it's a mix between Risky's Revenge and Pirate's Curse, you get the transformations of the 2nd game and the faster gameplay of the third game....Buuuut it's levels are not as large or have the depth of the previous games. They feel simple and easy. Maybe this changes a bit more later? I'm not sure yet. One thing that's a bit frustrating so far is there's a lot of weird backtracking. Weird as in, you'll beat level, go back to the level with a new power to get some more stuff right? But you won't have the ability to get through a wall...So you can only collect 2/5 items required to progress ...till you go further down the level, talk to an NPC who gives it to you making you walk back what you JUST did....twice. As said earlier, levels aren't massive so it's not a huge deal but it's just weird to make you run back right away. Overall, so far I think Pirate's Curse is a better game. But this is a game worth getting all the same. Lot of charm and polish. One thing is for sure, despite Mighty No. 09 getting all the hype and all the money this game managed to do more with less. It plays better, looks VASTLY better, is far more optimized and has all the charm and character you'd expect from Way Forward.

Posted: December 20, 2016
												Half-Genie Hero is a triumphant return of the Shantae series. The art style and animation is so fluid and detailed, there are times when I'm honestly not sure if what I'm looking at is a sprite or 3D model. I've NEVER had a game make me question this, and it's a testement to artists and animators who brought Shantae to life.The game is equally a blast to play. Controls are fluid and responsive, even the seconds needed to cycle between Shantae's animal forms don't take too long to break flow. Combat with Shantae's equally detailed and expressive foes is challenging, without being too frusterating. The platforming never gets so pixel-perfect as to want to break your controller, especially with Shantae having multiple ways to progress through challenges. I am also happy to say I never needed to go Googling for the answer to any puzzles or platforming challenges.The game is relatively short, I finished in about 3 days, spending 2-3 hours each run. Despite being metroid-vania in structure, the game is spread over different stages you chose to travel to, akin to Shantae and the Pirate's Curse. However, every stage is PACKED with secrets, and I found myself going through each stage again whenever I gained a new ability. The stages themselves visually change after the boss is defeated, making return trips feel fresh. Plus, there's new characters that will be added to the game for free with their own campaigns in the future, and I am eager to play them!The boss fights themselves are amazing. Many even zoom out to make room for the massive boss on screen. Each one is intense and satisfiying to fight, though none proved to be so difficult that I could not defeat on the first try.Like most of the Shantae games, the plot is fairly standard, and you can probably see all the twists a mile away. Though, like most of the Stantae games, the story is more defined by the characters and their dialogue, all of which is cleaverly written. Shantae and her friends are utterly hilarious and witty, and it's worth playing the game just to see them bounce quips off one another.My only serious complaint is the relatively weak finale, especially compared to the previous games. The final battle is disapointing, as is the conclusion, at least compared to the last 2 games. For less serious complaints, the story overall, especially in terms of character development, isn't quite as good as Pirate's Curse, though still good. There's also an issue of balance, as most of Shantae's animal forms are pointless to use in combat. You even wind up finding upgrades that enable them to attack too late in the game for them to be of any use. Shanate my actually have too many attacks, spells and abilities, most of which can't match her standard hair attack. And by the end of the game, I was stuffed with so many healing items and restorative abilities, I could brute-force my way through anything.None of these issues make me regret Kickstarting this game. The greatest testement to its quality, is the longing I felt to play more games like it, and seeing nothing in my steam library that match it.If you enjoy platformers, quality indie titles, metroid-vania, or just want a enjoyable tale about a beautiful and witty Half-Genie, Buy This Game!*Note: Was a backer on the Shantae: Half-Genie Hero Kickstarter.

Posted: December 27, 2016
												Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is Shantae's newest game, Kickstarted by the fans. Updated for the modern age and brought to Steam, the game is in full color (big shock) with a wonderful "indie" feel. Is it any good? Let's find out!Story: 7/10(Quirky and fun, but awkward pacing)Shantae's story in this game is fairly straightforward. It's definitely an indie-written story, but it wears that designation on its sleeve. The story itself is like the game: Quirky and fun. However, its pacing is somewhat awkward. It's not bad, but it seems to have some sections that drag on from a lack of direction (Thankfully, "Bathroom Angel" can fix that somewhat) and some that blow by.There's also some funny references and 4th-wall-breaking. The writing itself is fantastic, giving everyone personality and charm. I just wish the story itself was paced a little better and the initial directions you're given at the start of each quest were clearer, but nothing in the story has made me consult a walkthrough yet.Characters: 10/10 (YESYESYESYESYESYESYES)OK, I have to gush about the writing for the characters. There is so much charm and personality to the characters, ESPECIALLY Shantae. Shantae is a mixture of a straight-woman to the weirdness, a generic hero-type (played with), an airhead (without being a motor-mouth), and a bit of thickness. (She's not dense by any means, she seems pretty smart, just naive.) I like all of the characters and their dialogue is all great.Gameplay: 8/10 (Well-refined platformer with a bit of side-scrolling brawler)Shantae is evocative of the old-school Nintendo platformers, including some Metroidvania elements. You jump around like a maniac looking for platforms, look for every tiny hint to a secret/easter egg/new power-up, and some Castlevania-like brawling.Shantae's also bringing some tricks to help make platforming better and uncover more secrets. She can use her Belly Dance (which has an adorable animation) to transform into different Forms, each with their own unique traits, jump height, attacks (or lack thereof), and special abilities. Most Forms have an upgrade to unlock a new attack, which is, unfortunately, not that interesting. (Mermaid Form gets a bubble, Crab Form gets a quick snap that clips through seaweed, Mouse Form gets a spammable-low-damage bite, and so on.)The platforming itself is highly refined, practically to a science. The controls are tight and intuitive, Shantae's movement and jumping is consistent and controllable (You can adjust and correct your jumps mid-air, thankfully), and it's usually clear what you can and can't jump on. My only real complaint lies with a couple of her Forms, mainly with Harpy Form, where the controls become extremely floaty and nigh-controllable. Sometimes, the hitboxes can be a little iffy, especially with Mermaid Form where I've taken damage while close to (but not touching) an enemy that only damages you by touch because my TAIL got near it.The brawling is very simple: One button makes Shantae slap a short distance in front of her (your generic Hair-Whip Attack) and another uses your Magic. It's very simple one-button combat (technically, two-button, but w/e) and works well.I think my current major complaint with the gameplay is just the insane amount of backtracking you have to do. This isn't anything new if you've played a Metroidvania-style platformer in the past 10-15 years, but it really drives the pacing into the ground sometimes as you run from place to place, running the same levels at least 2 extra times each just praying you'll see the one thing different you can do with a new Form or upgrade. Granted, I'm not huge into Metroidvania, so take this with a massive grain of salt.One more minor complaint I have to get off my chest is the inventory. There's no quick-use keys, so if you want to use something, you have to go into the Inventory screen, select it, and Use it. This is a very minor complaint, considering this actually HELPS, since the Inventory screen pauses the game and can let you get your bearings.Music: 9/10 (Amazing Soundtrack)The music in this game is fantastic. It has that indie quirkyness to it without being grating. My only real complaint is that the music can get a LITTLE repetitive due to the Metroidvania nature of the game, forcing you to backtrack a ton and hear each track plenty of times.Art Style: 10/10 (Awesome, A Visual Treat)The art style in this game is absolutely awesome. It's 2.5D (meaning, gameplay on a 2D plane, but 3D models) with a very anime-esque style. In fact, this whole game looks like a playable anime. Everything has this cute-quirky style to it and just drips with personality. It's an absolute treat to look at, combining an old-school 2D game with a 3D art style flawlessly.Any the animations are just...AAAAAAAAAAA I LOVE THEM! Everything has this bouncy energy that brings the game to life. Shantae's idle animations are fun to watch, her Belly Dance is playful, just everything is beautifully animated.Conclusion: 9/10 (Fantastic)Simply put, Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is a fantastic game. I'm rarely a fan of platformers, but Shantae has me absolutely entranced. I can't stop smiling at this game. Its fun old-school gameplay, energy-filled art and animations, just everything about the game oozes charm and personality. This was clearly made by developers who love their craft and wanted this game to be fantastic. While I haven't played any of the previous Shantae games (Nothing against them, just wasn't interested), this game seems to fit perfectly with the rest of them, but with some excellent modernization.It's an absolute STEAL at $20. I can't wait to see how the developers will follow up to this fantastic platformer.Maybe a Squid Baron standalone with $0.99 Shantae DLC is in order too. ;)

Posted: December 29, 2016
												Half-Genie Hero is my first venture into the Shantae series, and it is always kinda difficult to review a game in an objective way if said game is part of an established franchise. I went out of my way to look at other people's opinions on the game and reviews of the previous titles in the series, as well as look over the wiki a few times, all just to make sure I knew what exactly what I was talking about. Without further ado, here's my review (oh hey it rhymes !)Half-Genie Hero is fun, really, really fun. The gameplay is just great, with super smooth controls, rapid transformations that open up new paths, magic powers to use and abuse, and despite the level design being on the weaker side, levels are a joy to play over and over again, collecting all the things you can find, and speedrunning is just the icing on the cake. It is a shame the levels are completely disconnected from the main hub, it makes the world feel rather disjointed. A shame for an entry in a series that is usually praised as a good example of Metroidvania (and god knows I'm a sukker for Metroidvanias).Graphically, the game is gorgeous, pure eye candy (and i'm not saying that for all the lovely Jigglypuffs, IYKWIM). The lovely art direction is only an added bonus on top of some of the smoothest animations I've seen in my life. Every level is a joy to explore thanks to the clever mix of 2D and 3D. It's just a shame that most of them are rather generic, with a port, a jungle with waterfalls, a desert, a volcano...the real standout level was the magic carpet ride, which isn't something you see everyday.Musically, it's also great, with many catchy tracks that don't feel the need to venture into 8/16 bit territory to be good. Jake Kaufman's the man when it comes to making great music, and I'm happy to say he delivered big time with his work on Half-Genie hero. The mermaid factory theme has to be my personal favorite, along with the boss fight theme. Sound design is also neat, it's very satisfying to fight enemies and hear them burn or get crushed.The story is pretty weak, however. It's kind of all over the place, with mini-plots that don't go anywhere, and no real big narrative to string it all together. Characters get introduced only to be ignored or forgotten, and it doesn't make a strong impression. For what it's worth, the writing is funny and the interactions between characters are great, and the whole thing can be ignored, but it's a shame that a game like this couldn't give its story more attention. It's all over pretty quickly, as is tradition with games designed with speedrunning in mind. Overall, I'd definitely recommend this game, even if you're not a fan of the series like me before playing it. I'm going to give Pirate's Curse a look one of these days, and I'm definitely looking forward to the extra content coming to HGH in the future.

Posted: December 27, 2016
												A wonderful game! A very fun platformer with wonderful characters and humor and levels that I gladly replay again. As someone who hasn't played any of the previous titles I could still very easily follow what this game was about. I really love it!

Posted: December 21, 2016
												This short review is based on the first 3 hours of gameplay.Having played Risky's Revenge and Pirate's Curse (both on PC and Wii U) I can say that this game is just as good. Of course, there's some differences, and to some the transformation mechanics can seem gimmicky, but the game redeems itself with OUTSTANDING art and music. Like litterely I was blown away by both of them. And the humor is still present, same ol' characters, same ol' thing. But it doesn't make it a bad game at all. For only 20 bucks, I think it's a well invested 20 bucks. I wouldn't buy it for 30, but I think 20 is a fair price for such a high quality game in the end. I don't know exactly what is its length, since I haven't finished it. But for achievement hunters and collectible OCD people, it fits right in.tl;dr? It's amazing and worth its price so far. If you liked the other Shantae games, chances are you will like this one just as much.

Posted: December 28, 2016
												Colorful game with plenty of eye candy and moderate "lol" inducing dialogue. Gameplay is pretty Metroidvania, you will be revisiting previous levels to grab tons of items but it's not a big hassle with the transform system and warp dance to move through the level without having to go through absolutely everything. Even if you haven't played the previous game, Shantae and the Pirate's Curse, I feel as if the story and characters would still be easily digestable for a new person to follow. The music and colors are great, you can even play on keyboard instead of a controller and if you set up your keys just right you can play one handed. The only two issues I had with this game are that if you run at a 144hz monitor you have to turn down the refresh rate to 60 or the game will only run at 33 fps, and I feel as if the game was a little bit too short. I would've liked maybe 1 or 2 more full levels before beating the end. Other than that, I give it a 9/10.

Posted: December 25, 2016
												This is a fun little metroidvania-type title. It's not an especially long or difficult game, but the different abilities are cool and add new dimensions to traversing the levels (except Spider. I like the design but I'm not really sure how useful it is outside of one instance where it's necessary). I also like that it's fairly short because it makes backtracking to use those new abilities much less tedious than it could otherwise have been.It controls well, the art direction is charming, and the songs are all nice. The voice acting is good although there isn't much of it, which is fine; it's not something I need in every game and I would have been fine without it. I also like the fact that you can 'adjust' the difficulty in-game by turning on or off your different power-ups; for example, something you can unlock later is unlimited magic as well as an invicibility spell which can make the last few bosses rather trivial, but if you feel like challenging yourself or 'doing it right' you can just turn off the relic and activate one of the lesser forms of the spell.In short, I recommend it.

Posted: December 28, 2016
												Great platformer with awesome music. The high resolution graphics are also a nice change from all the retro pixel platformers these days.You basically run around whipping things with your hair, defeating bosses, and collecting transformations. The transformations let you access hidden areas and collect all the secrets in the game. Getting 100% isn't super difficult and the basic gameplay is fun enough for some replay.The only piece that doesn't really seem fleshed out is the magic abilities. It's much more effective to just whip everything with your hair. There's only a handful of occasions where magic is useful and it's usually just for slightly more damage output.

Posted: December 28, 2016
												Although I did not play the previous Shantae game series before, but I'd still give a thumbs up to this one. This map designs itself has really good view, like in 3D viewing. Shantae's dance transformations allow players to re-explore the stage to collect hidden items, even the purpose is to achieve 100% game completion. What makes the transformations interesting is that players are able to explore certain areas even deeper, including hidden puzzles in certain areas. As a beginner for playing the game, transformations are what increases the player's desire to explore even further. Although there are unreachable areas that requires certain transformations to reach, that doesn't mean it's impossible to progress further.The dialogues before every boss fight (probably except Risky Boots), makes me think that there are some hidden references. That makes the game more entertain, instead of fully focusing on main objectives and beating bosses without hilarious jokes. Moreover, the game is really amazing. Recommend you guys should give it a shot.

Posted: January 2
												To all the backers of Shantae: Half-Genie Hero, thank you for all of your support! I would have happily joined you had I known how awesome the Shantae series was, but I came late into the game, and it was only shortly after the campaign ended did I take the time to enjoy Risky's Revenge and The Pirate Curse. Playing those two games, I've come to expect a lot from this series in terms of its artstyle, soundtrack, and gameplay. Needless to say, this game has exceeded some of my expectations while underwhelming others.The ArtsyleRight away you can tell this game is beautifully drawn and the characters are well animated. The colours, the movement, and even the backgrounds are vibrant and beaming of life. I don't usually pay attention to backgrounds, but I can see how much time and attention has gone into them along with the smooth character animations.The SoundtrackAlthough most of the music is rearranged and redone, the Shantae soundtrack continues to match the levels and the dialogue moods perfectly. None of the new music really stands out as super catchy and memorable, but when they are used for specific moments and levels, it composed well enough to immerse you into the situation.The GameplayAs much as I love the aesthetics for this game, I feel like the gameplay has taken a stepback. A lot of long times fans come to expect a more Metroidvania kind of structure to the levels and worlds, and for me this more level select method is a better for backtracking. There were times in previous games where I just got lost easily and felt like some stages lost their importance after a while.Thankfully the levels are all simply structured to have three stages each, along with a few obstacles you can't get past until you earn an animal transformation. I can see they wanted to focus on the use of them along with making the game more accessible to newcomers.So while the puzzles and extra sections are a ton of fun to figure out in terms of using the right transformations and abilities, I feel like the selection of transformations was overwhelming. There were too many transformations that could have been consolidated into less animals with more abilities as opposed to one animal with one unique ability each. I get excited learning a new ability and this game didn't seem to reward my experience as much as I'd like because you barely ever get to use your new abilities that often except for maybe one or two situations that call for them.Final ThoughtsAll in all though, I still had a ton of fun with this beautifully designed platformer. I patiently wait for the DLC that is already available for backers *shakes fist* and look forward to more of what WayForward can come up with in the future. I give this game a solid 7/10. The art, music, and levels are well crafted. Learning and using new abilities felt underwhelming when they were horribly underused, but the game makes up for some of these flaws for having a decent level of difficulty in puzzle solving and its exciting boss battles.On top of all that, I know that Shantae stories are usually meant to be light hearted and on the Saturday Morning cartoon side, I still can't help but feel like there could have been more to it than what was presented. There were moments where the story could have had some strong themes elaborated on. I was severely disappointed that the evil Shantae section was over as soon as it started. Maybe a level being inside Shantae's heart or something would have been nice. Like a good challenge to rid the evil that she's been inflicted with, instead of just having all these characters monologue at her saying how much they care for her. That would have been better if it was a reward to a one time level in the game.But I digress. Gameplay is king in Shantae games and having the story skimped out on is not a huge loss since they're not usually known for their stories alone. All in all a fun and exciting game that is good for its length and what it offers. Replayability is debatable and more geared towards a speed run, but we shall see what gets add for DLC later on!

Posted: January 6
												It's been a while since I played a platformer worth it's salt.  Thankfully, I decided to purchase Shantae: Half-Genie Hero entirely on a whim.  I hadn't heard about the kickstarter otherwise there's a strong chance I would have backed it.  I've since rectified that mistake and bought the game when Steam suggested it to me.Shantae is a game with great artwork, and incredibly catchy sound track, and a plethora of unlocks to get you through your quest.  The levels are designed incredibly well which is great since you'll be revisting them multiple times to get any new items you can find as the game progresses.  Bosses are humorous, animated well, and sometimes challenging.  Shantae isn't without it's flaws, though those are incredibly minor.  Really.  While the next bit sounds like a lot, I'm being incredibly nit-picky.  A few animation glitches occur during the opening sequence when Shantae first gets out of bed and in the mid-level save sequence.  Jumping can be a bit stiff but if you've played enough platforming games, you can quickly adapt.  One of the coolest parts of Shantae is also one of the most disappointing parts.  On your first go around in a level, you'll see many details that bring the stage to life.  These are usually tied to the story of the level and once you clear it, they go away.  Future vists see the level altered slightly to reflect what you've already accomplished.  For example, in the second level, a number of fair maidens are being carted away in a factory.  Once the issue is resolved, the women are obviously gone seeing how you saved them, but it kind of ruins the atmosphere a little.Again, nitpicking and critiqueing classical art.  Shantae is worth a playthrough.  It's a tad on the short end but don't let that detract from the quality of the game you get.  TL:DR If you're stillâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥at Mighty No. 9 and need a platformer to scratch the itch that disaster promised, then Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is here to fix you right up.

Posted: December 29, 2016
												Pretty faithful continuation of the shantae series.PROS:- Solid animation (some of the cleanest i've seen from 2D)- Tight controls (complete remapping options if you need it)- Dat soundtrack (probably the best in the series yet)- Good level design (for the most part)CONS:- So short (8 hours to 100%)- Open world is gone (style changed from metroidvania to megaman)- Character models cartoony (personal gripe but I liked the pirate's curse art better)- Too many fetch quests (exploration is more forced than encouraged)- Excessive level revisits (for all those fetch quests)- Extremely easy (didnt even know what the death animation was till after I beat the game)- Magic is useless (except for the invincible bubble, which breaks the game)- Too many forms (only a few are really useful while the others fill scarce niches)Wayforward has stated that additional characters will be available later on and hopefully it will help the game retain its value. Its a very fun and upbeat game to play regardless, it just ends too fast to enjoy to the fullest. Wait until more characters come out to buy it.

Posted: January 15
												I absolutely adore this game! The aesthetic is gorgeous, colorful and vibrant, with a range of interesting and distinctive locales. The character designs are absolutely top notch and a treat for the eyes, whether they be cute, sexy or both, not to mention that they are animated so fluidly and gracefully. Truly a triumph!The story, while simple and following the usual tropes of platformers, did through me for a loop and there were genuine surprises and unexpected turns. Even then, the formula is not so much that this game is unoriginal in its approach and more about not fixing what isn't broken.This game is such a treat to play. It controls well, and the unique mechanics such as the dancing to change to different character modes to the use of magic abilities was intuitive and easy to grasp while providing a surprising amount of depth, offering multiple avenues to approach the game. Not to mention the difficulty. True, it isn't Nintendo hard, but it is certainly challenging without being frustrating, for all players of all skill levels.An absolute triumph. I recommend this game to anyone with even a passing interest in 2D platformers.

Posted: January 17
												Having played and beaten every other game in the series, I was very hesitant at Half Genie Hero at first. After completing the first two levels, you see the roots of the game unfurl once again. Half Genie Hero holds true to its exploration heavy expectations in addition to distinguishing itself. That's everything you could ask for in a sequel really! My only complaints about the game is how horrendously easy and exploitable it is. Two hours in I found an exploit for infinite currency. Aside from that, there are items in the game that make your effective health absolutely unbelievable. Not to mention, magic can make boss fights far too easy, and when coupled with insane health, literally a joke. This shouldn't talk you out of the game though, I still had a great time even if everything was easy.Pros:-Beautiful design-Great soundtrack-Easy gameplay-A story far better than Pirate's Curse-Humor-Exploration is excellentCons:-Minor bugs, nothing you'd care about really.-Easy and exploitable. All in all, I believe this game should be in everybody's library. 9/10

Posted: January 17
												I played this game directly after playing Shantae and The Pirates Curse, which I absolutly Reccomend. Honestly, Half-Genie Hero, while visually pleasing and mechanically sound, is not at good. Don't get me wrong, still a good game that I feel is worth the price tag. It is simply that the game did not do what The Pirates Curse did for me. One of my favorite things is that even the hardest levels of the game aren't too frustrating and I found myself wanting to complete the level no matter what. However, my main issue with the game is level design. There are 2-3 levels set up around the idea of you dying a handful of times before you learn the 'pattern' and make it to the goal. Unlike Pirates Curse, where the game would introduce you to new things individually before forcing you to deal with combinations, they made sure you had an idea of what you might be facing and then if you died, it was your fault because you didn't handle a puzzle or scenario correctly. This game makes the mistake of just throwing things at you and forcing you to find the best way while dying several times to do so. The other issue I have with level design is that the game has several animal forms that are essentally the same form just one of them is superior and the other one is required for one or two puzzles. For example, there are two water forms, one is large and lets you swim in any direction, the other is small and lets you walk under water. It can be said, oh you need the small form to get through the blocks of seaweed, but the large form gets an ability that lets it break through large blocks of stone, so the same puzzles for the small form could have been scaled to allow the large form in with the block breaking ability. Similarly you get two flying abilities, one that lets you fly left to right, and one that lets you fly freely, the left to right one also gets another ability that is only usefully for a single puzzle and most of the left to right flying power's puzzles could have been solved by the free flying one if they had simply changed the distance of spike walls or removed one entirely, the left to right form cannot go up or down, so you simply transform on a platform and float lazily left or right. My final two issues are with post game events. During the entire game you can travel back to each location with the boss fights and some hazards removed, ie. sand storms. Yet for some reason they give the option to start a new playthrough with all of the main transformations already unlocked, it seems pointless seeing as aside from the end game boss all the bosses were beaten without using transformations. The final issue is simply a continuity problem in my opinion that involves spoilers, but as you can guess from the title, Pirate's Curse, the previous game was about Shantae and Risky Boots.****Spoilers Below****At the end of Pirate's Curse they show not only does Risky Boots reguard Shantae as some semblance of a friend, but she is extremely smart and was able to plan the entire adventure ahead insuring Shantae's Victory. So why in this game is she so dumb she not only drops a map to her hide out, but several articles of clothing around town? The other issue is that at the end of Pirate's Curse the two part ways, Shantae returning to being the Guardian Genie and Risky saying she must forge her own path, as she cannot become a 'goody two shoes' like Shantae, they part with a seeminly mutual understanding and a few nice words that make Risky seem like she actually has grown to like Shantae as the adventure came to a conclusion. So why would Risky just leave a Shantae after she converts her magic to dark magic, wouldn't she want to take her friend with her? Which reminds me, when Shantae is converted to evil nothing happens, literally each of her friends says, hey snap out of it, and she does. It's very anticlimatic and it feels like a small mini-boss fight is missing.If you actually read to the end, I'm amazed I know I went off on a tangent, but over all the game is good and a worth while buy, it just doesn't stack up to the standard that the previous game set for me.

Posted: December 22, 2016
												*NOTE: I WAS A BACKER FOR THIS GAME'S KICKSTARTER*I'm not gonna go too deep into this game because it's pretty obvious as to what it is by looking at it but I can say it is an excellent platformer from WayForward that has some metroidvania elements. The game is hud based, and you can revisit previous levels in order to collect items needed to progress. So, what you are looking at is a game that's part traditional run left to right platformer, and part collectathon. You will get various powers and upgrades as you progress through the game not unlike a Metroid or Castlevania title. You'll have a scene with characters in a hub town, go to a level and make it through, then likely have to find something you couldnt get before to progress to the next level by revisiting previous levels. The good news is that you won't be playing the exact same things over again as levels do have some changes as you go through them again but it's mostly the same. If I have any major negatives it may be the nature of having to revist old levels over again though it didn't bother me too much, and that it's fairly short, taking about 7 hours for me on my first run to collect everything and beat the game.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												Whether it be a reboot, soft reboot, sequel or soft robot rabbit, Shantae is back in town.  Everything is familiar for fans of the series, maybe a little too much so in some respects, and if you're unfamiliar to the series and looking for a light metroidvania-esque platforming game that isn't too hard, you'll enjoy this.The world is bright and colourful and the 3d background visuals are a pleasant departure from the standard 2d pixel art.  The soundtrack is pretty solid, as usual for the series.  Controls are mostly smooth, some jumps didn't feel quite as responsive as I'd like but good on the whole.  Though, Relic usage for animal transformations could be more seamless in game. On the topic of Relics, there are far too many transformations and not enough puzzles using them.  A few of the transformation upgrades only get used once or not at all.  There may have been plans to use these upgrades that never made it into the game, but it still feels like there's unnecessary clutter and it's disappointing to have useless abilities.  A lot of the magic you can buy from the store also isn't as useful as in past series.Plotline is disappointing.  Just... disappointing.  It's like the events of the previous game were completely forgotten.  Whilst I do enjoy seeing familiar faces like Sky, Bolo, Rotty and Mimic again, too many of the minor antagonists were reused from previous games in shallow ways and the culmination of the plot just felt very half-baked.  That being said, there is some witty banter and some enjoyable dialogue.  And some nice 'plot' as usual.The level design is decent and there are some interesting concepts and designs, though the execution isn't entirely there.  Bosses... eh.  I think the game misses not having any dungeons whatsoever, though, and the difficulty curve is pretty nonexistent.  I've no major issue with the backtracking elements to the game, but I do think that the game spoonfeeds a little too much with regards to some of the hidden items.  The hinting system is pretty inelegant as well.  Overall, enjoyable.  Bit of a step back from Pirate's Curse - WayForward may not be living up to their name - but a nice few hours romping around anyway.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
Full Disclosure: I'm a Kickstarter backer and am a big fan of the Shantae series.There's three things Wayforward excells at in each Shantae game. Animation, Music, and Writing.Animation: It's literally the best i've seen throughout the games yet, i'm not only gushing over the transition into 2.5D but am also liking the cartoonish character portraits.  The small image bobs gives a sense of liveliness and brings across the way each character is feeling quite adequately.  It's her first HD adventure and and HGH (Half-Genie Hero) fully captures the visual look of a Shantae game.Music: Jake Kaufman (who has composed each Shantae soundtrack) is the "Audio guy" yet again and has done yet another great job.  You can listen to remixes of older Shantae music and fully original tracks as well, my favorites being the title screen music and Neo Burning Town.Writing: Wayforward yet again gives you their classic tongue-and-cheek style of writing so you can enjoy both the plot and all of the silly jokes that go along with it with one of my favorite quotes being: "Blast it All. That airship cost billions of crowd-funded dollars!"GripesThe major gripe I have with the game currently is the content, it's somewhat of a short game and you'll find yourself finishing it with 100% in about 6-9 hours, Risky's Revenge is a shorter game but the story for HGH leaves more to be desired with the only other option available being the speedrun achievements).  Also two of the transformations only really have one-time uses and are under-powered in comparison to the others.  Granted the other transformations are very useful and gives shantae both tools for tackling a stage and a different means of attacking various enemies.However, they plan on adding THREE seperate playable costumes for Shantae (similar to the Dancer costume in Risky's Revenge) and plan on adding FOUR additional campaigns for Risky Boots, Rottytops, Bolo, and Sky which should solve the game's launch-date content issue.If you want to get a full-enjoyment out of HGH, I recommend you play through Risky's Revenge and Pirates Curse beforehand since it'll increase your enjoyment for HGH.  Regardless, this is a good starting point if you're thinking about getting into the series since it does a good job capturing the feel and gameplay of a Shantae game.I hope you enjoy!  I sure did!!

number of helpful: 38 of 75 people (51%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 8
												That game is disappointing gameplay wise. While the universe is brillant, the characters are adorable, the music is great and the controls are close from being perfect, the game requires you to do an incredible amount of backtracking.With only 6 levels, you are required to go back in those levels sometimes more than 5 times just to get what's remaining after you got a new power and progress in the story. The game manages to make that backtracking way less painful with a few mechanics (like that power that allows you to skip a part of a level). You may even say that the backtracking is overall brillantly implemented since everytime you have to go back you would be able to do it way faster than before thanks to your new power. But backtracking faster is still backtracking, even if the develloppers' ideas to make that backtracking not painful were good. In the end, after finishing the game for the first time, I'm not really satisfied and I don't really want to try the new game +.The game is also fairly short. Count around 6 hours to finish it. Maybe a bit more if like me you got stuck somewhere at one point. The fact that the game is short makes all that backtracking even more frustrating and give the feel that all of this is just made to give the feel that the game is longer than it looks. On the other hand, if you're a speedrunner, be aware that Shantae Half-Genie Hero is pretty much tailor made for it.I can't really recommand that game at full price.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2016
But wait! There's more!So this is the fourth game in the series, crowd-funded, and pure HD.There's something i have to say first, and it's that the game isn't yet fully finished. We're getting some DLC.I sorta find it a bit weird and expensive, but it'll probably get more value as the DLCs release.If you want reference for how good or bad the series is as a whole, it's good, read my other reviews of the previous 2 games:http://steamcommunity.com/id/garketmardener/recommended/277890/Ëshantae_relaxËShantae: Risky's Revengehttp://steamcommunity.com/id/garketmardener/recommended/345820/Ëshantae_relaxËShantae & the Pirate's Curse This time around, they went for a more visually stunning but shorter game, to be expanded with lots of replay value thanks to the upcoming DLCs.So right now it has the same problem as Switch Force: It's cool, and fun, it's pretty in graphics, but once you've done the 2 modes you're basically done with it. Wait for DLCs.As it is, and considering how the game's supposed to be expanded, it's good, it's really great. Most importantly, the graphics are really well done and don't even get close to straying off of the style the game usually goes for: Toonish, charming, colorful, vivid, and with noticeable details and tweaks. I believe it's the first time WayForwad does 3d models on one of their IPs, and they did it great for a first time. Characters are still well-put sprites in a 3d-2d parallax world. Really comes together as a modernized classic way of doing things.60FPS engine, but animations aren't all 60fps. It still looks consistant and doesn't really bother. Also, yes, it comes with chest jigglies. As it's obvious. I mean, WayForward? Fanservice? Isn't that the same thing? /jokeThis however doesn't stop the game from being fun and really great. As always, the prime 3 aspects i like about this company are on point: Decent difficulty (questionable here but whatever) and fun gameplay, great artstyle and personality, absolutely rocking synth muslc from Jake Kaufman AKA Virt. Album is out on bandcamp now btwgame's a bit short, you can get 100% in the base game mode in 5-6 hours approx, considering how the other games took up to 8 hours for that (all of those are player-dependant times, might take longer if you're not familiar with the games or genre).The game's very iconic and takes everything positive from the other games, such as returning gags, levels, enemies, bosses, transforms and abilities, while still refreshing everything really well.On the minus side, because of how short the game is, some features fell under the "situationally helpful" cape of negligence, but at least they get used once. There are a few annoying mechanics that were uncalled for, overall for the very stupidly placed pauses inbetween the action (Why is the level start Ready! screen a thing, and why can't you move while it's playing?), but for the most part it still is a great game.Buyer's advice: Play the other games before. Some of the content might go unappreciated if you haven't played the other games, or just watched a full gameplay. Any works. But still, playing is much more fun than watching, at least for me.Overall, i give it a [8.5-->10]/10 depending on how well executed the DLCs and extra modes come along.

content:
Posted: January 12
												Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is my favorite game developed by WayForward, and that's saying a lot. Other games developed by WF include DuckTales Remastered, Mighty Switch Force, LIT, Cat Girl Without Salad, and all of the other Shantae games. First of all, I have to praise the game composer god, Jake "Virt" Kaufman. This OST is absolutely fantastic. It could be better than Pirate's Curse's OST. The gameplay is very similar to the other Shantae games (and other Metroidvanias), but it's semi-level based and there are no dungeons. This may turn off some, but it's not that big of a problem. The graphics are similar to DuckTales Remastered, probably because they run on the same engine. The art style takes on more of a western approach than Risky's Revenge and Pirate's Curse. I like it, though.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												Coming totally fresh into the series I have to say I enjoyed what I played. It's definitely not an amazing game, by any means, but it's good throughout, despite some issues.This is a 2-D platformer that succeeds in bringing in some Metroidvania elements, to a certain extent.Pros:- Self-aware humor.- Good level design.- Colorful graphics and vivid animations.- Lots of power-ups and transformations to play with.- Soundtrack is catchy and memorable (for the most part).- Doesn't overstay its welcome (around 7-7:30 hours, which is perfect for this type of game).Cons:- No map to see which places you've already explored in a specific level.- Way too much backtracking.- Obscure objectives.- Some transformations are redundant, serving purpose for only few specific locations.- Last stage has a rather big difficulty spike with poor checkpoint placement.- Last boss fight is painfully slow and annoying,Overall, the game is bigger than the sum of its parts. I did enjoy it and I would recommend it to anyone looking for a good platformer with some solid exploration elements.It's a shame the last stage and boss weren't so good as it left me with a bitter taste, though.7/10

content:
Posted: January 9
												This is for me a difficult game to review â this was the first game I ever kickstarted back in the misty past of 2013, and I never believed for a moment that a 2D platformer would take three and a half years to materialise. With such a long time in development, backersâ expectations were high â Wayforward have a pedigree, and Iâve enjoyed every game theyâve ever produced. The Shantae games in particular are blessed with excellent production values, level design and waifus that are frankly off the hook.Itâs clear to me that those years in development were not spent productively. I completed the game with 100% items in under six hours, and Iâm fairly certain that it could easily be completed in half that. Of course length is not necessarily an indication of quality, as ur mum will attest â but the levels here are short and linear, so much so that there is no map screen. Some levels donât even feel finished, and considering the small number of them and the extensive development time thatâs prettyâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥poor. Most of the levels need to be revisited to find items crucial for advancing the story, which is a transparent way of lengthening the dismal play time. Backtracking is of course a metroidvania staple, but here it feels forced and unnecessary.In terms of abilities, transformations are back after an absence in Pirateâs Curse. There are certainly a wealth of transformations compared to previous games (each beautifully rendered and animated), but some of them barely have anything to do, and thereâs a surprising degree of redundancy. The level design also feels very flabby and under baked â certain abilities borderline break the game at the point they can be acquired, like the bat that allows you to pretty much skip half the desert level.Outside of the amazing visuals and music (and they really are best in class), Half Genie Hero is entirely inferior to Pirateâs Curse, and if Iâm being honest it doesnât even hold up particularly favourably to Riskyâs Revenge. Looking at Half Genie Hero in a vacuum, itâs a fun little platformer, and I canât deny I enjoyed my (short) time with it - however, compared to both its immediate predecessor and the stiff competition in the metroidvania market on Steam, it just isnât worth the fifteen quid.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												SPOILERS ALERTLike almost everyone here, I was eagerly waiting for the release of this game.I played every Shantae game in the series and and had many expectations for this last one,I was drooling when reading goals on Kikcstarter achieved one by one and naturally an ideal game picture wasdrawn in my head, a picture of a game that at least does not give in to it's previous incarnation, the brilliant Shantae and the Pirate's Curse. A game with the budget of almost 800,000 USD. I have never been so wrong... GraphicsFrom the very first time I played Shantae, I loved the concept and dreamed it to become an HD.Partially my wishes became true in RR and PC but that only involved sprites, not the actual universe.I like the graphics in HGH, it looks refreshing, though somewhat lacking in magic previous games had.I especially like the the job devs did on some of the Shantae's forms such as Mermaid and Spider, they look adorable. Some of my complaints lie in character animations, they are almost noexistent. Whatever happens during a dialogue, Sky is smiling happily, Risky dances, Bolo remains pokerface etc. It especially strikes your eye during a scene when Shantae turns dark and they come for help. I don't think it is a very difficult job to change a facial expression since it's HD and it would contribute greatly to a scenes' emotional impact. Music Music is wonderful. Kaufman knows his job well. Plot This is what actually disappoints me and what makes me give the game a thumb down.During the whole course of the game an impression stuck with me that devs had some great ideas which they failed (or didn't want) to implement for some reason. The plot seems rushed, teared and incompleted. No character development at all.New charactes appear to be tossed away right after their debut. Main Shantae friends could have more impact on the story. I'll give an example.- In the very first stage - mermaid falls, Bolo catches up to Shantae and complains he is always left out of her adventures.It was a great reference to the previous game but unfortunately it didn't go anywhere.There is a couple of funny moments with him in this episode, but after that he doesn't play any significant role at all.- The same thing with Rotty, I have an impression the devs had no idea how to insert her into the plot and just got away by giving her some nominal role. Abner and Poe are introduced and forgotten.- An episode with Shantae taken over by dark magic just cried for a fight with her dark self or an extra level "inside her",don't get me wrong, the thing her friends coming to her rescue is great but still a lot of potential is lost.- The new "villain" Holly was downright pathetic. Her reasons ridiculous, dialogues far-fetched, character - bad guy cliche. It was a real challenge to beat the boss with a palm on my face. - Moreover I was negatively suprised when I discovered it was actually a "bonus chapter" (along with the cape crustacean) inserted in the story because the kickstarter goal was achieved. Would would be left of the game without those? Bonus chapter should be BONUS and usually after you BEAT the game or can be completed optionally, but here it is an integral part of the story. I don't oppose this approach, just don't call it BONUS. Call it: "Initially we planned to make the game 4 hours long, but since you funded it we will make it 8".- The game has two endings and they differ by a couple of lines. If the whole genie realm was destoyed, Shantae will say something like: "Well, that's a bummer." and Mimic like: "Well, maybe it wasn't". Yes, I know it is a kind fairy-tale and there is no place for heavy dramatic moments but this very ending should motivate a player to search for a better one, but it doesn't.DifficultyToo casual. It does give you some challenge in the beginning, but once you have a bikini and 4+ hearts you dont really care to avoid attacks at all. Some people complained the last boss to be very difficult, but when you have invincibility magic what difficulty are you talking about??? I really like easy games, when I don't have to smash break the gamepad and just enjoy the gameplay, but there must be balance between difficulty and enjoyability, which this game definitely lacks.Conclusion.I, as a fan of the series, am very disillusioned because the potential the series had was destroyed by this game.Maybe the DLCs will brighten things up a bit but we'll have to pay for them which highlights the desire to only earn money, not caring much about their product. I'll repeat myself, as I was going through the game it seemed to me the devs had great ideas but right after the beginning they decided to save budget, which I don't understand. They raised twice they pledged + income from release, did they only care to make it "ok" but not "great"? Well, it was just my personal opinion, there are tons of positive reviews, so I probably just dramatized a lot.Agree or not? Comments are welcome.

Posted: February 26
												Once again WayForward have delivered a wonderful adventure. Though different in structure, Half-Genie Hero retains its predecessors' exploration-heavy gameplay, encouraging players to revisit and eke out every secret from its varied levels. The move to hand-drawn HD visuals worried me at first glance, but in motion it's utterly charming and the attention to detail is excellent. Music maintains the very high standard of the series, and our lovable cast of heroes and rogues drive the lighthearted story full steam ahead.Though not a challenging game by any means, Half-Genie Hero keeps the player on their toes with its abundance of secrets and a dash of precision platforming. The highest recommendation.

Product received for free
												I've seen Shantae and the Pirate's Curse a couple of years ago and I thought "that's a pretty sweet game". Then I heard about WayForward making a new Shantae game. That got me excited about how would this new release would be.I got Shantae Half-Genie Hero as a friend's christmas gift, and needless to say I was really really happy. Not only because I got a gift from a friend, but also because I was really into getting this game. That turn out to be the best gift I received in years!The HD Graphics are amazing! Never thought an 2D platformer could look so good and so fluid (even for my not-suited for game laptop). Which just makes me wonder how much better it would be if I had a better pc.The story is quite interesting, with lots of puns, gags, 4th wall breaking, etc. Never taking away the immersion of the player from the game.Gameplay, which is the most important (imo) is as fluid as the graphics and animations. The challenge of the game is not too simple, not too difficult, it's just right for a non-hardcore platformer. The teleport mechanics are SO SO handy, since there's a lot of sidetracking to do, which could've make the game a bit tiresome without it. So useful.My only complaining (if so), would be that the game seems a bit too short. Which is way Im quite anxious for the DLC.In resume, probably one of my favorite games in my steam library (if not my favorite). So worth it, So recommend it.

												Pros:+Same characters, same world, but in beautiful 2.5D+â¥â¥â¥â¥ing AMAZING music, Jake Kaufman does it again.+Really great level design+Transformations are really fun+Monster girlsNeutral:*It's definitely way easier than before (I put this as neutral because some people might want this) but I thought that it was a little saddening that there was a significant decrease in difficutlyCons:-It's a little short (I 100% it in 5 hours, less than half that what it took me in Pirate's Curse)-Continuation of above: The levels are way smaller than in previous games. While the individual areas are bigger so there's less loading between screens there's less going on in each level.-Some of the Transformations are poorly utliziedI'd also like to add that the "true ending" you get by collecting the four clues to get the Polarizer is kind of anti-climactic. It just ends and we don't see a final interaction between Shantae and Risky but it's possible that this was intentional because we'll see more in the eventual DLC modes that are supposed to come 2017 and onwards.Verdict:While the game is great in it's own right and a good evolution for the series, I can't help but feel that it doesn't quite top Pirate's Curse which was a really amazing game. It's still a great game, solid 8.5 from me. If you like the series or like 2D platformers then play this game, it's â¥â¥â¥â¥ing great.Also, Neo Burning Town is the best version of Burning Town.

content:
Posted: February 25
												The fourth game in the Shantae series is another instant classic. While not quite as good as Pirate's Curse, it offers snappy controls, plenty of movement and combat options, and a solid (if episodic) storyline with the series' trademark adorable pitch-dark humor.Shantae herself controls as wonderfully as always. Once again possessed of her genie powers, she learns transformations from each stage or from hidden items. Most of them, such as the elephant (which can crush blocks) and the mermaid (which can swim freely underwater) are primarily movement-focused, and open up new areas of each stage.Ah, yes ... stages. And therein lies the only problem with Shantae: Half-Genie Hero. In previous games of the series, Shantae would travel across the land, face a number of challenges, and then open up a dungeon for exploration. These dungeons were very much in the Metroidvania tradition, and navigating them successfully was the game's primary intellectual challenge.In Half-Genie Hero, the dungeons have been removed entirely; at the point in each stage when you'd be unlocking them, you go directly to the boss fight instead. The stages are mostly slightly longer than before, but not really enough to make up for the loss. A couple of them -- Main Street and a late-game castle -- remain downright puny.This makes the game's other negative more serious: the amount of BACKTRACKING. In the previous games, you mostly returned to old areas to seek out power-ups like life bar powerups or caches of treasure. While those are still here, some of the stages have little corners and nooks that contain MANDATORY items, including a transformation without which you can't even enter the last level! It honestly seems like you're intended to replay every stage to date whenever you get a new movement ability, or else take an amount of notes on obstacles that would put a JRPG to shame. (And even that wouldn't help in a couple of places -- I only found two crucial items by exhaustive searching.)All of this shouldn't put you off the game, though. Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is linear, sure, but you'll still get many hours of sweet gameplay for your admission fee. It's absolutely worth the price, even if it doesn't quite live up to its immediate predecessor.

YouTubeâ¢ Video: IS IT GOOD? Shantae: Half Genie Hero ReviewÂ 

			Views: 24,817		

			Shantae Half Genie Hero Review! To stop Risky's quest for booty, you'll need to shake Shantae's! Shantae Half Genie Hero is the latest in the belly dancing beauty's tales of half genie heroics!		

+Gameplay is smooth and fluid+Graphics are super slick+Music is catchy as all hell+Great level design reminescent of 8/16-bit Capcom titles+Interesting enemies with slightly more complex patterns than typical of the series+Amazing set pieces and boss encounters-Bikini Armor, Magic Tiara and the ridiculous number of heart containers break the difficulty utterly. Don't go into this game expecting a challenge past the first couple of levels if you aren't willing to handicap yourself on purpose. -Character development has taken a sharp back seat compared to Pirate's Curse, even regressing in the case of characters like Risky Boots and Rotty Tops-Story lacks a strong connecting thread and it feels more like a series of unrelated episodes strung together-I honestly can't remember a single puzzle-I can't put enough quotation marks around the word "dungeon" so I won't even try-At least for me, the frame rate stutters when I go through a level as fast as I possibly canThis is the least Metroidvania Shantae game that I've played, so keep that in mind. If you play these games for things like Risky's Revenge's Hypno Tower or Pirate's Curse's Cackle Tower, you should be warned that this game is more like Mega Man X than Super Metroid. That said, it excels at that sort of level design and I welcome the change... at least for now.But yeah, as many issues as I had with the game, it was a load of fun and I'd wholeheartedly recommend it.

content:
Posted: January 30
Shantae; A Great Game With Problems (NO SPOILERS)         As a New commer to the franchise, I found this to be a fun and interesting entry to the platforming genre. The game overall was a blast to play and I enjoyed almost every second of it..... almost all of it, dispite me enjoing this game a lot there are Two main problems with the game. Firstly, the difficulty is somewhat all over the place for example I found the game to be pretty easy till the last level where there was a huge spike in difficulty as to where the rest of the games platforming was simple to requiring a little bit of skill and finesse. Lastly, the game has some pretty bad glitches and game breaking exploits. the worst glitch I encountered was when I was about to finish the fourth level I missed a platform and died, when I respawned the game freaked out and I belive Shantae had  spawned out of the level then the game crashed; When the game was lanched again I had lost all my saved data. Besides that glitch there were a few minor ones like getting stuck in terrain and getting in to areas with no way to get out with out going to the level select screen. there is also a really bad exploit that lets you to unlock every spell and upgrade that is purchasable after you beat the second level. Other then those problems I loved the rest of the game Expecially the music. So If I had to rate this game out of ten, It would be a 7/10 overal a great game with a decent amount of problems.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
												SUMMARY: A fun, colorful metroidvaina-esque platformer with a lot of personality.  Though heir to a fan favorite series, it stands out pretty well on its own and shows a lot of crafting.  There's a few issues of polish and levels of difficulty, but the overal experience is very enjoyable.I Kickstarted this game.  Not because I was actually into the series, but as a lot of friends were, and were thrilled to see it returning.  I figured "what the heck" and tossed some money into the pot.Fast forward to now, and the results of a non-fan of the game?  Pretty damn good.Shantae is a platform-heavy metroidvania type game.  Start in a town, go to various areas on missions.  Complete missions, find new abilities, return to other areas to find stuff and use abilities, repeat.  Unlock new areas and new treasures.  It's a standard formula we all love.So let's see how it breaks down.PRESENTATION: The game is colorful and fun, with great graphics and soundtrack.  Characters have plenty of personality.  The game's look and feel is excellent.GAMEPLAY: Gameplay is very old-school and there's a heavy emphasis on exploring the environment and platforming timing. If you're not ready for it, it may be a bit of a shock.  When you "get" it then the game really comes together.CHARACTER GROWTH: Shantae basically A) finds new dances to transform into things, B) Buys spells and some combat upgrades, B) gets increased health.  It's not exactly complicated - the dances are the important part as they give you access to new areas.PUZZLES: Though the need to re-return to areas can be annoying,the different abilities you unlock make them easier to navigate, and help you access hidden areas.  A few times you'll have an "aha" moment and figure out how to solve something and get a real rush from it.STORY: The story seems to be more of a "Shantae's greatest hits gets the band back together" so you're not getting Game of Thrones or Dragon's Age here.If there's a flaw to the game, its some of it feels a tad disjointed, from varied difficulty to a grand adventure suddenly turning into a fetchquest that feels like it should have been optional.  It's a minor concern, but it did stand out for me.So do you buy it?1) If you're a fan, judging by the game's quality AND the fans I know you either should or already did, and I'm shocked you read this far.2) If you like colorful old-school patformers you'll probably enjoy this.3) It'd make a GREAT gift for a friend who liked old-school platformers.Who shouldn't buy it?1) If you don't like platformers, really, don't.  This game will make you angry.2) If you're not up for a game that involves repeating levels several times and poking around in their corners.

content:
Posted: January 23
												I've only discovered the Shantae games recently, seeing this game released on Steam a few days ago. I decided to buy Pirates Curse out of curiosity, and boy was I pleasantly surprised. It's so weird that I had never heard of this game before, despite how fun its gameplay is and how charming the world & characters were. After beating Pirate's Curse, I got 1/2 Hero. I had some reservations since it is a Kickstarter funded game but this isn't the the kind of Kickstarter game that disappoints. This one delivers pretty well. It is still fun to play, the character & world is still as charming, the soundtrack is sweet, the art style is much more striking (though I don't see why the character portraits shown in conversations in this game aren't as pretty as those in Pirate's Curse, but whatever), the LD changes still work (fewer and bigger levels with some backtracking, though the backtracking doesn't feel like a chore), overall a nice experience. Overall I am really impressed, and still kind of mad that I didn't know about this wonderful series before.As a side note in the menu there is a play mode that is coming soon (which I assume by the darkened silhouette with the hat that this is a Risky Boots mode). So when it comes out, keep in mind this review only covers the main game - Normal Mode & Hero Mode.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												It's still a good game but I feel like the kickstarter model didn't do too much good to the game because it's a step back from Pirate's Curse. Personally I'd say Risky's Revenge is even a little bit better.On the bright side they did progress from pixel art and have what I think is a great engine for the game. So perhaps there's some great potential in the future. The graphics, music and general movements are on point, although there are some minor bugs causing the game to stop for me from time to time. So overall it still plays great like a Shantae game. You get a lot of dances and the typical magic, which is very fun.Where it gets insufficient and I suspect may be due to the kickstarter forcing them to implement so many elements to the game and thus not having enough time left, is the content and the story. The writing, first of all, seems a bit off. Shantae isn't a story focused game by any means but I thought this game story wise is especially shallow and did not portray the main characters as well as they can. Content wise you have so many powers and forms but there is very little content specifically designed for them, in some cases only one zone or none at all. Also, to inflate the content the devs added a lot of backtracing the the zones and since this game is no longer metroidvania style that's also not as good an experience as in previous games where revisiting zones and doing challenge dungeons can be so much fun. Another issue is boss difficulty tuning-- the later bosses are a joke unless you restrict yourself to not using any magic or item at all.I think if this game was a bit more polished story wise and had 50% more content (that's not backtracing) it would have been great. As it is I still can't hate it because it's still Shantae but I don't regret not joining the kickstarter either.

												Just what I expected. A cheerful and near flawless platformer, where you are, again, in perfect control of your character. The puzzles and boss fights are  challenging, especially if you're new to the series, which is a good thing! If you played the previous titles, you won't notice a large difference, but won't get bored aswell.The zones' enemies now update, once you revisit them, reflecting that you've beaten the boss of that level.Lots and lots of transformations. WayForward was like: you asked for more transformations? THERE U GO!The playstyle is a mix between the original and Risky's Revenge, regarding the power-ups and weapons, making Pirate's Curse a unique experience. MOST IMPORTANTLY: The items (relics) you buy can make the game a walk in the park, but they can be disabled and you can define your own difficulty. There are some minor tech flaws, which I hope they get patched soon, other than that, I really recommend it. If you're a fan of the series, want a good platformer or another metroidvenia done right, then this is for you.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												It's still a good game but I feel like the kickstarter model didn't do too much good to the game because it's a step back from Pirate's Curse. Personally I'd say Risky's Revenge is even a little bit better.On the bright side they did progress from pixel art and have what I think is a great engine for the game. So perhaps there's some great potential in the future. The graphics, music and general movements are on point, although there are some minor bugs causing the game to stop for me from time to time. So overall it still plays great like a Shantae game. You get a lot of dances and the typical magic, which is very fun.Where it gets insufficient and I suspect may be due to the kickstarter forcing them to implement so many elements to the game and thus not having enough time left, is the content and the story. The writing, first of all, seems a bit off. Shantae isn't a story focused game by any means but I thought this game story wise is especially shallow and did not portray the main characters as well as they can. Content wise you have so many powers and forms but there is very little content specifically designed for them, in some cases only one zone or none at all. Also, to inflate the content the devs added a lot of backtracing the the zones and since this game is no longer metroidvania style that's also not as good an experience as in previous games where revisiting zones and doing challenge dungeons can be so much fun. Another issue is boss difficulty tuning-- the later bosses are a joke unless you restrict yourself to not using any magic or item at all.I think if this game was a bit more polished story wise and had 50% more content (that's not backtracing) it would have been great. As it is I still can't hate it because it's still Shantae but I don't regret not joining the kickstarter either.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
												Disclaimer: I'm a kicstarter backer and I was able to play this game early. I completed my first playthrough on December 19th. There are no spoilers in this review.I have been a long time fan of the Shantae series, the unique charm of the protagonist combined with the world the stories are set in made it for a fun and unique experience every time. The series falls into what qualifies as a Metroidvania. All games encourage backtracking and exploration as you gain more powers and mobility, the rewards being more story and of course, a higher completion. To my knowledge the latest two games even have multiple endings determined by your completion rate.Some history:---------------The first game in the series called "Shantae" came out late in the Game Boy Color's life (2002) and was a superbly animated game for the time. In my opinion it is also the most difficult game in the series so far as the first hour or two before you gain more abilities can be brutal. In this game, Shantae was set out to stop her ever present rival, the pirate called Risky Boots and her horde of Tinkerbats. The physical version of this game is quite rare nowadays. Thankfully, if you own a (New) 2/3DS/XL you can play this game via Virtual Console.The second game "Risky's Revenge" came out much later (2010) for the DS/DSi and was a worthy follow up that saw Shantae once again facing off against Risky Boots as the pirate lady sought revenge for the events in the first game. This game is still available for the DS series of portables and a PC version has been released as well, available right here on Steam.The third game came out in 2014 and is called "Pirate's Curse". This is the first game in the series to provide some voice acting, but also features a plot where Risky Boots seeks Shantae's help in defeating a foe more dangerous than her. Nevertheless I think this is the best game in the series so far. This game came out on a lot of platforms, including PC. The 3DS version has some nice depth effects as well.----------------Does it mean that Half-Genie Hero is an inferior game? Not at all! From a personal perspective I think Pirate's Curse has a better story and higher stakes (although even that could be argued as there is a lot at stake in HGH too, plot wise). But the gameplay, graphics and music are superb as expected from the experienced team at WayForward as well as the designs of Matt and Erin Bozon (who created Shantae) and the music of my favourite games musician, Jake "Virt" Kaufman.That said, in HGH, Shantae is once again out to face off against Risky Boots who seeks to abuse the knowledge she gained during "Pirate's Curse".  The controls are good and the storytelling is funny in the right places. Transformation magic returns once more (it was absent in "Pirate's Curse") but has been simplified to speed up game play.If you wonder if you should play all games in chronological order...that depends on you! While each game can be played on its own without knowing the earlier stories, there are some small nods here and there to events from previous games. Even so, HGH makes sure you are introduced to each character and immediately know what they are like.There were some problems in the version I played and I expect they will get ironed out after the game is released tomorrow. While not breaking, some powers can be exploited to make sections of the game extremely trivial. If you happen to find such a way, consider challenging yourself!All in all, it took me the listed time as of this review (11.7) hours to finish the game first time through. I had to peruse some youtube videos to find some items I missed, but the game does clue you in . I recommend talking to everyone after each plot event!-----------------TL;DR: Great game, as polished as expected from the creators. Personally I think the story in the previous game was better, but that's my opinion and doesn't detract from the gameplay enjoyment.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
												A very enjoyable little Metroidvania platformer. The art and music are excellent, the character designs are cute and fun, and the gameplay is solid.For those who have never played a Shantae title, the premise is fairly unique: You play a half-genie bellydancing heroine who fights enemies using her magical prehensile hair and magical dances that allow her to transform into a dozen-odd different animals.The game, unlike most previous Shantae titles, is split into distinct levels, which vary between being fairly linear to fairly open-ended, though both sorts allow for a fair amount of exploration and discovery. This division does make getting 100% much easier, as the level select lets you know what's left to find in a given level, so rather than having to hunt through the entire overworld you just have to explore on level, which is rather nice.It's not flawless, the story is largely an afterthought, the jokes can fall flat, and some of the transformations see essentially no use, but the game is definitely fun and very much worth a look.It took me about 7 hours to 100% the Shantae campaign (an additional campaign where you play as her arch-nemesis, Risky Boots, is being worked on), so this isn't going to occupy you for months, but that does make it comparable to Super Metroid for the amount of content, which is fine by me.
