content:
Posted: February 23
												I enjoy the Shantae Series, yet can't say this iteration is a step up. The only thing going for this game is the upgrade in graphics (Completely Objective) and that it continues the story for Shantae the character.The story in this game was weak. It does however give a nod to what of the main characters mentioned before, and they did just that. ( Trying not to spoil the game here).There are far more transformations in the games, which is nice. Say, we have 6 transformations in all, 3 would be base abilities, while the other 3 would be upgrades to those previous. Like a level 1 fireball that shoots 1 fireball to a level 2 fireball that shoots 2. Some transformations are oddly specific and have no other use to them.Dances is what Shantae does, yet she does only one dance for all the transformations. Which was sad to see.... I liked where she had many dance moves (animations) when she would transform.It seems art styles change with each game, and I am a huge fan of the Pirate Curse art the most. It had personality. I would blame transformations for taking up production time on making the conversation art better. Puzzles are nearly nonexistant, or way too easy. The game was fairly easy. I did not have to worry about dying due to lose of hearts, well, neither did I in the last game....There is no map this time, and finding things was easy. Some items made the game too easy. You can turn them off if you think that would present a challenge. Then if thats the case, don't look for items.Sadly, I would have rather played Pirates Curse again for the ingaging characters, side quests, and other such stuff.The good part is that they made it easier for you to travel where you want faster with a travel dance and a whistle to travel from world to world. Save points arent the usual, where you find the guy and choose to save. Each section of a level requires you to make the choice. In case you die or are trying to do a certain achievement this shines. A Little.I still recommend this game. I wished I got wind of the Kickstarter so I could support them. I want them to continue making more Shantae games, but I think they need to look back at Pirates Curse, which I think to be the best of the series.Platforming is really weak. I'm not sure if this game was trying to cater to some group that thought the platforming wasn't important. They even threw in a small castle level with those detestable magic doors that warp you all around.I feel the lack of funds and the over-ambition of making so many transformations has watered down the level design for puzzles and more animations for the characters has made this game not up to par.

number of helpful: 10 of 24 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												To start off, if Steam would let me I would say I'm between mixed and not into recommending it.It's a good game, but honestly not as good as its predecessors. It opts for linear level design and world design, the entire exploration aspect is gone. But for some reason, the game kept backtracking. As soon as you finish the second level you need to go through the entire first level and kill 30 enemies in one respawn area to progress. If you bought the warp spell you can just do a a bit of one third of the level and warp out, but you have to buy it, and you'll likely instead buy a damage or attack speed upgrade first. It really seems like something you can just do, like select and area of the level from a menu or something along those lines...The game itself controls nicely and has great art, animation, and music, but with lackluster bosses and seemingly bland level design, it really doesn't shine well.The third boss is what did it to me. It's such a boring mess. First of all, it's the worst type of boss, one where you have to wait for it to go through it's silly and long attack pattern before doing one hit to it (you have to hit it four times). It's also a cake walk to dodge the attacks. Personally, one of my favorite parts of side-scrolling platformers tends to be the bosses, so this really was a deal-breaker for me.If you dislike platformers being less linear, I suppose you could play this game.If not, you should rather play Shantae and the Pirates Curse and maybe the other games if you're up to it.This one is just too easy and tedious, and honestly, lacking in good game sense. I was really looking forward to this game and bought it early, but the direction it went in is dissatisfying to say the least. I'll buy it again when it goes on sale, most likely, but for now I'm refunding it.

content:
Posted: February 18
												Shantae: Half-Genie Hero just doesn't live up to the other games in the series in my opinion. It's not a bad game per say but I would only recommend this one for people that have children... the series kept getting easier ever since the first game but this one had a very unsatisfying level of challenge. The challenge came only from instant-death autoscroll segments which leave you more frusterated than satisfied. The combat is a joke in Shantae's latest outing... with the huge stock of food you can hold I never felt threatened by a boss... for the last few bosses I didn't even care about getting hit I just maximized my damage hitting them and healing when needed. Some of the attacks might have been somewhat fun to learn the patterns for but.. it was never necessary. It's nice to see a return of the transformations to Shantae but some of them feel pretty pointless (Mainly the spider form which is only used for a couple parts and essentially replaced later)I really wanted to like this game because the Shantae character and theme of the games are so fun, lighthearted and bouncy... but the gameplay this time around just didn't let that happen.

number of helpful: 3 of 11 people (27%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20
												I just wanted this game to END.The latest Shantae is the 4th in the series and is a fully crowdfunded game.  The self destructive mayor fires  Shantae (again) and she must solve a series of problems and fetch quests to regain Scuttle Town's favor.This game does a few new things.  First, the game is less like a metroidvania and more like Mega Man X.  The game no longer has a map, and instead has a sereis of levels with nooks and crannies that can only be accessed with new upgrades.This game has the nicest production values of the franchise.  Characters are now fully 3d cel shaded, looking like Guilty Gear Xrd without the deliberate frame rate reduction, so all animations and movement are silky smooth.  The soundtrack is phenomenal, including electronic and funk beats.The game starts off very strong, with wonderful humor, action and boss fights.  But as the game goes long, two things happen.  First, the action is bogged down between fetch quests.  For those who don't know, Shantae always has humorous fetch quests which depend on key items that you will not expect to need, recieve, or give.  In this game they are easily the most numerous.  You will run around in circles checking if your latest upgrade will work in "that one spot" you couldn't reach before.  If only you could remember where it was: you have no map!  Second, the difficulty of the game PLUMMETS.  This is easily the lowest difficulty game in the franchise.  In the time I spent running around in circles, I fully upgraded my attack and attack speed.  In the midgame, you will find heart containers like candy, to the point you can ignore enemies and damage to a silly degree.This was the most tiresome and boring Shantae game I played.  Play Momodora or any other intense action game and just youtube the boss fights instead.

number of helpful: 0 of 5 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12
												If you're looking for a deep story, great levels and a big world, this is not your game. Half-Genie Hero has more in common with Megaman than it does with its previous entries in the Shantae Series, while trying to hold to its original roots, and somewhat failing at it. Where HGH succeeds the most at is in its fidelity. This game is really colourful, the animations are bouncy and lively, it's just very pleasant to look at. The soundtrack is really good too, however, I do find it to sound REALLY flat due to its really high volume. After downloading several soundtracks from the composer, Jake Kaufman, that seems to be an ongoing issue with his masterings. So if the game sounds too loud when you first start it up, it might catch you off guard and I defnitely recommend lowering your volume.When it comes to being a sequel, the game improves a few things from it's closer sibling, Risky's Revenge, is the dancing system and overall powerups. The new system implemented in this one works better as you only have to press the dance button and then choose which transformation you want by pressing a direction. It works well and if you think it's too slow, you can even get a powerup to make the dance faster. In fact, HGH is probably the fastest feeling entry so far thanks to its responsiveness.Probably my personal favorite part of the game when it comes to gameplay are the first four stages... when played linearly. They are quick, action-packed and are quite fun to traverse with fun bosses (Except for the last two...).The first part where game falls apart to me when they want you to backtrack to stages to get specific items. It wouldn't be a huge issue if the stages introduced new things but they just don't. The ''new paths'' are usually one or two rooms, which more often than not, will either be coursed through in less than a minute, or are big and open with nothing in them, just to pad things out. It gets really monotous to since you have to do exactly that, several times in a row to even progress to the next stage.The second part is actualy the final third of the game. The stages feel unfinished, with even less original set pieces, hazards, especially when two key characters are haphazardly placed in the second to last stage, with no introduction. In fact, a lot of characters in HGH are completely forgetable and have barely to no development at all and when the game ends, it really feels unsatisfying. Now if you factor the rather dull design, and combine what is essentially the game breaking transformation, the Harpie, you get a final stage that is insultingly easy. Why? The stage was designed for you to take advantage of a couple of transformations. The Issue? The harpy can fly over the majority of them. There were only two counts where I switched to the monkey. This makes some rather elaborate traps completely useless.The final boss and endings are not much better. First, my game crashed once when I defeated the first phase of the boss. Second, I skipped the cutscene as the fade to black was still on the screen, leaving it black and making the fight impossible (I've encountered several glitches so far, some worse than others). Third, if I am either regular Shantae, Mermaid Shantae or Harpie Shantae, the background of the second phase will never rotate like it should and screw with the movement of the boss' attacks. FOURTH, the final phase has an attack that circles the whole arena, and it makes no sound effects. If it does, I can't hear it. It also blends with all the other assets during the fight due to their colours. FIFTH, the endings are almost identical, regardless if you get the ''best'' or ''regular'' ending. It's  just not satisfying at all and feels slapped together.The final slap in the face to me from this game, is the fact the DLC will have to be paid for non-backers. Considering how barebones the game felt, along with the lackluster two final stages AND the full price of this game, I flatout cannot consider even getting the DLC. I feel like they should have been part of the game ''and the price'' from the very start.If Shantae Half Genie Hero was not forcing mandatory exploration and padding and was more like Megaman, as its stages are clearly focused on being much more linear than the areas from the previous entries of the series, this would be so much better. However, as it stands, and WITHOUT THE DLC AND AT FULL price. I can't really recommend this game unless you're a die hard fan. If you want a significantly better experience, go get Shantae and The Pirate's Curse.If the DLC releases and they have a bundle for the launch price of the game and cut the standalone game's price, then it might be worth checking out. Maybe....

content:
Posted: March 5
												The worst of the three modern Shantae games - by FAR. Please hear me out.The game is way too easy. You quickly become ridiculously overpowered. After less than half through the game I didn't even care about taking damage. You practically never run out of hearts, and if you happen to be close to death you have lots of potions, magic, pickups, and food to restore health. You can turn off the upgrades that you've acquired, but that should NEVER be required to make the game sufficiently challenging. Really bad game design.Edit: People are talking about a hardcore mode. But that doesn't justify that the "normal" mode feels like beginner difficulty, especially since the previous games were really hard in their normal mode.The story is very forgettable. The plot progression is very often ridiculous, as the developers couldn't come up with believable ways to acquire key items. It just feels very rushed.The humor isn't at as funny as it was in previous games.Way too many transformations. Some of them are really boring, and some of them are almost never used apart from that one single stage you acquired them at.The charming pixel art is gone. It was one of the things that made the Shantae series stand apart from other platformer games, but now even that is gone.Not really the hardcore metroidvania style from the previous games. Really easy to acess the hidden areas.Very easy boss fights. Very easy platforming. No charming characters. The game is very short.Really bland game. Wish I hadn't bought it.3/10

Posted: January 29
												I enjoyed all previous Shantae titles, but have been signifigantly dissapointed by this entry. The artstyle and writing are top-notch but the difficulty is all over the place. My most notable gripe with it is that dying then reloading your last save does not restore Shantae's health at all. This become the most infuriating during a slide obstacle section in Mermaid Falls, where I ended up going into the section (and saving) with only 1HP making it so touching anything would kill me instantly. With no options to load previous saves, I was left with the option to try and finish it without taking any damage, or to restart my entire save file, and play through the first hour of the game again.As of writing this I have died 45 times on that section (which is ridiculously long by the way) and have since dropped the game, and refunded it. If I had the option to start the stage from the beginning again so I could try to have more HP going into this, I'd likely keep playing because I could fix the problem, but I'm not interested in playing the entire beginning of the game again.If you don't like difficulty and are going into this for it's witty narrative and colorfull artstyle, this game isn't for you.

number of helpful: 15 of 51 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is a game that wastes my time and jerks me around. I have beaten this game to 100% and this is my review:The positives:-Good music, which will get repetitive as you replay levels over and over.-Pretty good visuals.The negatives:-Poorly thought out level design-Terrible controls for several different Shantae transformations.-Monkey Island style wacky nonsensical solutions to puzzles that make no sense.-Awful check point system that makes you replay entire levels/the worst part of a level over and over.-Forces you to constantly replay levels over and over as you unlock new powers which, in the end, does not feel satisfying but instead wastes your time.-Boring boss battles.-Terrible memeatic writing that is forced sounding and fan service feeling in general-Has kick starter âbacker-exclusiveâ content that cannot be bought at all by anyone who didnât get in early on the kick starter. This is anti-consumerism no matter how you try to spin it. This basically says to people who wanted to wait for a finished product and reviews, âyour money is worth less to us than those who backed itâ.  More on this at the bottom of the review.-Very little bang for your buck. I frustratingly played through this game in 8 hours, it is designed to be beaten in 4 hours. This is a 20 dollar game.Details of this filth:I have invented a new term just for this game, which upon reflection can be applied to a lot of bad games.This term is called, âMonkey Island solutionsâ what is a, Monkey Island solution you ask? It is when a game, not just point-n-click adventure games, ask you to perform a series of complicated tasks to do a simple objective but also in which none of the steps nor end result makes sense and cannot be deduced naturally. Some other people in the video game realm might call this, ârub the fish on everythingâ syndrome.Here is an example from this very game: you must get the power, as a mermaid, to shoot bubbles. How do you do this? Well, one of the villagers tells you that only âelderâ sea creatures know this power! Well look at that, in town suddenly is the Grandma Blobfish (which earlier you had to find two tickets for her grandkids to go see a magic carpet ride via killing gator enemies with magic you must grind money for to unlock until they drop âgator stakesâ to give to too villains for a ticket and that was only HALF of that quest).Ahem, the example:"We're gonna need you to get this blobfish a new hat so she can sing you a song and give you the mermaid shooting ability but to do that you must get the hat from a WACKY CHARACTER GUY that tells you to find ANOTHER WACKY CHARACTER GUY but to do that you first need to unlock the Mermaid form (several step subquest), combo into Harpy unlock (several step subquest), and figure out this cryptic clue that actually makes no sense (subquest to get clue)"Do you see how this is a problem, how it is unfun to deal with and why guides are so popular for games today? This game is entirely like this, the whole game.Letâs mention some gameplay; there is a point in this game in which you must control Shantae through a SPIKE MAZE using the WORST CONTROLLING form in the game, the Harpy. The harpy controls like a flappy bird clone but you can move forwards and backwards. She does not stop in midair, she always slightly moves forward which is a problem when this is happening:


Shantae: Half-Genie HeroÂ 
A Screenshot of Shantae: Half-Genie Hero
By: Amelia




See these two blocks? They are rotating around each other, and before them there are a series of three columns that block the entire way from ceiling to floor (the floor also kills you) and you must step in between the middle set of these spike walls as it opens to wait for the next to open; all doing this mind you while the harpy cannot hover in midair so you must constantly tap jump to flap while wiggling back and forth to not die in a space less than an 8th of your screen for a character that takes up 90% of said space you are safe. This section alone is so disgustingly made, so poorly thought out I almost quit the game right then and there; and this is at the very end of the game, right before the big finish. Oh right, for good measure they take you back to the start of the level if you die so ya know, have fun backtracking through the level to get up to the point you died, only to then die again on the very next trap you have no idea is coming.The examples I give above are not single instances, but throughout the entire game. This whole game is a huge mess of poorly thought out choices, obscure and often offensive puzzles, poor controls for multiple transformation forms, and a absolutely terrible check point system that will make you want to quit. Do not buy this game.Why backer exclusive content is anti-consumerism Backer exclusive content is anti-consumerism in pure form.Well fear not, for I shall explain; you see by offering 'backer-exclusive" content the game devs are tempting you in parting with your money before a finished product is made. They are offering you promises for cash, this is anti-consumer.Pro-consumer is waiting for a finished, final product. If you are offered a chance to wait for a product, to see if you would like it and to experience reviews then you are in the clear and so are the devs. Backer-exclusives can be grouped in with other scummy practices devs/publishers often use. Here is an example:"If you buy this game now, you will get access to X thing! No one else will get access to X thing because they bought it AFTER the game was released." Can you name that anti-consumer practice? That's right, preorder bonuses! Buy now, get product later! Secure money now for nothing, offer a game that might be as good we promise ;). Sound familiar? In the above sentence replace "after the game is released" with "after the game is funded". Nice.A quick question to people that will come shilling in because of the bottom of this review: please riddle me this, how did games get made before kick starter?How did a game get produced without the backing of a publisher, triple A or otherwise? How did indie games come into this world without the hand holding of kick starter? Through the blood, sweet, and tears of game devs everywhere. Cave story came to exist and became an excellent game as it was done by a man in his spare time.

number of helpful: 22 of 86 people (26%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
												A game with beautiful, energetic aesthetics and unadventurous design.+ Aesthetics in general are sharp, cartoony and juicy. The animations with Wrench are particularly fun.+ Factory stage has a nice narrative progression.+ Stage progression is more arcade-style than metroidvania-style, which is a fun change for the series.+ New-form-containing genie rooms remind me of Rayman (PS1), and make understanding the basic utility of new forms very easy.+ The writing is fun and self-deprecating. Most of the dialogue has great gameplay utility as well, guiding the player with hints (though the bolded text takes some of the fun out of parsing dialogue for the important bits).+ VO is sprinkled throughout the game and contributes to the personality of the characters and dialogue. It seems like a clever (and budget friendly) way to equip our imaginations with a little more material.- The megaman-style disappearing blocks are played out, and a little overused in some of the level designs.- The dance selection screen is colorful, but has an odd timing-element that automates the cycling of menus. More than once I mis-selected as the menu switched at just the wrong time.- Stages tend to introduce a new mechanic, but they don't seem particularly novel so far. This level features something you can climb / hang from (Donkey Kong Country). This level features wind that pushes you (Megaman). This level features...enemy spawners? Levels don't feel surprising after the novelty of new visuals wear off.- The monkey form feels weirdly sticky when climbing on walls. It can feel awkward when I try to climb up over the side of a wall, or transform back into human form. The time lost performing attempting these acts often leads to cheap damage in combat situations.- projectile-wielding enemies tend to shoot from off-screen, which can lead to cheap damage when playing an area for the first time. - The Wilbur worm escape features level design that essentially dooms the player if they proceed up the wrong path. The choice is arbitrary the first time a player sees it, so these deaths are very frustrating.- Game over screen should have more character in a game as colorful as this. Players may see it several times, so why not try some arkham-asylum-style flavor dialogue?- The hitbox of Shantae's human form seems a bit large. Shrinking it a bit within the actual sprite raises the odds for a daring, exciting dodge. Players who get used to the smaller hitbox can use it to make combat faster, more risky, and more showy- Characters often animate during cutscenes and dialog, but without any zoom, this easily goes unnoticed (some dramatic zoom wouldn't seem out of place in a story this goofy).- Monkey form seems to have far more general utility than the crab form.- I wish there was an overarching villain to give the story a visible destination. As it stands, the magnet contraption ties things together a bit, but the player isn't even told how many pieces remain, or what the final design looks like (unless I'm missing something-- perhaps there was a way to look at the blueprints before handing them to uncle).- The liberal use of VO really gives the characters...character, but we don't need Shantae revealing the high-level strategy to each boss phase. It takes away the fun a bit, and most are simple enough to simply not need it.- There seems to be little difference between a fall-death and a game over. The latter should be a more impactful fate than the former, yet the latter typically places the player at the exact same location as the former, but with full health! Often, it is the better option, as being forced to restart an area without having health replenished sometimes sets the player up for quick, highly-probable (and frustrating) failure.- Bosses don't seem to emphasize new abilities much, in the way a Legend-of-Zelda boss would. While LoZ bosses may go overboard with the way they require stage-specific abilities, the bosses here feel a little rote-- all they seem to require is a bit of hair-whipping and jumping, for the most part. Mechanics never really come together, or combine in interesting ways during these fights, and they never really feel exciting as a result.Thank you for your effort on this game, and best of luck moving forward!

Before you read my Review: Im a long time gamer AND played the whole Shantae series. I dont only look at the game and say "oh look it hasâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ its a good game", i go into this review with a more, deeper sense. Next to this, i finished it 100% and was one of the original backers from its Kickstarter campaign back in 2013. Just dont be a "fanboy" and read it carefully.


Was looking around the city,missed something from the mayor. boom. 100%. done.Â 
A Screenshot of Shantae: Half-Genie Hero
By: W.A. the Anum




I waited to long for this...way to long...Shantae HGH was original backed back in 2013 and promissed to be finish in October 2014 - so the original Kickstarter project told. Now we have it Christmas 2016 and its finally there, after 3 years of waiting. Is the game good? Was it worth the wait? That all will i try to explain here in my review.Shantae and the long story shortShantae began her journey back on the GBC but got more fame on the Nindendo DSi systems with her 2nd game "Risky's Revenge. Both titles were more like Action adventures with (more or less) open worlds, metroidvania-like and a lot room to explore. Since Game nr. 3, "The Pirates Curse", The series changed more into a "stage-like-RPG" game. Still, the "stages" were pretty big and you really had a lot room ("still") to explore. Half-Genie Hero actually made more a step backward and gave the player only 7 pretty short stages to explore, one of them is the main town. Said that, HGH feels somehow "smaller" and even plays that way. the stages have maybe about 3 areas and are not even "that" big. At least not so big that HGH has a Map system (so it doesnt has one) unlike other Shantae games. They also are more like "walk from left to right" unlike in the Pirates Curse.In terms of music and sounds i can say they really did a good job, i actually like some of the tracks playing in the background. Still, they actually are not better than from the other Shantae games and some others fails to shine, like the song with actual lyrics.For the grafic i can say i actually enjoy them but i have to say, if i looked at the concept art, i really miss some emotions or animations somehow, like Shantaes actually Belly-"dances" are now just the stereotype "move the hip from left to right". No other, cute dances or animations or like.


they should have gone with that- The original dances.Â 
A Screenshot of Shantae: Half-Genie Hero
By: W.A. the Anum




Next to this they ported the Stand animation from RR/PC into this game and it looks, honestly, very very awkward. They should have gone with the original stand from the GBC Shantae game - i might understood why they used this "stand animation", still it really doesnt fits the artstyle of the game. But as i said already, it feels like the game lacks some animations. a good sample would be here:


RUN FOR YOUR LIFE! DONT FORGET TO SMILE! EMOTIONS! :DÂ 
A Screenshot of Shantae: Half-Genie Hero
By: W.A. the Anum




The characters are suppost to show fear but they dont, no emotions at all.I know, animations "handdrawn" like the game already shows is a lot work but thinking about that they had 3 years time(+), and normaly it SHOULD had been done in 2014, it looks a bit "rushed" all of a sudden. The only "effort" i can sadly see is how "badly" they sexualized Shantae and all other characters. The full game feels like, if you dont look only "its gameplay", like (nothing personal) some nerd who wants to get laid created a character withâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥that all effort and money went right between the charactersâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ Like for real, if you dont belive me, here a timeline:http://www.dmgice.com/revs/images/shantaethroughtheyears.pngAnd if you dont belive me, nearly ever "good" looking character is Female, has a very "obvious" short looking dress and mostly moves (and "talks") that way...and the cherry on top is that THAT also counts for good 90% of the "monsters". http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=819664595Female Spiders, Slimegirls and other "female", "boobed" monster appiers in someway, showing her "content" in all their best way. I have no problem, as "normal Hetero Male Person", to seeâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥and hips in a video game but it gives a right time and moment....and the right games for that, if you know what i mean. But we are talking about a game from Wayforward...A Backers opinion...Thinking about that this game "should" be done in 2014 and its now 2 years to late is a HUGE and long time to wait. At the end, it sure is finally there but the game feels still rushed and somehow, it really misses a bit more "emotions" which went only into the (so it seems) "female breast sizes". I mean, if they wana make it that obvious that the full game is only aboutâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥and hips, they should make it like namco and bring out a "nearly naked shantae DLC" for 5 bucks, really. If i dont look only on the sexualized characters (which is pretty hard since nearly every good character is female and nearly "half-naked" somehow...), the game plays really good and nice. Still, it misses the "charm" of the older games from the series since its only "Level based" and not "Metroidvania" World based. Next to this, i finished the game with 100% in about ~7 hours (my screenshot shows more but i also was afk for a moment and forgot the game was running) which feels, next to 3 years of wait which were to long, way to short for the peroid of waiting time i had as backer. I didnt expect a very huge Zelda-like clone adventure but if i look back at, as sample, RR, you had a pretty large world to explore and that actually made a whole lot fun, which i miss in this game. It just feels "short" even if i had fun playing it it felt more like a cookie you eat but you want more but you know, this was the last.So is it worth it?If i look at the pricetag for 20â¬, i can recomment it but only if you really want it or youre a hardcore Shantae-fan. It is not a bad game but it lacks of content (right now at least) and feels somehow rushed even after 3 years of pur waiting. Next to this you have this game done in round about ~7 hours (or less) - and that 100%. It looks nice, maybe a bit "to much" sexualized. I actually had fun playing it but if you want to try a better Shantae game you should try the Original GBC or risky's revenge, with both great worlds to explore which you will NOT find in this game title, Sadly. Still, it sure is worth playing but as backer im kinda a bit disappointed about that whole 3 years went only intoâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥and hips and not into a better gameplay, longer levels or maybe even a Metroidvaina-Open World...

Posted: December 29, 2016
												Somewhat conflicted over this one. Half-Genie Hero is a good game in its own right, but IMO it's a big step down from Pirate's Curse. The transformation dances from the original game and Risky's Revenge are back, but many of them feel shoehorned in and don't serve much purpose outside of getting an item here and there. The level design is much more linear and straightforward compared to the previous entries, and dungeons with maps and keys are completely absent. Even so, there are still plenty of secret items that you can go back and find throughout the levels.The bosses are a lot of fun but also pushovers, it's true that these games have never been particularly difficult to begin with but I think even by the series standards this game stands out as being the least challenging one yet(Hardcore mode update rectifies this). As far as story goes, it still retains the charm and humor from the previous games but there's not really any continuation from Pirate's Curse, as if all the character development and events that occurred never took place. The game acts more like a soft reboot.Despite everything, I still think it's a good and very fun game, I definitely recommend it if you're a fan of the series. Music is top notch, controls are tight, the game looks great and DLC is coming in the near future that'll let you play through 4 additional campaigns as other characters, so that may alleviate some of the issues.

												EDIT: The hard mode has been unlocked so pretty much ignore anything about me calling the game easy as a whole, because as of right now I haven't played the game on hardThe story is little too dumb and cliche-heavy to actually praise in my book.The gameplay isn't as good as RR or PC comparitively and there's not much to do once you get everything (besides being a goddess because nothing can kill you at that point)Not a bad game overall, and they've made some dlc (Hard mode and probably Risky mode soon) free so that's definitely a plus.It is a fun and charming ride while I played it and using transformations for what they were meant for was satisfying (despite most of the forms not having a use outside of their intended used aside from the monkey which is faster than your normal form and the harpy that lets you skip most of the stages in the game if they aren't closed-roofed). 												A solid 10 hours if you want to get 100% items, take your time, and enjoy the game (that's 2 dollars an hour at full price... totally worth it.) Some of the platforming can be frustrating, but other than that, it is a very well-done game with tight controls, beautiful graphics, and the most adorable 1/2 genie hero you'll ever meet. I wish I helped kickstart it.I just wish that the kickstarter got enough funding for full voice acting, and the animated cut scenes. If they add that as DLC I might consider buying it, to replay with full voice.Below is my QQ rant:Edit: Tassel Town made me hate platformers. I'm 26% complete at this point, and I am starting to remember why I don't play this sort of game. I still recommend it.Edit #2: I collected all the things. They gave me unlimited magic, therefore total invulnerability to any enemy attack. I figured I could just walk through Risky's Hideout and see the story. I was horribly wrong. Instead, they are forcing you to play JOUST while avoiding spiked walls that MOVE and ONE SHOT you. Wayforward, you are making me very sad. Though, I am developing a mastery for the harpy form, and realizing that using HARPY TALON (which I may never unhear now, because she says it so much) stops me in mid-air. I want to cry right now; I've restarted this level over 25 times now, and each time I get a little further, I get one-shotted.Edit #3: Finished the game, had 99% completion. WTF. I had to load the save right before the longâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥boss fight, go back, buy the stupid blobfish whatever dance, then do the longâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥fight again, just to get 100%. Dumb.

Posted: December 21, 2016
												The amazing 4th installment of the Shantae series.PROS:The controls respond exactly how they should.There's so much thought put into the art and animation.The transformation count in this one certainly does not disappoint!Boss fights are fantastic, not too difficult, but require you to pay attention.You make use of all your transformations near the end of the game, which in itself is a massive plus.The ability to turn off gear and abilities from the shop and the ability to use older versions of magic powers.Hero mode and plenty of achievements to hunt for.CONS:It's a bit easier than other shantae games (As well as some transformations making certain segments way too easy to platform through)... but you can switch certain items off to give yourself more of a challenge.It's quite a bit shorter than other shantae games, but there's more content on the way.If you like Metroidvania games and platformers, this is right up your alley.A ton of fun and very hard to put down, and one of my favorite games of this year.It gets a 8.5/10 from me because Squid Baron isn't last boss yet. (Totally a valid reason, right?)

Posted: December 21, 2016
												Fun game to play through, controls are tight, attacking feels good. Cast of characters are cute some more memorable than others, overall a joy to play through. The enviroments are quite detailed some of the plot is interesting (and disturbing if you think too much into it). Some puzzles can be fun to solve while others are merely wait until you get X powerup then backtrack, which honestly didn't really fit that well in an arcade style game like this.But this game has a few issues with challenge, there are a couple of parts which are challenging BUT because of 1 hit kill hazards, so it is more of a change the angle of your jump or timing challenge.Spells feel quite useless, only ever needing to use one just because I had to for a quest. Some forms just outright break some of the platforming stages allowing you to just skip entire segments by simply going off screen (Much like with Super Mario World and the Cape).The main meat of the game, the gameplay itself the generic enemies are rather forgetable outside 1 - 2 enemy designs and many enemy types you can easily just ignore and run through if you feel like it. The main offender for this happening is how easy and quick it is to obtain powerups in this game that basically breaks your character. You will find that you are practically invincible after the first stage, once you obtained 2 health powerups and the armor that reduces all damage taken by half.So to put thing short, the game is fun to play but if you are after something that can challenge you this may not be the game for you.

												Highly polished and very fun to play but a little short compared to its predecessors with the ever present metroidvania back tracking.Hoewever some of the transformations seemingly only being there to create an optional achievement and I'm not sure what was even different about the heroic difficulty mode as it didn't feel any harder.This might not have been helped by an infinite money trick unlocking very early in the game.Want more and looking forward to  more content and regardless.

Posted: December 21, 2016
												I feel so glad i finally had a chance to play this. I can definitely recommend it.For those that ask, is it like Pirates Curse? Yes and no.While 1/2 Genie Hero keeps the goofy Characters (friends and foes alike).- I think the major difference to the prequels is: No more "Zelda like" Dungeons where you have to go back and forth collecting keys to unlock doors.Instead each world has stories when you visit them. The developers made it a nice touch that almost every world is a bit different when you visit them a second time and the mainstory bypassed them.- The Graphic is a pure collection of ART XD- The Music is good too- The Gameplay is good. Controlls are easy, but in my opionion the game should also have had a hard mode. Its way easier to beat than the former games. Ironically the game seems harder to me in the beginning when you only start with 2 heart containers... later you easily upgrade to half demage and collect like 10 more Heartcountainers. Only in Bossfights you can run into trouble of losing all energy then.- That aside there are lots of items to search for. Stying true to a metroidvania like game you can only reach certain upgrades and items after you got something else at other places.The Main story (including collecting all sidequests items) can be done in around 6 hours of a first playthrough.However, I am certain the game will be longer once the developers publish the promised DLC's.So keep checking from time to time when you played it through.

Posted: December 20, 2016
												Gotta get that right off the bat: I'm one of 18.500+ backers that made this game possible and I'm happy how it turned out.You play as Shantae, a half-genie and sole protector of Scuttle Town, ready to defend it against any threat. She uses her long, purple hair as a weapon, alongside few offensive and defensive spells. Her magical heritage allow her to perform a variety of belly dances that transform her into various forms, each with different uses. For example, she can turn into a crab and a mermaid, but only her crustacean form can snap through tangled vines, while as a water nymph she can swim properly and attack with bubbles.Even though it is a part of a series, you absolutely don't need to play any other Shantae game. All characters from previous installments (plus few new faces) make a return and are properly reintroduced. Plot is once again silly with tongue-in-cheek, self-aware humor sprinkled all over. There are six levels in total, but as you unlock new abilities you can replay them to find numerous hidden collectibles and secrets. This time WayForward went for HD graphics instead of pixel art I dare say it turned out pretty well. All character models are hand drawn, big, colorful and wonderfully animated. They mesh really well with lush, detailed backgrounds.Not everything is shiny though. Sometimes a tool tip or two would be helpful. For example, it took me half of my play through to realize that you can jump directly down through some platforms. There are also few frustrating sections that simply require player to memorize sequences of obstacles by trial and error. That wouldn't be much of a problem if it weren't for inconsistent checkpoints. Thankfully you can obtain a special dance to skip sections of a previously completed levels. Levels that try their hardest to hide that they are way too short and  you will be revisiting them many times even if you don't want to get 100% of items. Story is also noticeably weaker compared to previous Pirate's Curse, where Shantae, Risky and each side-character had a story arc.Finishing the game took me around 7 hours and unlocked new game plus mode. There is at least one planned free DLC (for backers) with (supposedly) brand new story. There might be more content coming along the way based on stretch goals, which may or may not turn it into best Shantae game to date.A solid entry in the series, slightly below Pirate's Curse. Recommended.

Posted: December 21, 2016
												This game blows me away. The art style is new and absolutely beautiful (just look at the trailer), the mechanics are the same as the previous games but tweaked and improved so it just feels better overall, and the soundtrack has got me unreasonably hyped the entire time. Level design seems to have much more thought put into it, beating Risky's Revenge and of course Pirate's Curse. I really wish I backed this on Kickstarter, but it was already funded by the time I got into the series. Absolutely, 100% worth it. The art and visuals left me extremely impressed, especially.Also, the technical difficulties of the first two games seem to be absent here. (No framerate or resolution problems. Running at 1440p 144hz, settings were autodetected correctly.) It seems to be capped at 60fps, but that's only noticeable when the camera is panning, for the character sprites and UI don't really need it.Make sure not to play this if you haven't first played Risky's Revenge and then Pirate's Curse. They both go for really low prices on sale.+ Art and visuals are amazing+ Same witty humor, which I personally really enjoy+ Mechanics control so well, noticeable improvement over previous games+ THAT SOUNDTRACK.+ Level and boss/fight design is very thought out. This is a very welcome improvement over the previous games, especially Pirate's Curse. I'm impressed, I must say.~ A little fast paced. At times I would like to stop and admire the scenery a bit more.- Can't think of any constructive criticism. I will update if anything jumps out at me.

Posted: December 23, 2016
												I'm not generally given to reviewing games, as there are others more qualified (or at least willing) to get into the nitty-gritty of such things. That said, if you love gaming in general, and side-scrolling 2.5D platformers in particular, you owe it to yourself to check out this little gem. It's adoreable. It's winky and fun, without being precious about it. The controls are smooth, the action is plentiful and occasionally challenging, and every new location, interaction, or character has something to delight the senses.Perhaps the highest praise I can give this game is that it took me back to my earliest days of gaming on the NES, when all you had to do was press start and immerse yourself in FUN. I know we're not supposed to enjoy things unironically anymore, but I'm having me some fun. You should, too.

Posted: December 23, 2016
												Caution: While my end result is that I do recommend the game, I do not heavily recommend it like I would with snap-buy titles.I've enjoyed Shantae throughout the years. Pirate's Curse is, to me, the best game of the series and sadly, Half-Genie Hero does not surpass that game's level. It has too many flaws for that.For one, the past games had a sense of exploration. Big worlds which you'd discover all kinds of new things in when going through them later on, metroidvania style. Half-Genie Hero...tries to have that, but the worlds are just so tiny. There's a feeling that there should be more, but there simply isn't.The end-game also has a very strong "Collect 10 Bear Asses" feel to it. Just padding to make the game last a bit longer for those who want to get the proper ending. While it is a tradition for Shantae games to do something like that, it never felt as obvious as it does here. Then there's the various forms you can take. Some just feel a bit tacked on, like the Spider form which you need only for one little thing, and is never needed again except for an achievement. The Crab form also feels redundant with the Mermaid form around, with only a very few small things ensuring you must use it.Finally, the game is on the short side. 7.5 hours for 100% completion without actually rushing through the game...it's not horribly short, but I had hoped for longer.Having said that, these aren't huge problems. The gameplay itself is smooth as ever, perhaps even smoother than before. The flow of most of the game is perfect, the enemies are nice and varied, the level design itself, while small, is very well done, so gameplay wise there's nothing really wrong with the game.The graphics are also top notch. A lot of work has gone into the animation and it shows, the game looks fabulous. The music also helps, the ever-present ear worms keep up a great tone.Finally, the absurd and hilarious conversations are, as ever, another highlight of the game. It does refer it's predecessors a fair bit which might be annoying if this is your first Shantae, but even for those people there's plenty of good humor to go around.All in all, I think that this game's biggest problem is the existence of Pirate's Curse. That game set a very high bar that Half-Genie Hero falls just short of. I definitely do not regret the purchase, I had just hoped for a bit more after the kickstarter and the various postponings. The game is technically very well done, it just lacks that bit of punch.7/10.

Posted: December 22, 2016
												Shantae is one of my favorite game series of all time. While other reviews will talk about the great level design, the (occasionally) amusing writing, the phenomenal music (thanks to Jake Kaufman). I'd like to talk about the thing I truly love about the shantae series (excluding the original).The game engine in these games is flawless. The greatest crime I feel a platformer can commit in my opinion is have a poor engine. If I ever feel like missing a jump is the game's fault, or some BS pixel perfect jump requirements, then it is a bad platformer. This is never the case in Shantae. Shantae always lands from every jump exactly the way I expect based on the buttons I pressed. If I miss a jump, it is clear and obvious what I did wrong. I timed it wrong for the moving platform, I misjudged the arc, an enemy attack threw me off. I never fight the controls, and I never yell at the screen "OH THATS BULL, I MADE THAT JUMP". Hard sections feel challenging, not frustrating.That right there, the silky smooth controls and rock solid engine, are the best part of this game and its predecessors (except the original, lets not talk about the original....)UPDATE:Now that I'm less starry eyed from just finishing the game. I'll give my honest opinion to long time fans of Shantae. The biggest difference in this game is the style of level design. Its less metroidvania, more mega man. This isn't a bad thing, its just different. Levels are less about being labyrinths, and more about combining enemy placement and platforming to create a challenge. To those that prefer the labyrinth style designs, Shantae and the Pirate's Curse remains your best bet. To those that prefer stuff like Mega Man X, this game is perfect. To those that like both, like me, both games are awesome.

												Half-Genie Hero isn't as good as Pirates Curse but its still a great deal of fun and well worth the price. The game goes back to the Risky's Revenge style over Pirate's Curse with a focus on Shantae transforming into various creatures in order to traverse the world, however the developers have said that the promised "Risky Mode" will include a move set similar to Pirates Curse on top of future game modes for Sky, Rotty, and Bolo.The overall game plays well, there is quite a bit of creativity in each level and the same kind of humor you would expect from a Shantae game. Transforming does kind of slow down the pace of the game some, but there is upgrades to speed it up and once you get used to each form you'll start to be able to recognize when is the best time to use them. The only negative I really have with the game is its too easy, there are far too many heart containers and too many ways to refill your health, magic would be the balancer here but then there is also upgrades to reduce the amount of magic your spells cost.Still at the end of the day if you like Shantae then you'll like this game: Its a fun game with a good art direction and cute girls, whats not to love?

Posted: December 22, 2016
Half-Genie Hero is Ret-2-GoHalf-Genie hero is the fourth installment in the Shantae series, and each entry manages to impress in new ways. Half-Genie Hero's visuals are its most impressive feature, from the artwork to the animation, its all very good. I liked this game a lot, but I think it does have a few minor shortcomings.Pros +++ Visuals, they're great. The character portraits are nice, the models and sprites fit the style well, and the animations accentuate character personalities+++ Soundtrack, it's very good, each area has a unique track that sets the mood well++ Level Design, the levels are nicely designed, each new ability that is unlocked makes them easier to traverse in some way, as well as unlocking new areas in previous levels, new enemies appear in previous levels after clearing them as well+ Gameplay, transformations add a fresh take on the playstyle of Pirate's Curse, but transforming back and forth between them can sometimes feel tediousCons- Length, as a metroidvania game, short lengths are to be expected and replay value is where play time comes from. However, in comparison to Pirate's Curse I found this game to be shorter without much justification gameplay-wise-- Difficulty, Half-Genie Hero is an easy game. The ability to toggle upgrades helps to add an artifical challenge should it be desired, but for a casual player the base game is hardly challenging, especially compared to Pirate's CurseOverall, Half-Genie hero is an excellent game. I never felt frustrated with it, and that made it a fun experience. Even though it was an easy game, the effort WayForward put into creating and polishing this title was evident. With more content coming next year and a 10% discount on the game, I wholly recommend giving Shantae: Half-Genie Hero your consideration.

												Excellent game! The graphics are awesome, with very fluid animations, and the gameplay is great and fun. Posted: December 23, 2016
												Shantae: Half Genie Hero is the 4th installment of  developer WayForward's Shantae series and the first to be funded by the fans via Kickstarter. Despite being overlooked and criminally under funded when compared to the likes of the now long forgotten Mighty No 9, Wayforward has once again have shown their true talents as a game developer.HGH is the first Shantae game that's in full HD.  It's also a more linear adventure, although there are secrets and hidden areas to find and discover. There are a total of 6 levels. Each broken into 3 to 4 stages each with a boss waiting at the end of each level. In this new adventure Shantae has more transformations at her disposal that totals up to 12 forms she can use. The animations and the overall look of HGH is possibly the best visualls WayForward has brought to the table with the series. The soundtrack has once again hit another home run thanks to series composer Jake Kaufman and also credit to Shantae's voice actress Christina Vee for lending her talented voice in main theme. Pros:-Beautiful visuals that match with the equally vibrating soundtrack-Shantae's arsinal and transformations is the most varied in the series yet-Each of the 6 levels do well to make use and compliment the way the transfomations are used in certain situations-Gameplay is simple, but does offer some complexity-The 6 levels are varied and offer plenty of action platforming that doesnt get dullCon:-Short playthough that could be completed around 6+ hours on a blind run-4 of the transformations are forgeteble and are hardly used-Certain pickup items can make Shantae go extremely OP-Difficulty is easiest entry out of the entire seriesVerdict: Despite the game's shortcommings, this is still one of the better Shantae titles released being behind The Pirate's Curse. It doesn't change the formula too much, but rather it gives it a bigger, HD paint-job. This is an easy buy, but may want to wait for a sale and/or DLC to come out for additional content.

												Shantae: Half-Genie Hero surprised me. Good and original platformers are getting more and more rare. The gameplay is fun and responsive, I got used to the transformations, they add a variety of different ways to play the game. But the pacing does suffer, especially later on, when you get a lot of transformations and have to shuffle through them all. The story is very basic but it is very charming, it gives the game a fun and light feel. The hub world can get annoying because it isn't always clear what you have to do, to move on to the next level, and you have to return to the same levels allot and search for that one thing you need to move on to the next level. It sometimes felt like I played the same level 10 times. I feel like they didn't put in everything they wanted to in the game, either because they didn't have time or some other reason. So they make you play the same thing again and again. And the boss levels are Iâm sad to say too easy and repetitive. Overall though I really enjoyed the level design in Shantae: Half-Genie Hero, even though I got sick of playing the same levels, it has some game design ideas I haven't seen before. And I really like the graphics, it is one of my favorite games this year. But it was a bad year for me, so that doesn't say much. It is still just barely an above average game. Games like, Shovel Knight, Ori and the blind forest and Super meat boy are much better.6 out of 10. It makes me wonder why it took so long to release the game, development issues maybe?

Posted: December 20, 2016
												As a Kickstarter I got the game 2 weeks early for being a Backer.I personally enjoy this game, so much that I'm going to also be speedrunning it quite often.But this is a review so I'll give my review.Pros:Beauitfully done animationJake Kauffman comes through again with one of his best soundtracks yetFan Service, Fan Service, Fan Service!Enjoyable StoryAll the enjoyable Shantae gameplay is still thereDLC will have Risky Mode, more costumes and hero modes when released.As a Kickstarter, the DLC will be free for meCons:Short, first time playthrough averages 5-6 hoursUntil DLC comes out, not much replayability aside from Speedrunning/Hero modeHaving compeated with Mighty No. 9 during the kickstarter - It didn't get as much backing, so content is considerably lacking due to it even with the upcoming DLC.More linear, lost quite a bit of the Metroidvania feel and less exploration.Non Kickstarters have to pay for DLCNeutrals:It's easier, which can be a con to some. But after the terror that was Shantae and the Pirates Curse platforming, it was welcoming.Animations are beautiful, but feels like they are missing something.As a speedrunner, the in game time is programmed strangely - Doesn't run in pause(Item) menu/dance menu and will reset to previous time if you die. Casual players won't care about this.Overall:An enjoyable game with great animation and music, though short and lacking content due to competing Kickstarters against the overly popular Mighty No. 9 at the time.I hope the sales of the game will help them get more funding to add more content to the game at a later time. :)I'll still be running it as a Speedrunner, as mentioned above, very very ofter as I enjoyed the game quite a bit.

Posted: December 20, 2016
												DISCLAIMER: I am a backer of this title and paid $55.A project started 4 years ago has come to fruition and I'll be honest, it easily makes my personal game of the year. Playing similar to previous titles like Ducktales Remastered, A Boy and his Blob, and various other titles by the company it shows that Wayforward has not lost it's touch with making platformers. Bright, cheerful and a difficulty that ranges from easy to difficult without being a cackewalk or mind-numbingly difficult. Often compared to Mighty No. 9, Wayforward delivered on something that Comcept failed to do so: a relatively smooth game that has very intuitive gameplay mechanics and stages that put the mind to work as much as the fingers. The bosses, while really large (HUGE in some cases) all have a very capable strategy to beat. To add, while there are cases of a large number of enemies, I never felt at any point where I was forced to take a hit, making untouchable runs a fun challenge. To add, as with most Wayforward titles there is a game clock so speedrunners are going to have fun optimizing this game. The music and voices are superb as always with variations of Jake Kaufman (Wayforwards cheif Maestro) and Cristina Vee's (the voice actor for Shantae amongst others and the lead singer) "Dance Through the Danger" interspecced throughout amid an incredible selection of other music.As good as the game is, it is not perfect however. There are two nagging issues. The dances are not as dynamic as the tools from Pirate's curse though the mechanic has been improved from previous iterations, utilizing a radial menu system instead of button presses or timing cues. However there are three panels of four icons that cycle automatically, slowing down the gameplay. This can be sped up with a store purchase but that also has the drawback of accidentally picking the wrong dance. Second, like Ducktales Remastered the game is laid out in a stage format as opposed to a single world format like the original game or Risky's Revenge and each stage has a LOt of stuff to collect, often requiring special hidden dances and abilities. This necessitates a LOT of backtracking in the stages, in some cases being required to progress. Personally, not a huge issue but it can frustrate players. Both of these issues are relatively minor and only impact the game in marginal ways. Overall, another fantastic game from an incredible team who have the support of their fans. People on the fence waiting to know whether it will be any good or not can rest easy knowing that Wayforward can still deliver a fun game with a mix of fast paced gameplay, humorous characters and story, and a bright, colorful world.

Posted: December 24, 2016
												Overall a very fun game with solid controls in which you start out really weak and get exteremly broken by the end of the game...so much so that you feel invinicbile (i dont think i ever died in this game and came the cloest to dying on the first level due to how weak shantae starts out)unlike most games of this genre, when you beat a boss you get a new transformation then usually you have to backtrack through a level you beaten again to find more upgrades (and this isnt optional the game halts and forces you to do this to continue the story and it happens every time)...this may sound like a negative but since you just got a new transfomation and became even stronger, it wont seem like backtracking through a stage and you might find optional upgrades to make the rest of the game even easier...and thats the charm of the game, you really feel the progression of the main character who starts out super weak with very traditional moveset you will see in most platformers then slowly start breaking the mold once you start finding upgrades and start going back to levels that gave you headaches in the past and just watch them get broken apart due to your new abilites.Also you eventually get a warp spells so you can skip unneccary parts of a level to find that 1 upgrade or part you need in a level you already beaten and you can leave the level at anytime you want if you gotten everything you need...it does become super easy at the end when you can go invinicbile at will, fly over the whole stage, and have so many heart containers that theres no way the enemy can kill you but ya you sorta earned that right? though hard work and upgrading yourself...its not a hard game in the slightest but its so much fun when you are so strong at the end of the game and it feels justified with all the time you spent on making shantate stronger...Lastly this game is getting dlc to extend the gameplay later on...and its not just skins...its new playable characters with unique gameplay styles and their own storylines so you have something to look forward too...and this game rewards speedruns so if you thought it was so easy by the end...try going for the achivements, some requiring you to speedrun the game...

Posted: December 26, 2016
												Pretty much the first Shantae game I ever completed and for good reason. This game involves a lot of backtracking, which is the reason I guess fans are disappoint. As a person who usually hates backtracking more than any other video game mechanic, I have to say this is the one of the few games that did it right.Gameplay:Pros-As I tried to imply, I barely know much about Shantae or the gameplay so overall how I can describe this game as the love-child of the Paper Mario series and Donkey Kong Country. As I said, a 'lot' of the game revolves around backtracking, yet it honestly didn't feel at all like a chore. It flows well for this type of game as levels feel brand new or updated once you acquire more power ups and dances. My fear when I purchased this is that the animal dances were going to be used as gimmicks for obstacles and puzzles, but there are several situations where you can get through a level more efficiently than base Shantae.Cons-This game goes from delightfully challenging(while annoying on a few parts) to being way too easy. You'll get multiple hearts and food to keep them full forever later in the game, despite the x9 limit for each food. Combining her hair whip with the spike balls/scimitar magic could pretty much smash virtually every enemy away with ease. In fact, magic is immensely unbalanced in this game. You could literally just only purchase the weapon summoning and barrier magic then still beat the game with ease. The difficulty jump and lack of checkpoints can get annoying at times, if you fall off or run into a spike then 2-3 minutes of platforming is basically gone.Story:How can I describe it? It basically feels like a Saturday morning cartoon. I don't mean that in a negative or positive way. The dialogue feels witty and the characters keep the liveliness of the game going. Even though I found it funny, I actually felt characters taking catastrophic events to lightly to be rather museless about. The main characters seemed a bit cookie cutter, but they were solid through and through. Even though it was mostly Shantae doing the work, you enjoyed the moral support you was giving from your friends. It's hard to go too deep into it without spoiling. The town NPCs felt like characters in the beginning, but then they reverted into mere hint givers. Overall, I did find it awesome how a simple anti-monster Beacon turned into genie corrupting war machine.Music:Overall it was enjoyable to play through the game, but it didn't feel memorable aside from maybe the slide theme. Although, I can't get over Shantae dancing to the town theme.Overall:I give it a 7.5/10. Despite a lot of my nit-pickings(and a couple more I didn't mention without spoiling), there was nothing in this game that was game breaking. The platforming by itself is... decent. What saves the game is the versatile abilities and how you can use them to get through puzzles along with faster methods to defeat enemies. It also could've been 'much' longer, yet seeing how this is a Kickstarter game it's understand they had to use the funds they were given in such a little time.

Posted: December 26, 2016
												A decent platformer, but with it has its faultsI was a huge fan of the previous game in the series, and I was very excited to play this, unfortunately some things feel like a step backwards rather than forwards. There, however, are a lot of things to love here: The art is fantastic, and is easily one of the best looking platformers you can play on PC. The music, as composed by the great Jake Kaufman (Shovel Knight/Mighty Switch Force)  is generally top notch, although a few tracks (such as the last two parts of the game) I found very underwhelming. The levels are extremely fun the first time through, they all have fun gimmicks to them that make them stand out among the others, but you will be doing a ton of backtracking to find items, which can feel like a chore, and make the levels feel very small after a while, I know it was done to lengthen the game, but it spreads too thin, and I'd have preferred a 3-4 hour game that stayed fresh than a 7-8 hour game where you constantly comb through the same areas.The boss fights are hit and miss, not horrible for a platform game (a genre not generally known for good bosses, outside of megaman and metroid) but not as challenging or charming as they were in Pirate's curse.The biggest positive of the game by far is the transformations, there are tons of forms Shantae aquires and they all have fun and unique properties that change up the game a lot, and they all look dang cute.I give this game a soft reccomendation, but hope there will be more that feels in line with Pirate's Curse in the upcoming Risky Boots campaign, as it was left feeling pretty dry at the end.Still, one of the better platformers on steam, and for 20 dollars it's not a bad way to kill a few hours.

Posted: December 25, 2016
												This is a fun platformer game which has elements from some fantastic old games like Aladdin, Rocket Knight Adventures and Quackshot but also adds some new things to the mix.The platforming experience is overall fun but the story elements that glue the game together feel tedious; especially the errands in town that are required before moving on...One thing that I think could be massively improved in a patch is the morph screen that appears when you press the Y button on the game pad. When you have multiple pages of morphs it flashes between them in a really awkward way. It's way too fast and disorienting for no good reason. It would be better if there was just a single screen that you can select from; or, if you used LB/RB to change page.All in all this is a top notch game and I would recommend to anybody that enjoys platformers.

Posted: December 26, 2016
A Solid PlatformerI've looked forward to this game for a while and it had not failed to deliver. The visuals are a mix of beautifully drawn characters within a colourfully crafted world. The music also doesn't fail to bring you deeper into the world that has a blend of a megaman x/sonic feel to them. Controls are tight and responsive giving you the needed accuracy to navigate some of the hair line dangers. Level design is that of a stage select with some backtracking through previous areas. The only problems I have with that is you would get a power that at some point only serves a single purpose instead of being used multiple times and once certain areas have been completed they feel like they have lost their charm in some way (mermaids and tower).If you are looking for a decent platformer with a decent amount of puzzle solving then this game is for you.

												This is an amazing game and everything I wanted from a platformer! The characters are very charismatic, the mechanics are solid and the script made laugh many times. Posted: December 21, 2016
												Due to character limit, this is a brief review compared to my more detailed one on my website. See it HERE[www.omaralikaj.com]. Here here a lot things I liked about the game, and a few I didn't:PROS:Interesting plot, and sub-plots and missions, plus funny and what-on-earth moments.Transformations, acquired from the messenger, item shop, or snake merchant make a fun gameplay. Unlike Mario, they're essential in clearing certain areas.I like that this game is not too cryptic, but some ways of collecting items were harder than others to figure out.Great soundtracks. Having played the mobile version of "Lit", WayForward did it again.Cool audio and sound effects, but some like Shantae ducking, or the centipede making grunt sounds, felt out of place.The graphics feel like an interactive cartoon show. The stages are pretty, and surprisingly interactive.Boss fights are fun and challenging, but, getting heart holders, power-ups, items, and acquiring new forms along the way, I felt like the later ones were easy.CONS:Shantae's story at least is really short. Thankfully, the other stories/DLCs were funded via Kickstarter. The game triggers purchased certain power-ups upon controlling my laptop's volume, as opposed to just pressing "C". I avoid blowing up enemies with my flame attack when there are many of them on the screen, so the game won't crash. This happened 3x.No clarification that store-bought items are essential for 100% completion. You get "Hero Mode" after beating the game, but it feels unneeded, and only ideal for speedrun or clearing early stages and side missions quicker.The brat the Mayor replaced Shantae with, even when she was genuinely worried, WayForward still showed the same image of her being a snub in the dialogues.And finally, some stages or missions take a long time to get back to, especially the "Great Escape", where you can't get hit by a gear during first try only. Thankfully, I got this achievement during my first speedrun.

Posted: December 23, 2016
												I backed this game on kickstarter and have no regrets. The gameplay is fast-paced and highly enjoyable. The main mechanic, transforming, is very well executed and a pleasure to use. This is definitely one of those games that makes you feel powerful, jumping around and whipping things to death with hair attacks and shifting smoothly between whatever forms you need for the task at hand. I played with an XBox 360 USB controller and had no issues whatsoever. You can even rebind the buttons if you want, something not every game offers.The game has a cute but fairly light story, which is honestly perfect for it. It is enough to keep you moving without bogging you down or getting in the way of the main feature, which is the excellent gameplay. Pretty much my only issue with the game is one I knew I'd have going in. I do find the female outfits and character designs a bit silly/fanservicey (personal preference here, not an attack). That said, they don't really exploit that in gross ways like some titles do. Something I read on TVTropes seems pretty true, describing the style as 'sexy but not sexualized'. The only exception I found was the first playthrough of the second level Mermaid Factory. I found that level seriously squicky in a variety of ways.  Seriously, girls tied to some kind of assembly line looking thing, being shoved into cans to be sold (as you find out later) as *food*? That's pretty messed up. Thankfully all the disturbing elements are gone when you come back later. And to be fair this series has always had some squicky elements to its humor. I am generally pretty sensitive to this sort of thing, so if you aren't this may not bother you at all. If you are very sensitve, then, be aware. I still definitely reccommend the game, which I feel has a great deal of heart and is well worth it. I have already beat both normal and hero mode, and am looking forward to the extra content that will eventually be released.EDIT: Something I forgot to mention was the soundtrack, which I found highly enjoyable and perfectly suited to the rhythm of the gameplay. It's all instrumental with the exception of the theme song, 'Dance Through the Danger', which plays during the first run of the first level as well as during the ending credits. That song... well, let's just say that three days after playing it was still getting stuck in my head. xD
