												Straight-forward and fun.Some people may find the title lacking in the exploration department, but that does not mean this game is unenjoyable.Far from it, the pacing is well executed and there's always something to do immediately in short bursts after a main mission, such as seeking a hidden object or extra heart container or key item.Grab it when you can, have a solid 6 hours playthrough.You won't be disappointed.Well, I guess you can be disappointed if a game is "too short" for you.

Posted: January 3
												This game is worth the 20$ I spent. I'm a Huge fan of the new visuals. Shantae's model is adorable...well all the female characters are adorable both their models and illustrations. It's so clean, crisp, and very colorful. With this new style, details like facial expression are very easy to see on these new models. Every character looks amazing. The characters/items really standout from the background. So it doesn't matter if you are playing this on a teeny tiny screen or your 55" screen in the family room, it's going to look great. The game ran smoothly.Everything Shantae does looks good. Same goes for enemies. There were some hiccups, not like lag or anything but some blinks of color in spots of the screen. This could be fault with something in the game or something on my end.The levels were well designed. Many of them seem to be designed for several ways of navigation up until end in the event you miss some transformation or moves hidden along the way. On the topic of transformations. I enjoyed all but one, the one I'd have to say it is nothing more than a joke. I found the levels to be moderately difficult and some small spots kind of hard. Part of me wishes most was hard but at the same time given the number of times I treked back and forth in levels, I think perhaps moderate is for the best. If you are into time trials be it just finishing as fast as possible, getting all unlocks, or going for 100%(buying all shop items) There levels are large enough that they take a good amount of memorization and creativity to navigate them as quickly/efficiently as possible.This game also rewards those have keen eyes for finding things in the levels/taking the time to get them. I found the Mermaid level to be my favorite level. Lots of jumps, its really big. Really pretty and cute. Spoiler, don't read unless you played game  So sad that all the girls are gone after beating the boss, the level loses much of its charm, it would of been nice to have Mermaids/village girls in the background overseeing those croc guys on the hooks instead of the girlsThe last game's levels were bigger and everything was conencted. There was a lot more exploring. I really liked that bout the last game. I could care less for it all being connected but I really love big levels that can be explored because it really makes you feel like you found stuff rather than it just being inevitable that you'd come across it. I feel like Shantae's amazing hairproducts overshadowed the offensive spells, fire and electricity a bit. I would wager that if there were no basic atk upgrades that the fire and lightning spells would feel very relevant. In contrast to the shield and pike(swirling DPS) which can be used with your basic atks. Nonetheless its good to have variety. xD I almost never found out what they were because the last game stuff like that were consumables rather than learned abilities lol.I ended up getting all of the acheivements for this game. I beat it 3 times. 1st playthrough was 7hrs long 100%. The 2nd was 3hrs20min long, 100%, while the 3rd was 2hrs 14min 88%. The game was really enjoyable. I did leave wanting more. i felt that it was a bit short. Honestly I think whether it was a legit 20hr+ game or not, I'd still be left wanting. I'm looking forward to Risky's DLC which gives her, her very own campaign and unique abilities. So I will definitely be playing that whenever it comes out.Unfortunately I wasn't a backer because it ended by the time I even learned of this game. Seeing some of the other stretch goals really makes me pray this game does well and perhaps does some of them.Playing as Rottytops, Sky, or Bolo all with their own unique moves sounds amazing. A new chapter (who doesn't love more playable content.) Lastly animated cutscenes that are fully voice....................*drools*   Realistically I hope for the chapter and characters the most.The stretch goals that were not met I'd definitely pay for if they were DLC. So my only 2 real complaints are these.1 I already covered, I wish the game was longer.2 I wish some of the transformations we gained had more time to shine with much larger parts of the levels dedicated to them. Some of them were pretty neglected. The underwater ones, flying, and most definitely the spider.*3 need more Mermaids.All in all this a great game that I would recommend getting. I hope it does well and that they support it in the future.I've been stepping away from larger companies/AAA and been playing more games from smaller studios and I have been very happy with that choice.

												I'm a big fan of this series. I love the art, the writing, and the gameplay, and while I don't think this lives up to the standard that Pirate's Curse set, I enjoyed it a lot.BUT.Whoever designed the final sequence has a lot to answer for. Posted: December 31, 2016
												A very fun game with beautiful art, incredily smooth animation, good music, charming characters and silly sense of humour. Shantae games are always an enjoyable experience, and Half-Genie Hero is no exception. To make things even better, the game will still get more updates, giving us extra characters to play with unique abilities.My one complaint is that the game is too easy, and it's possible to collect an item that gives you unlimited magic, which downright breaks the game. However, we are given the option of deactivating these items, which is nice, as it helps keeping the game more challenging.The story is a bit ot a let-down as well in two senses: 1- it doesn't really follow the pllot of Shantae and the Pirate's Curse, and 2- the missions don't feel like part of a bigger adventure, IMO. They feel like episodic quests only slightly connected to each other.Still, the game is really fun to play and the animation is gorgeous! If you're looking for a light-hearted plataforming adventure with great visuals and delightful characters, this is the game for you!

Posted: January 2
												The only reason someone wouldn't like this game is if they can't appreciate the level design of repeadtedly going back into each world to find other treasures. Although it admittedly is a bit repetitive, the devs deserve props for the design of their game: each world is aesthetically pleasing and full of awesome surprises and great music. If you don't mind that, however, you're in for a real treat: 1/2 Genie Hero has the best soundtrack in the series (Jake Kaufman, who did Necrodancer and Shovvel Knight, produced a very catchy and groovy OST, the best graphics (the HD is gorgeous and runs around 60 fps consistently), and great gameplay and writing, arguably better than the others in the series. All in all, this game will make you look at belly dancers in a whole new light.

Posted: December 20, 2016
												Shantae: Half-Genie Hero surprised me. Good and original platformers are getting more and more rare. The gameplay is fun and responsive, I got used to the transformations, they add a variety of different ways to play the game. But the pacing does suffer, especially later on, when you get a lot of transformations and have to shuffle through them all. The story is very basic but it is very charming, it gives the game a fun and light feel. The hub world can get annoying because it isn't always clear what you have to do, to move on to the next level, and you have to return to the same levels allot and search for that one thing you need to move on to the next level. It sometimes felt like I played the same level 10 times. I feel like they didn't put in everything they wanted to in the game, either because they didn't have time or some other reason. So they make you play the same thing again and again. And the boss levels are Iâm sad to say too easy and repetitive. Overall though I really enjoyed the level design in Shantae: Half-Genie Hero, even though I got sick of playing the same levels, it has some game design ideas I haven't seen before. And I really like the graphics, it is one of my favorite games this year. But it was a bad year for me, so that doesn't say much. It is still just barely an above average game. Games like, Shovel Knight, Ori and the blind forest and Super meat boy are much better.6 out of 10. It makes me wonder why it took so long to release the game, development issues maybe?

Posted: December 20, 2016
												As a Kickstarter I got the game 2 weeks early for being a Backer.I personally enjoy this game, so much that I'm going to also be speedrunning it quite often.But this is a review so I'll give my review.Pros:Beauitfully done animationJake Kauffman comes through again with one of his best soundtracks yetFan Service, Fan Service, Fan Service!Enjoyable StoryAll the enjoyable Shantae gameplay is still thereDLC will have Risky Mode, more costumes and hero modes when released.As a Kickstarter, the DLC will be free for meCons:Short, first time playthrough averages 5-6 hoursUntil DLC comes out, not much replayability aside from Speedrunning/Hero modeHaving compeated with Mighty No. 9 during the kickstarter - It didn't get as much backing, so content is considerably lacking due to it even with the upcoming DLC.More linear, lost quite a bit of the Metroidvania feel and less exploration.Non Kickstarters have to pay for DLCNeutrals:It's easier, which can be a con to some. But after the terror that was Shantae and the Pirates Curse platforming, it was welcoming.Animations are beautiful, but feels like they are missing something.As a speedrunner, the in game time is programmed strangely - Doesn't run in pause(Item) menu/dance menu and will reset to previous time if you die. Casual players won't care about this.Overall:An enjoyable game with great animation and music, though short and lacking content due to competing Kickstarters against the overly popular Mighty No. 9 at the time.I hope the sales of the game will help them get more funding to add more content to the game at a later time. :)I'll still be running it as a Speedrunner, as mentioned above, very very ofter as I enjoyed the game quite a bit.

Posted: December 20, 2016
												DISCLAIMER: I am a backer of this title and paid $55.A project started 4 years ago has come to fruition and I'll be honest, it easily makes my personal game of the year. Playing similar to previous titles like Ducktales Remastered, A Boy and his Blob, and various other titles by the company it shows that Wayforward has not lost it's touch with making platformers. Bright, cheerful and a difficulty that ranges from easy to difficult without being a cackewalk or mind-numbingly difficult. Often compared to Mighty No. 9, Wayforward delivered on something that Comcept failed to do so: a relatively smooth game that has very intuitive gameplay mechanics and stages that put the mind to work as much as the fingers. The bosses, while really large (HUGE in some cases) all have a very capable strategy to beat. To add, while there are cases of a large number of enemies, I never felt at any point where I was forced to take a hit, making untouchable runs a fun challenge. To add, as with most Wayforward titles there is a game clock so speedrunners are going to have fun optimizing this game. The music and voices are superb as always with variations of Jake Kaufman (Wayforwards cheif Maestro) and Cristina Vee's (the voice actor for Shantae amongst others and the lead singer) "Dance Through the Danger" interspecced throughout amid an incredible selection of other music.As good as the game is, it is not perfect however. There are two nagging issues. The dances are not as dynamic as the tools from Pirate's curse though the mechanic has been improved from previous iterations, utilizing a radial menu system instead of button presses or timing cues. However there are three panels of four icons that cycle automatically, slowing down the gameplay. This can be sped up with a store purchase but that also has the drawback of accidentally picking the wrong dance. Second, like Ducktales Remastered the game is laid out in a stage format as opposed to a single world format like the original game or Risky's Revenge and each stage has a LOt of stuff to collect, often requiring special hidden dances and abilities. This necessitates a LOT of backtracking in the stages, in some cases being required to progress. Personally, not a huge issue but it can frustrate players. Both of these issues are relatively minor and only impact the game in marginal ways. Overall, another fantastic game from an incredible team who have the support of their fans. People on the fence waiting to know whether it will be any good or not can rest easy knowing that Wayforward can still deliver a fun game with a mix of fast paced gameplay, humorous characters and story, and a bright, colorful world.

Posted: December 22, 2016
												Half-Genie Hero isn't as good as Pirates Curse but its still a great deal of fun and well worth the price. The game goes back to the Risky's Revenge style over Pirate's Curse with a focus on Shantae transforming into various creatures in order to traverse the world, however the developers have said that the promised "Risky Mode" will include a move set similar to Pirates Curse on top of future game modes for Sky, Rotty, and Bolo.The overall game plays well, there is quite a bit of creativity in each level and the same kind of humor you would expect from a Shantae game. Transforming does kind of slow down the pace of the game some, but there is upgrades to speed it up and once you get used to each form you'll start to be able to recognize when is the best time to use them. The only negative I really have with the game is its too easy, there are far too many heart containers and too many ways to refill your health, magic would be the balancer here but then there is also upgrades to reduce the amount of magic your spells cost.Still at the end of the day if you like Shantae then you'll like this game: Its a fun game with a good art direction and cute girls, whats not to love?

												I enjoyed this game a great deal.  For me...Pros: Good platform jumping game play. (Somewhat challenging at times but always fun.)Smooth controls. (Every death was my own fault and I never felt I was fighting against the controls.)Excellent art style/graphics that felt vibrant and immersive. (The world that I saw seemed deep and detailed.) Enjoyable/Whimsical characters and a tongue in cheek story line. (It IS silly but it has an infectious cheerfulness to it.)Very good music throughout the game.  (Some of the stages have really decent scores.)Cons:Short.  (I milked as much as I could out of my first time and only got to about 9 hours. Others will do that in half.)Easy Bosses.  (Although creative and fun they are not going to be much challenge to seasoned players.)Few Stages. (Couple this with "Short" above but the world itself is crying out for places for Shantae to visit.)Summary:  I would recommend this game to anyone who likes a good 2D platformer.  I enjoyed it very much and had a smile on my face while I played it.  And for its price I'd say its worth it.

Posted: December 23, 2016
												I backed this game on kickstarter and have no regrets. The gameplay is fast-paced and highly enjoyable. The main mechanic, transforming, is very well executed and a pleasure to use. This is definitely one of those games that makes you feel powerful, jumping around and whipping things to death with hair attacks and shifting smoothly between whatever forms you need for the task at hand. I played with an XBox 360 USB controller and had no issues whatsoever. You can even rebind the buttons if you want, something not every game offers.The game has a cute but fairly light story, which is honestly perfect for it. It is enough to keep you moving without bogging you down or getting in the way of the main feature, which is the excellent gameplay. Pretty much my only issue with the game is one I knew I'd have going in. I do find the female outfits and character designs a bit silly/fanservicey (personal preference here, not an attack). That said, they don't really exploit that in gross ways like some titles do. Something I read on TVTropes seems pretty true, describing the style as 'sexy but not sexualized'. The only exception I found was the first playthrough of the second level Mermaid Factory. I found that level seriously squicky in a variety of ways.  Seriously, girls tied to some kind of assembly line looking thing, being shoved into cans to be sold (as you find out later) as *food*? That's pretty messed up. Thankfully all the disturbing elements are gone when you come back later. And to be fair this series has always had some squicky elements to its humor. I am generally pretty sensitive to this sort of thing, so if you aren't this may not bother you at all. If you are very sensitve, then, be aware. I still definitely reccommend the game, which I feel has a great deal of heart and is well worth it. I have already beat both normal and hero mode, and am looking forward to the extra content that will eventually be released.EDIT: Something I forgot to mention was the soundtrack, which I found highly enjoyable and perfectly suited to the rhythm of the gameplay. It's all instrumental with the exception of the theme song, 'Dance Through the Danger', which plays during the first run of the first level as well as during the ending credits. That song... well, let's just say that three days after playing it was still getting stuck in my head. xD

Posted: December 30, 2016
												The first couple of hours of Half-Genie Hero are really good, but there are problems which become apparent as the game goes on. Pirate's Curse is my all time favourite platforming game, so I concede that I may be judging this game more critically due to the high bar its predecessor set. For the sake of simple formatting, I'll make a pros/ cons list. Pros The OST is really fun and varied - there are some funky, catchy songs mixed in here.  For the most part, the animation is great, especially on Shantae herself. Most of the animations have a certain bounce to them, which compliments the music. The controls feel tight and responsive.  Being able to transform into a bunch of 'Shantae-ified' objects and creatures is really cool. It's certainly swooped in and stolen Momodora 4's '2016's Best Game With A Transforming Anime Girl' award.  The general tone of the game, in terms of presentation and writing, are really light-hearted and upbeat. The game has this sex-positive vibe without taking things too far, and I personally enjoy the sense of humour in the writing (e.g. fourth wall breaking). Cons The level design isn't very intricate. It's too often just a straight shot from left to right, with a few little extras to find here and there. In comparison, Pirate's Curse's levels felt more Metroidvania-ish in design, looping around or reusing rooms in interesting ways.  There's a lack of variety. Since transformations are this game's core mechanic, it's basically just a series of platforming challenges with slightly different rules introduced throughout (e.g. 'you can swim now', 'you can climb walls now'). Again, comparing to Pirate's Curse, those out-the-blue levels, where it turns into a runner, stealth or puzzle game, are almost non-existent.  The game's way too easy, and I'm not a person who usually cares or complains about challenge. There's just such an abundance of healing items, and enemies do so little damage. There came a point where I wasn't really engaging with boss fights, but instead just standing there, whipping constantly, because that's all I had to do to win. Once you have Shantae's hair fully upgraded, bikini armour and a few heart containers, enemies may as well not exist.   Some of the transformations feel redundent (and I'm not including the ones which are redundant by design, for comedy). For example, (avoiding spoilers) I feel the first two transformations assigned to D-Up could easily have been combined to be one form. Transforming is a cool mechanic, but with so many, it slows the pace of the game down. I feel as though dropping some forms in favour of fleshing out some other's movesets would've helped the pacing of the game.  The backtracking feels like padding. I don't recall feeling this way about Pirate's Curse, so I'm not sure if there's just more fetch-quests here, or if the level design is part of the reason for this feeling.  The world-building is weaker than past games. The hub area, Scuttle Town, though more refined in terms of utility, feels more restricted and shallow.  There aren't any real narrative stakes. The episodic nature does work, but there isn't really anything tying it all together (unlike Pirate's Curse, with both Risky's and the Ammo Baron's plotlines). I was hoping the new town genie would play a larger role, but that narrative thread ends way too early.  I feel bad for writing so many negative opinions about the game. Again, I think I'm biased towards being critical because I hold Pirate's Curse really highly. I appreciate that Half-Genie Hero tried something a little different, rather than just rehashing the last game. It's obvious that I'd recommend Pirate's Curse above this game, but I honestly think it comes down to preference. Overall, it's still a fun platformer with an upbeat atmosphere and some compelling gameplay mechanics.

												I really enjoyed Shantae and the Pirates Curse but this game seems to be a total bore compared to it.Do not get me wrong, it's well made. But I'ven't seen as much hand holding ina game as this. You have a spell that shields you from almost everything, and then you have a spell that heals you completely. On top of that, if you go around and collect all the keys to unlock the concept art gallery you'll get an item that gives you unlimited magic! Why so much hand holding? The Final boss is a joke by the way, regardless if the game has 2 endings (I think squid baron was harder) I like the art of the game, it's not pixel art it's stylized and it works nicely. The voice acting is pretty much ... the same (wish there was more) There are some very tedious sliding levels, while the first one is ok, the second one is ok, I thought the last one was pushing it. Not in terms of skill level but rather how long it was, I ended up basically memorizing it to completion. And backtracking is another thing, there's virtually no reward for finding items in this game because you buy an item to make your hair do more damage. You buy a spell to completely heal you. You buy this, you buy that. The items that you find are usually worthless. The spider form is only useful in like 2 areas so why does it even have an attack? On top of all of this the game lacks the comedy aspect that was delivered in The pirates curse. It's just so bland I found myself just trying to complete it as fast as possible. I'm only recommending because I still liked the game, it's just a slight dissapointment to the shantae franchise.

Posted: January 6
												Were you disapointed by Mighty Number 9?  Well look no further then Shantae: Half-Genie Hero for an example of how both kick starters and platformers can be done well.  I didn't much care for the original Shantae, and thought Risky's Revenge was only just okay.  I did love Pirate's Curse, but when I heard this Shantae was going back more to its roots with the dance transformations I admit to having been concerned.  I was also worried about the art style, which looked much more cartoony then the previous games, as well as all the 3d elements which felt unnecessary in a 2d platformer.I'm VERY happy to say all my fears were unfounded.  This game is FANTASTIC.  You can really tell these developers are learning from each of their releases, with each one taking the best of the previous games, dropping the bits that no one cared for, and then just further expanding and refining everything people liked.  S:HGH has the speed and creativity of Pirates curse, while making the transformations finally into something fun, something I looked forward to getting.  The music is as fantastic as ever, while the art, while admittedly more cartoony, looks incredible and really feels like it fits.  Even the 3d is used in just the right proportions such that it actually feels like it adds instead of takes away from the experience.Wayforward has officially gone from a little developer I wanted to see succeed, to one whose legitimately earned my trust and support going forward through top notch quality content that.  If you like platformers at ALL, you owe it to yourself to give this game a chance.  If you didn't like Pirates Curse, I'm not sure this game will change your mind, but if you felt the original and Risky's Revenge were over hyped, I strongly urge you to give this one a chance.

Posted: January 3
												This game is worth the 20$ I spent. I'm a Huge fan of the new visuals. Shantae's model is adorable...well all the female characters are adorable both their models and illustrations. It's so clean, crisp, and very colorful. With this new style, details like facial expression are very easy to see on these new models. Every character looks amazing. The characters/items really standout from the background. So it doesn't matter if you are playing this on a teeny tiny screen or your 55" screen in the family room, it's going to look great. The game ran smoothly.Everything Shantae does looks good. Same goes for enemies. There were some hiccups, not like lag or anything but some blinks of color in spots of the screen. This could be fault with something in the game or something on my end.The levels were well designed. Many of them seem to be designed for several ways of navigation up until end in the event you miss some transformation or moves hidden along the way. On the topic of transformations. I enjoyed all but one, the one I'd have to say it is nothing more than a joke. I found the levels to be moderately difficult and some small spots kind of hard. Part of me wishes most was hard but at the same time given the number of times I treked back and forth in levels, I think perhaps moderate is for the best. If you are into time trials be it just finishing as fast as possible, getting all unlocks, or going for 100%(buying all shop items) There levels are large enough that they take a good amount of memorization and creativity to navigate them as quickly/efficiently as possible.This game also rewards those have keen eyes for finding things in the levels/taking the time to get them. I found the Mermaid level to be my favorite level. Lots of jumps, its really big. Really pretty and cute. Spoiler, don't read unless you played game  So sad that all the girls are gone after beating the boss, the level loses much of its charm, it would of been nice to have Mermaids/village girls in the background overseeing those croc guys on the hooks instead of the girlsThe last game's levels were bigger and everything was conencted. There was a lot more exploring. I really liked that bout the last game. I could care less for it all being connected but I really love big levels that can be explored because it really makes you feel like you found stuff rather than it just being inevitable that you'd come across it. I feel like Shantae's amazing hairproducts overshadowed the offensive spells, fire and electricity a bit. I would wager that if there were no basic atk upgrades that the fire and lightning spells would feel very relevant. In contrast to the shield and pike(swirling DPS) which can be used with your basic atks. Nonetheless its good to have variety. xD I almost never found out what they were because the last game stuff like that were consumables rather than learned abilities lol.I ended up getting all of the acheivements for this game. I beat it 3 times. 1st playthrough was 7hrs long 100%. The 2nd was 3hrs20min long, 100%, while the 3rd was 2hrs 14min 88%. The game was really enjoyable. I did leave wanting more. i felt that it was a bit short. Honestly I think whether it was a legit 20hr+ game or not, I'd still be left wanting. I'm looking forward to Risky's DLC which gives her, her very own campaign and unique abilities. So I will definitely be playing that whenever it comes out.Unfortunately I wasn't a backer because it ended by the time I even learned of this game. Seeing some of the other stretch goals really makes me pray this game does well and perhaps does some of them.Playing as Rottytops, Sky, or Bolo all with their own unique moves sounds amazing. A new chapter (who doesn't love more playable content.) Lastly animated cutscenes that are fully voice....................*drools*   Realistically I hope for the chapter and characters the most.The stretch goals that were not met I'd definitely pay for if they were DLC. So my only 2 real complaints are these.1 I already covered, I wish the game was longer.2 I wish some of the transformations we gained had more time to shine with much larger parts of the levels dedicated to them. Some of them were pretty neglected. The underwater ones, flying, and most definitely the spider.*3 need more Mermaids.All in all this a great game that I would recommend getting. I hope it does well and that they support it in the future.I've been stepping away from larger companies/AAA and been playing more games from smaller studios and I have been very happy with that choice.

Posted: January 2
												If you want to play this game because of the Metroidvania style of the previous games in the series, prepare to be disappointed. But not in a bad way, by any means. This game is something else rather, more of a cross between Megaman X  and old-school Castlevania.Areas are broken up into fairly linear levels that must be re-played when you unlock more abilities in order to explore various branching paths previously unavailable to you on the first run. However, you're never forced to play any stage from beginning to end more than once, as you can get the ability to warp between all 3 parts of level and also drop out of the level at any time, keeping whatever new items you've grabbed. While it sounds a bit tedious to backtrack, the aforementioned warping plus the added mobility of your new transformation abilities really cut down on the time it takes to backtrack.The story plays out like a day in the life of Shantae, with all the offbeat humor and cute babes intact from the rest of the series. It's nothing revolutionary, but it makes a lot of shout outs for longtime fans of the series, in addition to serving as a great introduction to the world of sequin land for those who haven't played Shantae before.Overall, it's a fun game with loads of speedrunning potential. It would be apt to compare it to something like a theme park ride. A rather long wait for an ultimately short experience, but with theming and entertainment so good, I can't help but want to go again sometime later. Speaking of which, I'm looking forward to the upcoming DLC for Risky mode + Sky/Bolo/Rotty mode, which should further add replayability to this joyride of a game.

Posted: December 30, 2016
												WayForward did a good job working out this game.  In comparison to previous titles in the Shantae series, this one has the least "clunkiness" feel to it.  The game feels better streamlined.I will also say, the game will feel easy.   Once you are decently equipped with pick-ups and upgrades, the game and boss fights do get easier.  This game is built around the same premises that keeps Super Metroid in the spotlight.  Super Metroid has good replayability and is as challenging as you make it.  Shantae: Half-Genie Hero, all the same.  This game is as challenging as you make it.  If you don't want the last fights too easy, don't collect everything or put everything to full use.  Find your own challenges.The story is great and worth reading through, even though you can skip through it for a speed run.  I find the story is well balanced and fun.All being said, previous games had a Metroidvania feel.  This game is more like the Mega Man X series where you replay levels to pick up items hidden in each level.I fully recommend playing this game and the other 2 Shantae games available on Steam.  The original game is Shantae for the Game Boy Color, and WayForward has not ported or remastered it for a modern console or PC.  And this game is also the 4th game in the series, not a reboot.

Posted: December 29, 2016
												A stellar game that it's backers should feel proud to have supported.Shantae: Half Genie Hero excels in just about every category. The level design is superb, the music is fantastic, the visuals are gorgeous, and the characters are likable. Add those with one of the most unique and well-designed protagonists in gaming, and you get one of the finest games of the year. Unlike the previous installments, Shantae travels via map rather than a connected overworld. Keep this in mind if you were expecting more of a Metroidvania style game. Each area of the map counts as a chapter, with each chapter having a seperate plot, making it somewhat akin to Kirby Super Star. Assuming the player is a completionist, the game shold take roughly around 6-8 hours. Some may feel this is too short, but for me personally, I think it's fair for it's price. I do wish, however, that Risky Boot's story was availabe at purchase, and that Hero Mode gave the player access to ALL of Shantae's transformations and transformation attacks. Other than that, I find it hard to find any notable criticisms with the game itself. What I think this game really did well at was achieving it's own identity. For me, it didn't feel like "a Mega Man game" or "a Metroidvania" game. It felt like a SHANTAE game, which is something that Risky's Revenge and The Pirate's Curse, as good as those games are, felt like they were lacking in my opinion.Buy this game. It's great.

												Just bought and finished the basic game in about 6 and a half hours, Merry Christmas to me. It was the $18 price tag for the release special, but it would be $20 normally. I would recommend trying to find it on sale if you can.It was pretty good. I had a lot of fun playing it and I'm glad to be adding it to my Shantae collection. It's a little bit expensive for the length, but I think it will be much more worth the price when all of the rest of the Kickstarter-promised features get added in. Like I said, I recommend it on sale and mostly to fans of Shantae.If you own previous Shantae games, you should probably get it. If you haven't played a Shantae game before, I recommend you get Shantae and the Pirate's Curse much more.Warning: My review perspective will involve a lot of comparisons to Risky's Revenge (RR) and the Pirate's Curse (TPC) since I played all three this year.It also has a lot of gripes and may come off as slightly negative.Gameplay:The main way it deviates from the previous two Shantae games is that the levels are much more linear. Each level is divided into 2 or 3 separated sections that you have to sift through to get the collectables. It's much closer to TPC's island levels than RR's single connected overworld. No more dungeons, which is a little disappointing because I really like the previous games' dungeon designs. I think it completely loses its status as Metroidvania, even though TPC wasn't very Metroidvania. But that's fine.I felt that the platforming suffered. Shantae runs slightly too slow and jumps slightly too short to be satisfying. Platforming only felt good in monkey form. And unfortunately, transforming from human to monkey repeatedly was not great. It was much more jarring compared to RR's dance transforms because it requires more complicated inputs and briefly pauses the game. The platforming with Risky's items in Pirate's Curse can't be outdone.The dance system felt sort of "crowdfundy" with a bunch of transformations thrown in just because they could. However the transformations were generally really fun to use once you got used to it, even if some were a bit too niche. My favorites were the monkey and crab mechanics.Combat was solid. The character hitboxes and attacking animations were super smooth and fluid. The max attack speed upgrade surpassed my xbox button pressing abilities, which is kind of absurd.  It also added the spellcasting system back from RR which is fun, but pretty much optional for most of the game. Upgrades allow you to become completely overpowered very quickly.Boss designs were pretty good, all had pretty cool designs and unique mechanics. However, I did not have very much fun with the final boss, or the final level design in general.The overall difficulty is pretty low. It was the easiest of the three Shantae games I played.Story:I think it was almost a soft reboot?The story was okay. I felt like it was clearly "crowdfundy," meaning it was kind of garbled to fit a desired checklist. I had no idea what my main storyline motivation was for the first 80% of the game and I had to get invested in these little villain-of-the-week episodic stuff. But the episodic stuff was fun and amusing, so I was able to roll with it, even though some of the subplots weren't fleshed out enough. Shantae has never been known for its gripping story line, but I didn't think it was as good as the last two games.Characters:As with every Shantae game, the characters are super appealing. They are as endearing, flirty, and ridiculous as I expect out of Wayforward. The dialogue writing is clever and funny. My one big gripe is that all of the Sequin Town NPCs are just there to bombard you with hints for progression, which feels wrong. Also, some of the great characters don't get a long enough exposure because the story is so scattered.Music:Virt's work is godtier. No exeptions. I downloaded the OST (free on his Bandcamp!) immediately.Artstyle:The art is great overall. The character and world designs are top notch, and together with the music it makes a very pretty package. Sometimes the 2-D/3-D mix is a little jarring.

												Being a long time fan of Wayforward, I was thrilled to finally play "Shantae and the pirate's curse" on the Wii U back a few years ago. I've always enjoyed their use of 2d and superb animation. When I see Wayforward listed as the developer I know I've got a good looking retro game coming my way. Then I heard the new one was going to be done in 3d using cell shading. I got very worried....but Wayforward managed to keep their mojo while moving into the third dimension.We have been given a beautiful game, with drop jaw graphics...wow that mermaid boss. It also plays well, very responsive. Also still in tact is all the charm and silliness. Cute in jokes from previous games show up, a knod to long time fans. Unfortunately it is kinda short, I think shorter than Pirates curse. There is some replay value though, the collect-a-thon is always present, and the game offers treats for those who run perfect sequences.But if you love the other games, you will like this one.

Posted: December 28, 2016
												I'll keep this brief. The newest game in the Shantae series is a sure winner. Wayforward has outdone themselves in many ways with this game.The visuals are fantastic. They're clean, crisp and colorful, and the animations are really smooth for virtually every character onscreen.The audio is amazing. The compositions by Jake Kaufman are perfect to get you in the proper mood for the level and the challenge ahead. Sound effects are well done and avoid being annoying. What little voice acting is here is well done and makes me wish the voice acting stretch goal was met.Controls are spot on. Rest assured that if you get hit by an enemy or if you fall off a cliff, it's 99.9% your fault and not the controls acting up. Playing on a keyboard is alright, but a bit annoying, so I recommend using a controller for this game.The game structure is different from previous Shantae games, as it is level-based instead of metroidvania style. This allows for stronger platforming, but somehow makes the unavoidable backtracking a bit more annoying that previous entries.Using Shantae's abilites is way smoother and faster than in past games. No longer is it a chore to, for example, transform into a monkey, climb a wall, transform back into Shantae to fight an enemy, transform back into a monkey to climb more walls, then back to Shantae, then to an elephant to break a wall, then back to Shantae. The various upgrades and special powers also make the gameplay varied and more fun for all.Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is more platformer than metroidvania. It loses on fun exploration, but gains better platforming challenges. It doesn't feel as cohesive as Pirate's Curse, and the individual stories don't get enough time to develop, but it's charming to see these new, individual sides of the world. Maybe in a future game we will see a better story, but as a whole package, I found it completely satisfying.My score: 8/10

Posted: January 3
												This game is worth the 20$ I spent. I'm a Huge fan of the new visuals. Shantae's model is adorable...well all the female characters are adorable both their models and illustrations. It's so clean, crisp, and very colorful. With this new style, details like facial expression are very easy to see on these new models. Every character looks amazing. The characters/items really standout from the background. So it doesn't matter if you are playing this on a teeny tiny screen or your 55" screen in the family room, it's going to look great. The game ran smoothly.Everything Shantae does looks good. Same goes for enemies. There were some hiccups, not like lag or anything but some blinks of color in spots of the screen. This could be fault with something in the game or something on my end.The levels were well designed. Many of them seem to be designed for several ways of navigation up until end in the event you miss some transformation or moves hidden along the way. On the topic of transformations. I enjoyed all but one, the one I'd have to say it is nothing more than a joke. I found the levels to be moderately difficult and some small spots kind of hard. Part of me wishes most was hard but at the same time given the number of times I treked back and forth in levels, I think perhaps moderate is for the best. If you are into time trials be it just finishing as fast as possible, getting all unlocks, or going for 100%(buying all shop items) There levels are large enough that they take a good amount of memorization and creativity to navigate them as quickly/efficiently as possible.This game also rewards those have keen eyes for finding things in the levels/taking the time to get them. I found the Mermaid level to be my favorite level. Lots of jumps, its really big. Really pretty and cute. Spoiler, don't read unless you played game  So sad that all the girls are gone after beating the boss, the level loses much of its charm, it would of been nice to have Mermaids/village girls in the background overseeing those croc guys on the hooks instead of the girlsThe last game's levels were bigger and everything was conencted. There was a lot more exploring. I really liked that bout the last game. I could care less for it all being connected but I really love big levels that can be explored because it really makes you feel like you found stuff rather than it just being inevitable that you'd come across it. I feel like Shantae's amazing hairproducts overshadowed the offensive spells, fire and electricity a bit. I would wager that if there were no basic atk upgrades that the fire and lightning spells would feel very relevant. In contrast to the shield and pike(swirling DPS) which can be used with your basic atks. Nonetheless its good to have variety. xD I almost never found out what they were because the last game stuff like that were consumables rather than learned abilities lol.I ended up getting all of the acheivements for this game. I beat it 3 times. 1st playthrough was 7hrs long 100%. The 2nd was 3hrs20min long, 100%, while the 3rd was 2hrs 14min 88%. The game was really enjoyable. I did leave wanting more. i felt that it was a bit short. Honestly I think whether it was a legit 20hr+ game or not, I'd still be left wanting. I'm looking forward to Risky's DLC which gives her, her very own campaign and unique abilities. So I will definitely be playing that whenever it comes out.Unfortunately I wasn't a backer because it ended by the time I even learned of this game. Seeing some of the other stretch goals really makes me pray this game does well and perhaps does some of them.Playing as Rottytops, Sky, or Bolo all with their own unique moves sounds amazing. A new chapter (who doesn't love more playable content.) Lastly animated cutscenes that are fully voice....................*drools*   Realistically I hope for the chapter and characters the most.The stretch goals that were not met I'd definitely pay for if they were DLC. So my only 2 real complaints are these.1 I already covered, I wish the game was longer.2 I wish some of the transformations we gained had more time to shine with much larger parts of the levels dedicated to them. Some of them were pretty neglected. The underwater ones, flying, and most definitely the spider.*3 need more Mermaids.All in all this a great game that I would recommend getting. I hope it does well and that they support it in the future.I've been stepping away from larger companies/AAA and been playing more games from smaller studios and I have been very happy with that choice.

Posted: December 23, 2016
												Caution: While my end result is that I do recommend the game, I do not heavily recommend it like I would with snap-buy titles.I've enjoyed Shantae throughout the years. Pirate's Curse is, to me, the best game of the series and sadly, Half-Genie Hero does not surpass that game's level. It has too many flaws for that.For one, the past games had a sense of exploration. Big worlds which you'd discover all kinds of new things in when going through them later on, metroidvania style. Half-Genie Hero...tries to have that, but the worlds are just so tiny. There's a feeling that there should be more, but there simply isn't.The end-game also has a very strong "Collect 10 Bear Asses" feel to it. Just padding to make the game last a bit longer for those who want to get the proper ending. While it is a tradition for Shantae games to do something like that, it never felt as obvious as it does here. Then there's the various forms you can take. Some just feel a bit tacked on, like the Spider form which you need only for one little thing, and is never needed again except for an achievement. The Crab form also feels redundant with the Mermaid form around, with only a very few small things ensuring you must use it.Finally, the game is on the short side. 7.5 hours for 100% completion without actually rushing through the game...it's not horribly short, but I had hoped for longer.Having said that, these aren't huge problems. The gameplay itself is smooth as ever, perhaps even smoother than before. The flow of most of the game is perfect, the enemies are nice and varied, the level design itself, while small, is very well done, so gameplay wise there's nothing really wrong with the game.The graphics are also top notch. A lot of work has gone into the animation and it shows, the game looks fabulous. The music also helps, the ever-present ear worms keep up a great tone.Finally, the absurd and hilarious conversations are, as ever, another highlight of the game. It does refer it's predecessors a fair bit which might be annoying if this is your first Shantae, but even for those people there's plenty of good humor to go around.All in all, I think that this game's biggest problem is the existence of Pirate's Curse. That game set a very high bar that Half-Genie Hero falls just short of. I definitely do not regret the purchase, I had just hoped for a bit more after the kickstarter and the various postponings. The game is technically very well done, it just lacks that bit of punch.7/10.

Posted: December 25, 2016
												I would say this game is overall very good. It was a tough task to follow up the Pirates Curse, and I didn't expect a masterpiece.First of all, the music and graphics are simply great. The trailer gives you a pretty good impression of what this was going to be in that regard and I'm really loving it. The gameplay feels smoother overall than previous entries and they improved on the transformations, making the process less time consuming.That said, the transformations are my first big negative. We get a mix of old and new, but really they  break the flow of the game. That's an issue previous games had already, but it feels a lot more pronounced in this one. If you want to move efficiently through levels you will change forms a lot, and that can be a bit annoying at times. Not terrible, but I would say the older games handled this better, probably because this one has more transformations, and quite a few aren't really that useful.Similarly the backtracking feels worse in this one, probably because you only have 5 leveles plus Risky's Hideout. Going back to the same level, with minor changes when you enter the 2nd time, over and over just doesn't feel satisfying. Even worse every level basically consists of 2 main screens with secrets dispersed in between them plus a boss battle.The biggest issue for me is that everything feels so segmented. The stories of the bosses don't really have anything to do with the main plot, the levels, due to the select screen, feel just like that: levels and not a connected world. I just feel like they could have done a lot better by connecting the villains and give us pointless connection roads. Yes they take more time and can be annoying, but they make the gameworld feel connected.The levels themselves are absolutely great. They just feel well designed and fun to play, if you weren't forced to play them quite as often (if you want to get 100% of course). The bosses are also very creative, and some kind of boss rush at the end would have been really fun.Overall, I would certainly recommend this game to anyone who likes fun platformers. It's a little too easy for my tastes and could be better, but it's fun and that's what matters the most.

Posted: January 6
												This game is a great step forward for the series, and the previous entry was already pretty good. The new semi-3D graphics look awesome and are put to great use. Shantae gets a lot of forms and they all feel more organic and useful than they did in Risky's Revenge (probably thanks to the level design). Zelda-dungeons have been replaced with more megaman-style linear levels, which you could go either way on; my feeling is that the levels are much more fun and tightly-paced, and they have much better setpieces.There is a lot of mandatory backtracking, but it's not any worse than the previous games (especially if you get the warp dance). Usually by the time it wants you to return to a level a few new enemies have been added you have new forms to find hidden items in it.The only criticism I can think of is that the story is kinda all-over-the-place. Instead of pursuing an overarching "gather X plot coupons" goal you jump back and forth between unrelated plotlines that each last one level, while occasionally fetching an item for your uncle's machine from a previous level. But it still has fun characters and cute dialog, so it's ok.

												WayForward comes through with another great game in the Shantae series.Pros:The game is quite gorgeos, with great levels, characters and bosses.The bosses are all very unique and each one has a gimmick Great soundtrack, found myself liking every song in every stageLots of power ups. You'll be grabbing dances, and relics and upgrading said relics.Lots of secrets to unlock in the different levels.Cons:Wish there were a few more levels to this gameA lot of backtracking. Since there are parts of a level you won't have access until you pick up a certain item later on, you'll have to keep going back to different levels repeatedly. To get EVERYTHING in the shop, you'll have to do a bit of grinding.Overall: 4/5 stars. Easy recommendation especially for 20 dollars. 												I saw the first trailer for this game approximately one year ago, long after the kickstarter campaign had finished.I deeply regret not having been a part of crowdfunding this amazing game.As a gamer well into my 30s, I absolutely adore retro-style platformers; they inspire memories of sitting around the couch with friends trying to get past the Gutsman level in Megaman. Truth be told, I hand't been this excited or looking forward to a game like it since the release of Ori and the Blind Forest.I was blown away by the fluid, gorgeous hand-drawn animation style, the music was upbeat and perky, and the gameplay made for a classic metroidvania approach that never felt repetitive. My only quip with the game is I felt it was a little too short (given its approximate 7-hour initial runthrough), feeling it could have expanded so much more, but overall a very fun experience.If you're having second doubts about buying this game, don't. Posted: December 23, 2016
												Beautiful animations and gorgeous designs, this is definitely one of the prettiest 2.5D sidescrollers I've seen in a while. Visually, this game, is so vibrant and joyous to watch, it simply leaves you feeling good.The music is also nice and simple, having a sort of retro feel to it without the exclussive use of 8-bit samples. It feels very Early-Sonic-ish at some points, wich is high praise considering that the early Sonic games had nice, catchy and energetic tunes for each level to give emphasis to the rapid action.The game controls very much like most 2D platformers, the controls are fast and responsive and after only a few minutes they will feel like second nature. This game also adds a bit of variety with transformations, meaning that as you progress through the game you will gain the ability to transform into a variety of cratures with different abilities, but I won't spoil too much about that. This mechanic adds to the value of each level, as when you return to them with your new transformation abilities, after you played for a while, you will be able to explore more areas that you couldn't before.Now, the game in total is not all that long, in fact if you are really into it and don't do much of exploring around each level, you could easily get to the end in the same day you downloaded it. As mentioned before, bacause of the transformations, you will have to do a lot of backtracking, which it can get tedious if you are not into this sort of thing, but discovering little secrets in each level can feel so rewarding at times.Overall, it's a pleasant little game that I highly recomend to people who want a nice platforming expireince, amazing visuals and simple story that doesn't take forever to finish. It just makes me wonder; if the team had a bigger budget (the game was crowd-funded) and maybe more time, what more could have they accomplished.

Posted: December 23, 2016
												Full diclosure: I was a Kickstarter backer for this game.  After playing it, I feel like I got my money's worth.Wayforward has a good track record with 2-D platforming games (the other one I have played is Ducktales Remastered).  Half-Genie Hero is a fun, bright, easy-to-pickup game that I recommend to fans of platforming games.  The development team put a lot of effort into ensuring that this was a well-executed, polished, product. Pros: Easy-to-play, fun platforming, interesting special moves/transformations, varied/interesting stages, great soundtrack.  Accessible challenge level that doesn't ever feel unfair - no "cheap deaths." Cons:  Sometimes too easy - there is a relic/magic combination that makes the final boss trivial, but you have to do all the legwork to get everything and then realize the combination.  Other thoughts:  I recommend using a controller (my Logitech F310 worked perfectly).

Posted: December 29, 2016
												A stellar game that it's backers should feel proud to have supported.Shantae: Half Genie Hero excels in just about every category. The level design is superb, the music is fantastic, the visuals are gorgeous, and the characters are likable. Add those with one of the most unique and well-designed protagonists in gaming, and you get one of the finest games of the year. Unlike the previous installments, Shantae travels via map rather than a connected overworld. Keep this in mind if you were expecting more of a Metroidvania style game. Each area of the map counts as a chapter, with each chapter having a seperate plot, making it somewhat akin to Kirby Super Star. Assuming the player is a completionist, the game shold take roughly around 6-8 hours. Some may feel this is too short, but for me personally, I think it's fair for it's price. I do wish, however, that Risky Boot's story was availabe at purchase, and that Hero Mode gave the player access to ALL of Shantae's transformations and transformation attacks. Other than that, I find it hard to find any notable criticisms with the game itself. What I think this game really did well at was achieving it's own identity. For me, it didn't feel like "a Mega Man game" or "a Metroidvania" game. It felt like a SHANTAE game, which is something that Risky's Revenge and The Pirate's Curse, as good as those games are, felt like they were lacking in my opinion.Buy this game. It's great.

Posted: January 6
												Were you disapointed by Mighty Number 9?  Well look no further then Shantae: Half-Genie Hero for an example of how both kick starters and platformers can be done well.  I didn't much care for the original Shantae, and thought Risky's Revenge was only just okay.  I did love Pirate's Curse, but when I heard this Shantae was going back more to its roots with the dance transformations I admit to having been concerned.  I was also worried about the art style, which looked much more cartoony then the previous games, as well as all the 3d elements which felt unnecessary in a 2d platformer.I'm VERY happy to say all my fears were unfounded.  This game is FANTASTIC.  You can really tell these developers are learning from each of their releases, with each one taking the best of the previous games, dropping the bits that no one cared for, and then just further expanding and refining everything people liked.  S:HGH has the speed and creativity of Pirates curse, while making the transformations finally into something fun, something I looked forward to getting.  The music is as fantastic as ever, while the art, while admittedly more cartoony, looks incredible and really feels like it fits.  Even the 3d is used in just the right proportions such that it actually feels like it adds instead of takes away from the experience.Wayforward has officially gone from a little developer I wanted to see succeed, to one whose legitimately earned my trust and support going forward through top notch quality content that.  If you like platformers at ALL, you owe it to yourself to give this game a chance.  If you didn't like Pirates Curse, I'm not sure this game will change your mind, but if you felt the original and Risky's Revenge were over hyped, I strongly urge you to give this one a chance.

Posted: January 12
												This game is an example of how crowd-funded projects can turn out spectacularly well.  If you've played any of the Shantae games before, you already know what to expect.  If you haven't, you've clearly had a deprived, borderline abusive childhood, and I'm sorry for that.Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is a 2D platformer that, despite the HD graphics, retains its indie-esque feel.  Mechanics of the game are simple enough to pick up quickly, yet with enough depth that the game remains enjoyable many hours later (I pause to note that Steam vastly underestimates how many hours I've put into this game.  At time of writing, it's close to 20 hours).Having mentioned it earlier, I should mention that the graphics of this game are simply gorgeous.  It's an upgrade from the classic style without disrespecting its roots.Soundtrack is absolutely amazing.  Plenty of allusions to previous Shantae games that carry over with distinctive sequencing, and virtually guaranteed to be stuck in your head for hours to come.  Not that I'm complaining.With regards to the plot/story, Shantae isn't known for its compelling storytelling.  The plot is best described as 'cute' or 'quirky' and mostly serves as a vehicle by which the gameplay is delivered.  The dialogue is snappy and self-aware enough to be entertaining to read, carried by characters that are caricatures of stereotypes, but are entertaining rather than annoying.The achievement list is very reasonable with only a single 'joke' achievement, and one harder achievement for completing a 100% speedrun.  That being said, I 100%'d the game in about 10 hours in-game (which involved two full playthroughs).  If you can't be bothered to route the speedrun yourself, there are plenty of guides for it hanging around.Overall thoughts:  This game is absolutely amazing and everybody should be playing it.

Posted: March 5
												Shante: Half-Genie Hero is a good game but it has flaws that kind of ruin the game. But before we talk about those, let's talk about what the game did right first.Disclaimer: While I have only have played through the main story, these are what I like and dislike about the game.PROS:1. The level design. The game is a fairly challenging platformer with some Metroidvania elements added into mix that will keep you on your toes while looking for secrets in stages with it's megaman levels of precise platforming.2. The story. The story revolves around half human and half genie hero Shante helping her uncle build a machine called the Dynamo that will help protect her hometown, but while she is helping her uncle the barons and monsters in the land keep stirring trouble, and it's her job to travel across the land while meeting some very colorful charaters and put a stop to their evil plans.3. The Transformation dances. One of the main gameplay points is Shante's transformation dances, these dances allow her to transform into a multitude of creatures and animals that give specific abilites from swiming underwater with the mermaid to climbing on walls with the monkey and to taking it to the skies with the harpy.4.The bosses. I won't go into much detail on them, but the bosses in the game are very fun and creative, they also provide a unique challenge that make the game more interesting.Now that we covered the pros lets now go over the cons.CONS:1. The game is too short. While the game has good level design and fun bosses, there are only 6 stages in the entire game. Eventough each stage is composed of 4 segments, the game is very short. (It only took me about 8 hours to beat it.)2. 100%ing the game. Do want to know why it took me 8 hours to beat the game? Because I spent most of those 8 hours looking and grinding for all the items and equipment in the game. One of my personal gripes with Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is that completing the game is such a hassle. If you want to complete the game you will have to a METRICâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥TON OF BACKTRACKING since some of the items and stages requrire you to go back to a pevious stage and get a certain power or item(s) to progress. While the warp dance and having a guide to help you will give you less of a headache you still have to backtrack alot.Oh yeah, if you want to get all the achivements in the game, you have to speedrun all theâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥3. The Bat and Harpy transformation dances. Do you want to know how to beat half of the game? Go up to a high place and transform into one of these two free passes with wings, The bat and harpy allow you to fly, in a PLATFORMER. While you get the harpy late in the game, the bat transformation is the worst of the two since you can fly horizontal for as long as you want and you can get it in the 2nd stage!Anyway while Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is a fun and challenging game with a few issues. I would recommend it to anyone. But I highly recommend the you play it causaly if you don't to deal with the headache of completing the game.

Posted: December 30, 2016
												(Edited since the addition of hardcore mode)TL;DR: Good game, but a step back from the previous title. Initially downvoted because of lack of content, and even now I feel like the base game only barely meets the $20 asking price, especially since there will be paid DLC in the future (unless you were a backer in which case it's all free). If you're looking to get into the franchise, I would VERY strongly recommend Pirate's curse instead, or even Risky's Revenge: Director's Cut since Pirate's Curse is a continuation of that story.PROS:-Platforming is fluid and satisfying.-Absolutely amazing soundtrack. Less tracks here than PC, but what is here is golden. My only critique is that the first run of the first level had vocals which I found distracting, but that same track is also played during the credits which is perfectly fine.-Transformations are more fluid than previous games, and there are many more of them.-New art style isn't bad (chibi isn't really my thing personally, I prefer pixel sprites and Inti Creates' art style from Pirate's Curse).-Humorous dialogue. I laughed out loud on multiple occasions.CONS:-Easily my biggest issue is the switch from the metroidvania playstyle. There are no dungeons, no save stations and no open world. HGH plays more like a Megaman game. You have stages divided up into a few areas that give you a save option between them. Stages can be replayed from the beginning to collect upgrades/items previously unattainable, and later on you get the ability to warp ahead to the next area of a stage if what you're looking for is in that area, but there is no backtracking to the previous area in a stage. If you miss something in the previous area you have to restart the entire stage (warp is handy here).-Overall less content than PC, as stated before.-Story is severely lacking. Rather than an overarching plot, HGH consists of several mini-plots, none of which are very interesting.IMO, the game feels like less effort went into building the game and instead that effort went into creating new assets and engine. Probably the reason Pirate's Curse was so awesome was because it reused so many assets from Risky's Revenge, and so much more effort was able to go into the game itself. If so, then I can only hope that the next game turns out to be at least as successful as PC was by reusing assets from HGH.Also, I would absolutely LOVE to see the return of Inti Creates artwork for the next game.

Posted: January 13
												Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is in no way a bad game. It has much of what made the previous Shantae games great, like its fluid animations, great visuals, silly story and amazing music. The gameplay feels fantastic and responsive aswell. But despite the game's numerous positives, one can't help but feel a little disappointed. The metroidvania style world building and levels in the previous titles have been cut for "chapters". A chapter consists of several linear stages (go right. for the most part) and side scrollers. There are secrets spread throughout each chapter. Some you can get right away, while others you'll need a certain skill to get to. This forces you to backtrack and revisit chapters, and is a small substitution for the metroidvania styled secrets. This however doesn't make the exploration that enjoyable, as you're forced to run through the stages quite a few times to get everything. There is a dance you can get in the game called "Warp Dance", that lets you skip a previously completed stage. This helps getting to a correct stage faster, if you know there is an unacquired secret there. But you will still always start at the very beginning of a stage, so you'll always have to run through the beginning each time you want to visit the area.Another minor disappointment is the absence of a few animations that exists in the game's previous titles. Some examples are the various dance animations, a proper dodge animation, and an idle "hurt" animation. Even though they seem minor, and not too important. It all adds up, and more fluid animations helps the atmosphere of the game greatly. However, this doesn't change the fact that the game has quite a few animations already, and of very great quality.One can't help but feel that the game is missing something when coming from Shantae and the Pirate's Curse. There are many small things that if added, would add that little extra bit of polish and quality, and it would help out the game immensely. There are even concept art within the game that shows that there was so much more planned for the game, but for whatever reason was scrapped. If it is because of the lack of money or time isn't easy to tell, but it could also be because of the promises they have to deliver because of the kickstarter.These are however minor flaws. Half-Genie hero is very enjoyable for what it offers. The game oozes "Shantae" from the very beginning, and is a treat for every fan of the series. If there is one thing WayForward doesn't get (too) wrong, it's the Shantae titles. And one can tell that they really care about this series.Here's to a successful Risky dlc campaign, and future Shantae titles, because this series is absolutely splendid.

Posted: December 22, 2016
												Let me just say it first: yes! The game is pretty good.However, when you played Pirates Curse before, then may not expect a direct sequel to that. I mean, yeah, Storywise it is the continuation of the Shantae francise, but when it comes to gameplay, it's kinda more like Riskys Revenge and the first game on the GBC.And even then it is quite frankly less of a Metroidvania then before. There are no Dungeons anymore for example. Instead you got regular levels who seems more linear at the first sight, and play suprisingly more like the old Mega Man games, with focus of challenging levels with plenty of obstacles to avoid instead of the open nature with a lot of exploration what Shantae used to be (yeah, the old Games had also a lot of tricky platforming, but in this game there are way more bottomless pits and instant death Spikes like in Mega Man as I already mentioned).However, when you unlock more and more transformations (and there are a lot of them, much more then in the old titles) and revisit old areas, which the game forces you on a repeatedly routine, then you realise that there are more and more open areas hidden inside of these levels where you can find new Items and upgrades and such. And because you can buy a move which can warp you through revisited levels and later even unlock a transformation with that you can fly and skip hard platforming, backtracking isn't even that much of a problem anymore. However, there is no more Map that help you to orient, but too be honest, it isn't needed, since the levels are still quite linear.So yeah, the gameplay rocks, but sadly, the Story doesn't. Instead of a fully fletched Story, we got more like a Saturday Morning Cartoon approach with small stories that surround every level and a tiny, tiny main plot that got it's focus at the end of the game, and is pretty predictable to be honest. It's not bad, but kinda dissapointing since Pirates Curse felt more massive beause it was one big story (and the Story in that game was really good!). But that aside: It is really a good game, the second best in the series too be honest. and while I had my problems with the Story,  the gameplay, the really excellent humor and awesome Soundtrack made me forgive this one particular flaw. If you are a Shantae fan: buy this game! If this is you are a newcomer to the francise, hmmm, try Pirates curse first, or even Riskys Revenge so you can tell if you like this Gameplaystyle. But at the end it is indeed a good game!

Posted: December 22, 2016
												Let me just say it first: yes! The game is pretty good.However, when you played Pirates Curse before, then may not expect a direct sequel to that. I mean, yeah, Storywise it is the continuation of the Shantae francise, but when it comes to gameplay, it's kinda more like Riskys Revenge and the first game on the GBC.And even then it is quite frankly less of a Metroidvania then before. There are no Dungeons anymore for example. Instead you got regular levels who seems more linear at the first sight, and play suprisingly more like the old Mega Man games, with focus of challenging levels with plenty of obstacles to avoid instead of the open nature with a lot of exploration what Shantae used to be (yeah, the old Games had also a lot of tricky platforming, but in this game there are way more bottomless pits and instant death Spikes like in Mega Man as I already mentioned).However, when you unlock more and more transformations (and there are a lot of them, much more then in the old titles) and revisit old areas, which the game forces you on a repeatedly routine, then you realise that there are more and more open areas hidden inside of these levels where you can find new Items and upgrades and such. And because you can buy a move which can warp you through revisited levels and later even unlock a transformation with that you can fly and skip hard platforming, backtracking isn't even that much of a problem anymore. However, there is no more Map that help you to orient, but too be honest, it isn't needed, since the levels are still quite linear.So yeah, the gameplay rocks, but sadly, the Story doesn't. Instead of a fully fletched Story, we got more like a Saturday Morning Cartoon approach with small stories that surround every level and a tiny, tiny main plot that got it's focus at the end of the game, and is pretty predictable to be honest. It's not bad, but kinda dissapointing since Pirates Curse felt more massive beause it was one big story (and the Story in that game was really good!). But that aside: It is really a good game, the second best in the series too be honest. and while I had my problems with the Story,  the gameplay, the really excellent humor and awesome Soundtrack made me forgive this one particular flaw. If you are a Shantae fan: buy this game! If this is you are a newcomer to the francise, hmmm, try Pirates curse first, or even Riskys Revenge so you can tell if you like this Gameplaystyle. But at the end it is indeed a good game!

Posted: December 22, 2016
												Shantae is one of my favorite game series of all time. While other reviews will talk about the great level design, the (occasionally) amusing writing, the phenomenal music (thanks to Jake Kaufman). I'd like to talk about the thing I truly love about the shantae series (excluding the original).The game engine in these games is flawless. The greatest crime I feel a platformer can commit in my opinion is have a poor engine. If I ever feel like missing a jump is the game's fault, or some BS pixel perfect jump requirements, then it is a bad platformer. This is never the case in Shantae. Shantae always lands from every jump exactly the way I expect based on the buttons I pressed. If I miss a jump, it is clear and obvious what I did wrong. I timed it wrong for the moving platform, I misjudged the arc, an enemy attack threw me off. I never fight the controls, and I never yell at the screen "OH THATS BULL, I MADE THAT JUMP". Hard sections feel challenging, not frustrating.That right there, the silky smooth controls and rock solid engine, are the best part of this game and its predecessors (except the original, lets not talk about the original....)UPDATE:Now that I'm less starry eyed from just finishing the game. I'll give my honest opinion to long time fans of Shantae. The biggest difference in this game is the style of level design. Its less metroidvania, more mega man. This isn't a bad thing, its just different. Levels are less about being labyrinths, and more about combining enemy placement and platforming to create a challenge. To those that prefer the labyrinth style designs, Shantae and the Pirate's Curse remains your best bet. To those that prefer stuff like Mega Man X, this game is perfect. To those that like both, like me, both games are awesome.
