Posted: December 20, 2016
												Shantae: Half-Genie Hero surprised me. Good and original platformers are getting more and more rare. The gameplay is fun and responsive, I got used to the transformations, they add a variety of different ways to play the game. But the pacing does suffer, especially later on, when you get a lot of transformations and have to shuffle through them all. The story is very basic but it is very charming, it gives the game a fun and light feel. The hub world can get annoying because it isn't always clear what you have to do, to move on to the next level, and you have to return to the same levels allot and search for that one thing you need to move on to the next level. It sometimes felt like I played the same level 10 times. I feel like they didn't put in everything they wanted to in the game, either because they didn't have time or some other reason. So they make you play the same thing again and again. And the boss levels are Iâm sad to say too easy and repetitive. Overall though I really enjoyed the level design in Shantae: Half-Genie Hero, even though I got sick of playing the same levels, it has some game design ideas I haven't seen before. And I really like the graphics, it is one of my favorite games this year. But it was a bad year for me, so that doesn't say much. It is still just barely an above average game. Games like, Shovel Knight, Ori and the blind forest and Super meat boy are much better.6 out of 10. It makes me wonder why it took so long to release the game, development issues maybe?

Posted: December 20, 2016
												As a Kickstarter I got the game 2 weeks early for being a Backer.I personally enjoy this game, so much that I'm going to also be speedrunning it quite often.But this is a review so I'll give my review.Pros:Beauitfully done animationJake Kauffman comes through again with one of his best soundtracks yetFan Service, Fan Service, Fan Service!Enjoyable StoryAll the enjoyable Shantae gameplay is still thereDLC will have Risky Mode, more costumes and hero modes when released.As a Kickstarter, the DLC will be free for meCons:Short, first time playthrough averages 5-6 hoursUntil DLC comes out, not much replayability aside from Speedrunning/Hero modeHaving compeated with Mighty No. 9 during the kickstarter - It didn't get as much backing, so content is considerably lacking due to it even with the upcoming DLC.More linear, lost quite a bit of the Metroidvania feel and less exploration.Non Kickstarters have to pay for DLCNeutrals:It's easier, which can be a con to some. But after the terror that was Shantae and the Pirates Curse platforming, it was welcoming.Animations are beautiful, but feels like they are missing something.As a speedrunner, the in game time is programmed strangely - Doesn't run in pause(Item) menu/dance menu and will reset to previous time if you die. Casual players won't care about this.Overall:An enjoyable game with great animation and music, though short and lacking content due to competing Kickstarters against the overly popular Mighty No. 9 at the time.I hope the sales of the game will help them get more funding to add more content to the game at a later time. :)I'll still be running it as a Speedrunner, as mentioned above, very very ofter as I enjoyed the game quite a bit.

Posted: December 20, 2016
												DISCLAIMER: I am a backer of this title and paid $55.A project started 4 years ago has come to fruition and I'll be honest, it easily makes my personal game of the year. Playing similar to previous titles like Ducktales Remastered, A Boy and his Blob, and various other titles by the company it shows that Wayforward has not lost it's touch with making platformers. Bright, cheerful and a difficulty that ranges from easy to difficult without being a cackewalk or mind-numbingly difficult. Often compared to Mighty No. 9, Wayforward delivered on something that Comcept failed to do so: a relatively smooth game that has very intuitive gameplay mechanics and stages that put the mind to work as much as the fingers. The bosses, while really large (HUGE in some cases) all have a very capable strategy to beat. To add, while there are cases of a large number of enemies, I never felt at any point where I was forced to take a hit, making untouchable runs a fun challenge. To add, as with most Wayforward titles there is a game clock so speedrunners are going to have fun optimizing this game. The music and voices are superb as always with variations of Jake Kaufman (Wayforwards cheif Maestro) and Cristina Vee's (the voice actor for Shantae amongst others and the lead singer) "Dance Through the Danger" interspecced throughout amid an incredible selection of other music.As good as the game is, it is not perfect however. There are two nagging issues. The dances are not as dynamic as the tools from Pirate's curse though the mechanic has been improved from previous iterations, utilizing a radial menu system instead of button presses or timing cues. However there are three panels of four icons that cycle automatically, slowing down the gameplay. This can be sped up with a store purchase but that also has the drawback of accidentally picking the wrong dance. Second, like Ducktales Remastered the game is laid out in a stage format as opposed to a single world format like the original game or Risky's Revenge and each stage has a LOt of stuff to collect, often requiring special hidden dances and abilities. This necessitates a LOT of backtracking in the stages, in some cases being required to progress. Personally, not a huge issue but it can frustrate players. Both of these issues are relatively minor and only impact the game in marginal ways. Overall, another fantastic game from an incredible team who have the support of their fans. People on the fence waiting to know whether it will be any good or not can rest easy knowing that Wayforward can still deliver a fun game with a mix of fast paced gameplay, humorous characters and story, and a bright, colorful world.

Posted: January 22
												Half Genie Hero is another excellent Shantae game.  I've played Risky's Revenge and Pirate's Curse as well and each game has it's own strengths and weaknesses despite them being similar overall.  I've enjoyed my time with each game enough that I'm not sure I could even rank them. It should suffice to say that Half Genie hero was not a disappointment for me, but I can't say it stands head and shoulders above the other games either.First up, the game looks fantastic, maybe not quite up to par with something like Ori and Blind Forest, but it has a crisp cartoon style that's appealing and is definitely one of the best (if not *the* best) implementations of 2D sprites on 3D backgrounds I've ever seen in terms of making the two look like they belong together.The music is also great.  It conveys the feeling of upbeat chiptunes from platformers of old while still using a modern full (synthesized) orchestration.The game is still basically a Metroidvania, just with discrete levels instead of a contiguous world.  The animal transformations (which weren't in Pirate's Curse) make a return and are a welcome sight.  The level of challenge is still pretty light, with the exception of two sections in the last level which can get a tad frustrating, but aren't too bad.The one downside - the game is a little content light. There are only 5 main levels and then an ending level.  The game is structured so that you will need revist those 5 levels multiple times as you get new powers.  There's a scripted dependency where you'll get a power in one level that lets you explore a singe new area of another level, where you'll find an item which unlocks the next power in a different level and so on, at some point wrapping back around to letting you explore the next hidden area in the original level.  I.e. this isn't a game where playing through all the levels once gets you all the powers you need to unlock everything and then you can just go back to the levels one more time, getting all hidden items in one shot.That said, the game is very generous at giving you tools to warp around levels quickly and you can quit out of a level as soon as you get an item or powerup without losing it.  So despite the need to revisit the same levels, they do actually allow you to eliminate much of the tedium of retreading old ground.I was still quite satisfied with the amount of play time and the game overall for the price, but if there was just a little more unique meat on those bones, I think this would easily be the best Shantae game.

Posted: January 23
												This game is a worthy successor to Pirate's Curse. Everything about it is perfectly rounded and well finished.The controls are tight, speedrun tight. Default button mapping is perfect with an xbox controller, and has rumble feedbackIf you like visuals, you're in it for a treat: every sprite is beautifully hand drawm, and scenery is in 3D with plenty of details. The animations, as always a strong point of the Shantae series, are buttery smooth. Nearly every character and object in the game is carefully animated! This game really comes to life on screen. It was made for 1080p, but with anti-aliasing, plays at 1440p very well.The soundtrack, again as is the case with previous installements of the series, is a gift for your eartubes! Posted: February 9
												Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is an indie 2D Metroidvania platformer and the fourth installment in the series.HGH boasts an enormous visual upgrade compared to its handheld predecessors, with smooth, fluid sprites popping against gorgeous 3D backgrounds. The sprites are lovingly animated and move with a bubbling energy, often, seemingly, in rhythm with the background music.  The game is a joy to the eyes and the ears, with an aesthetic integrity that's rare in indie titles.These visuals compliment the story and characters of HGH. Shantae is surrounded by barely threatening antagonists and frequently obstructive friends, all of whom are charming and fun. Lacking a central antagonist for much of the narrative, the game is presented as a series of tangential episodes strung together by a vague goal, an undefined threat, and a series of humorous contrivances. As refreshing as this approach is, it often makes the game feel directionless. Further, whereas the previous installment gave Shantae a foil in the form of Risky Boots, HGH only casually touches upon the protagonist's relationship with her friends and enemies, making her feel unmoored in the setting.As a platformer HGH gives a solid performance. Shantae controls with precision and grace in a world that makes her limitations clear; players won't struggle against false impressions of what obstacles Shantae is and isn't capable of surmounting. Puzzles are solved by transforming into various animal and monster shapes that are unlocked over the course of the game, most often at the expense of offensive capabilities. Combat is a fairly bare-bones affair, with Shantae being limited to a melee attack that's supplemented by underwhelming mana-dependent spells.HGH is paced like a mad dash, with the game throwing power-ups and new abilities at players faster than they can find a use for them. Indeed, Shantae has a wide assortment of tools with too few obstacles to apply them to, and many of her more interesting powers go underused or are rendered superfluous by later acquisitions. Complicating this problem is all the backtracking that's required of a Metroidvania title; revisiting the game's small handful of areas quickly feels like padding, and makes replaying from the beginning feel unlikely. On the other hand, the dizzying volume of options available to Shantae by the end of the game will undoubtedly delight many players; for all of its backtracking, the sense of progress and growth is palpable.While not without its flaws, it's difficult to not recommend HGH. The game is clearly a labor of love, with an emphasis on color and energy that's uncommon in today's industry.

Posted: January 19
												I have been a fan of Shantae since Pirate's Curse, and Pirate's Curse is one of my favorite games of 2014. A new Shantae was very excited for me that the moment it went on sale and I had money I bought it and, long story short, I loved it. Now it's not as big as Pirate's Curse and 1/2 Genie Hero doesn't have dungeons like the last game but I still love 1/2 Genie Hero.   Let us start with the graphics... amazing. No joke, this is what HD sprites should look like, not just high color pixels. What made me like the graphics especially was the fact that the character portraits look like the models. Pirate's Curse had portraits similar to this game but the sprites were pixels, it created a discord between what the gameplay says characters look like and what the portraits and promo art says the characters look like.   The gameplay, on base level, is mostly the same as the previous game but with the added bonus of not having the well implemented pirate gear and replacing it with the well implemented animal transformations. The most useful to me was the monkey because of it's speed and jumping ability. Despite my previous statement on the animal transformations, there are many ways to cheat. Case in point, the bat. It is so easy and tempting to jump to the highest place on a horizontal scroll and transform into the bat and fly over every thing. Also the Harpie kinda makes the monkey and bat useless.   And now some quick thoughts on small points. The music is amazing in 1/2 Genie Hero, I recommend that you go get the soundtrack from Jake Kaufman's bandcamp page, seriously you don't have to play the game to like the soundtrack. Next, the story, it's okay. SomeCallMeJohnny put it best, it's more like a series of microstories with a big plot at the end.  I hope you found this review helpful and be kind this is my first review. Thank You!

Posted: December 28, 2016
												I'll keep this brief. The newest game in the Shantae series is a sure winner. Wayforward has outdone themselves in many ways with this game.The visuals are fantastic. They're clean, crisp and colorful, and the animations are really smooth for virtually every character onscreen.The audio is amazing. The compositions by Jake Kaufman are perfect to get you in the proper mood for the level and the challenge ahead. Sound effects are well done and avoid being annoying. What little voice acting is here is well done and makes me wish the voice acting stretch goal was met.Controls are spot on. Rest assured that if you get hit by an enemy or if you fall off a cliff, it's 99.9% your fault and not the controls acting up. Playing on a keyboard is alright, but a bit annoying, so I recommend using a controller for this game.The game structure is different from previous Shantae games, as it is level-based instead of metroidvania style. This allows for stronger platforming, but somehow makes the unavoidable backtracking a bit more annoying that previous entries.Using Shantae's abilites is way smoother and faster than in past games. No longer is it a chore to, for example, transform into a monkey, climb a wall, transform back into Shantae to fight an enemy, transform back into a monkey to climb more walls, then back to Shantae, then to an elephant to break a wall, then back to Shantae. The various upgrades and special powers also make the gameplay varied and more fun for all.Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is more platformer than metroidvania. It loses on fun exploration, but gains better platforming challenges. It doesn't feel as cohesive as Pirate's Curse, and the individual stories don't get enough time to develop, but it's charming to see these new, individual sides of the world. Maybe in a future game we will see a better story, but as a whole package, I found it completely satisfying.My score: 8/10

Posted: January 15
												Note: Playtime isn't displayed correctly, because I've played on a different system for the most part. Actual total playtime is just shy of 10 hours as of now.------------------------------Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is a short but very sweet platformer with some nicely integrated Metroidvania elements and interesting character upgrades and skills. Level design is very good for the most part of the game, the soundtrack features some very nicely remixed versions from some of the previous games and is generally fitting for the fast-paced style of the game. Character design is especially nice, with some pretty funny and light-hearted dialogues, deceptively cute drawings and brilliant animations. Just seeing the characters bob to the beat of the rhythm is truly heartwarming.The platforming itself feels good and responsive at all times and integrates the skills the game has to offer nicely.The difficulty starts off a tad on the challenging side, but actually gets progressively easier as Shantae gets more upgrades, up to the point where she's outright overpowered and some skills that pretty much break the game (talkin' about you, secret-key-bonus. ;P). Thankfully all the upgrades are fully optional and can be switched off in the menu at all times. Some transformations make platforming in some levels a little too easy in my opinion though.It took me almost 10 hours for 100% completion, but I took it pretty slowly. If you know what you're doing you can certainly beat it much faster. The game does offer a certain replay value, although it might not be enough for everyone to make them want to replay right away.The only real downside is that, compared to it's predecessor "Shantae and the Pirate's Curse", Half-Genie Hero feels a little more shallow, with less dialogues and a little less of the series' refreshing whacky humor. And even though most of the levels are extremely well designed, I really miss the dungeons of the previous game that had to be beaten at the end of a level.Still, if you're looking for a light-hearted, nicely paced platformer, I'd say you can't really go wrong here for the ~20â¬ this game costs. I for my part have had a lot of fun with this and will certainly keep a eye out for possible DLCs or additional content.You've made it this far. Thanks for reading my review. ;)

												Pros:-Stage music is incredibly catchy (like really good Sonic music catchy)-Extremely smooth and satisfying controls and platforming experience-Story and dialogue are cute and hilarious-Voice acting is adorable-Visuals are extremely sharp, animations are silky smoothCons:-Boss battle music is the worst in the series-The entire game is painfully easy, and disappointingly short (less than 5 hours to beat it, 8 hours to 100% it)-Boss fights look pretty, but are poorly designed (nearly impossible to dodge many mechanics, but trivial to just ignore the damage / eat consumables and faceroll through them)-A lot of the new content (kickstarter goals, I think) is inconsistent (a lot of the new transformations you get are borderline useless, and only exist to solve one or two specific puzzles)-Plot continuity has been effectively discarded, for those that actually cared about it (it's a prequel/not prequel/reboot/not-reboot ????????)Neutral:-Character design is generally more cute, less sexualizedTLDR: If you like Shantae, you'll love this game. Posted: December 30, 2016
												(Edited since the addition of hardcore mode)TL;DR: Good game, but a step back from the previous title. Initially downvoted because of lack of content, and even now I feel like the base game only barely meets the $20 asking price, especially since there will be paid DLC in the future (unless you were a backer in which case it's all free). If you're looking to get into the franchise, I would VERY strongly recommend Pirate's curse instead, or even Risky's Revenge: Director's Cut since Pirate's Curse is a continuation of that story.PROS:-Platforming is fluid and satisfying.-Absolutely amazing soundtrack. Less tracks here than PC, but what is here is golden. My only critique is that the first run of the first level had vocals which I found distracting, but that same track is also played during the credits which is perfectly fine.-Transformations are more fluid than previous games, and there are many more of them.-New art style isn't bad (chibi isn't really my thing personally, I prefer pixel sprites and Inti Creates' art style from Pirate's Curse).-Humorous dialogue. I laughed out loud on multiple occasions.CONS:-Easily my biggest issue is the switch from the metroidvania playstyle. There are no dungeons, no save stations and no open world. HGH plays more like a Megaman game. You have stages divided up into a few areas that give you a save option between them. Stages can be replayed from the beginning to collect upgrades/items previously unattainable, and later on you get the ability to warp ahead to the next area of a stage if what you're looking for is in that area, but there is no backtracking to the previous area in a stage. If you miss something in the previous area you have to restart the entire stage (warp is handy here).-Overall less content than PC, as stated before.-Story is severely lacking. Rather than an overarching plot, HGH consists of several mini-plots, none of which are very interesting.IMO, the game feels like less effort went into building the game and instead that effort went into creating new assets and engine. Probably the reason Pirate's Curse was so awesome was because it reused so many assets from Risky's Revenge, and so much more effort was able to go into the game itself. If so, then I can only hope that the next game turns out to be at least as successful as PC was by reusing assets from HGH.Also, I would absolutely LOVE to see the return of Inti Creates artwork for the next game.

Posted: April 23
												The latest, and second-best, entry into the Shantae series. A competent platformer full of fun characters, humor, and music along with an absolutely adorable art style, I can definitely recommend Half-Genie Hero, along with the rest of the series... especially Pirate's Curse.The gameplay is a level-based platformer with some seemingly token Metroidvania aspects, but continues the Shantae series's trend of moving away from a "true" Metroidvania style. Instead of complex levels as seen in previous titles, levels are now standard left-to-right platforming stages where you move through 2-3 areas and end with a boss. Metroidvania aspects come in when you have to repeat levels with new lock-and-key transformations (and unlockable powers for them) to find 'hidden' areas to collect collectibles for various NPCs or new abilities. This leads to the gameplay "loop" of doing a few new levels, getting to a plot roadblock, and backtracking to solve it.The world of Shantae does, however, make up its merely good-but-not-great gameplay. It's hard to not have fun in the colorful world filled with its genuinely likeable characters, humor, and music. As a entry-point into the series, you meet most, if not all, of the series's cast of characters and the humor isn't too reliant on referential in-jokes.Perhaps the most disappointing thing I can say about the game was the fact it was a Kickstarter game with more ideas than they hit stretch goals for, and it shows. Some characters are introduced and summarily dealt with in an incredibly unsatisfying manner, especially with a late-game *lack* of boss battle that can only be truly described as a "blue ballsing most foul" when it's presented and solved in the span of one cutscene.In the end, I can still recommend Half-Genie Hero and would recommend you try Pirate's Curse if you enjoy the world, which is the best part of every game in the series.

Posted: December 23, 2016
												Half Genie WaifuThe best waifu.But seriously though this is a great game. A charming artstyle with beautiful and bright HD graphics, fun level design, and tight platforming controls make this a must-buy for any fan of the 2D platforming genre. The mechanics of your genie powers, the great music, and Shantae's cheery personality itself makes this an amazing game in my opinion. If you like the idea of playing a head-strong, spunky girl who transforms into animals as she saves the day, then this is the game for you.This is more of a Megaman style of platforming than a Metroidvania, this means the levels are going to feel alot more linear at first. The real exploration comes from after you get your animal abilities, where the extra means of movement allow you to explore the untouched nooks and crannies  of the levels you previously cleared.The cons I can think of are:backtracking to find every item in every stage may get repetitive. However this is entirely optional unless you either want to do the little bit of extra work to get the good ending or just 100% complete the game.This game is also probably the easiest game in the Shantae series. Shop items might as well be given to you with how cheap they are, barely any real threats in terms of enemies, and thinking creatively will sometimes let you use your animal transformations to completely bypass entire sections of the game.  Edit:The new introduction of hardcore ups the difficulty on a grand scale. More enemies, different enemy placement, more damage, and new boss attacks make for a much more exhilerating experience.However.Even with its faults, I stil llove the game. It is an excellent edition to the series and a pretty good step forward.Personally I loved the story, but heads up, its episodic like a Saturday morning cartoon. *SPOILERS* There is no Big Evil threatening to destroy the entire planet that requires an epic adventure. Instead Shantae has to deal with a bunch of smaller threats and go on smaller adventures one at a time. It's less of "This is one of the most important days in this character's life" and more of a "This the stuff this young lady has to deal with sometimes."Using internet guides at the late part of the game, I was able to 100% the main default story within a total of about 7 hours. Its a short game, but it was fun enough that I'm going to be revisiting this story plenty more times. I also need to mention that there is going to be alot of DLC coming out in the future of writing this review. Costume swaps for Shantae, and extra story modes where you play as some of the side characters are all underway. As a fan of the series, I am very excited to see some of the other characters get some time in the spotlight.

Posted: March 5
												Shante: Half-Genie Hero is a good game but it has flaws that kind of ruin the game. But before we talk about those, let's talk about what the game did right first.Disclaimer: While I have only have played through the main story, these are what I like and dislike about the game.PROS:1. The level design. The game is a fairly challenging platformer with some Metroidvania elements added into mix that will keep you on your toes while looking for secrets in stages with it's megaman levels of precise platforming.2. The story. The story revolves around half human and half genie hero Shante helping her uncle build a machine called the Dynamo that will help protect her hometown, but while she is helping her uncle the barons and monsters in the land keep stirring trouble, and it's her job to travel across the land while meeting some very colorful charaters and put a stop to their evil plans.3. The Transformation dances. One of the main gameplay points is Shante's transformation dances, these dances allow her to transform into a multitude of creatures and animals that give specific abilites from swiming underwater with the mermaid to climbing on walls with the monkey and to taking it to the skies with the harpy.4.The bosses. I won't go into much detail on them, but the bosses in the game are very fun and creative, they also provide a unique challenge that make the game more interesting.Now that we covered the pros lets now go over the cons.CONS:1. The game is too short. While the game has good level design and fun bosses, there are only 6 stages in the entire game. Eventough each stage is composed of 4 segments, the game is very short. (It only took me about 8 hours to beat it.)2. 100%ing the game. Do want to know why it took me 8 hours to beat the game? Because I spent most of those 8 hours looking and grinding for all the items and equipment in the game. One of my personal gripes with Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is that completing the game is such a hassle. If you want to complete the game you will have to a METRICâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥TON OF BACKTRACKING since some of the items and stages requrire you to go back to a pevious stage and get a certain power or item(s) to progress. While the warp dance and having a guide to help you will give you less of a headache you still have to backtrack alot.Oh yeah, if you want to get all the achivements in the game, you have to speedrun all theâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥3. The Bat and Harpy transformation dances. Do you want to know how to beat half of the game? Go up to a high place and transform into one of these two free passes with wings, The bat and harpy allow you to fly, in a PLATFORMER. While you get the harpy late in the game, the bat transformation is the worst of the two since you can fly horizontal for as long as you want and you can get it in the 2nd stage!Anyway while Shantae: Half-Genie Hero is a fun and challenging game with a few issues. I would recommend it to anyone. But I highly recommend the you play it causaly if you don't to deal with the headache of completing the game.
